I'd like to preface this review with the fact that I am not good at this game. I get my ass kicked by pretty much every end game monster. HOWEVER, the horrific lack of quality of life features in this game is astounding, and makes the overall experience more pain than joy.

You can't skip these god forsaken cringe worthy cut scenes. The story in this game is not interesting, and it doesn't have to be. I just wanna kill big monsters with cool weapons.

At the end of the base game, it forces you through nearly 10 minutes of just credits. Why?

You can't play through the story with friends. All players must have started the mission solo and discovered the monsters UNSKIPPABLE CUTSCENE, then everyone has to join someones game. 

The monsters hitboxes are just awful. Sometimes I get knocked over by them, sometimes I don't. Sometimes I can roll out of the way of attacks, sometimes I can't. Probably a skill issue, but it still feels clunky and lazily designed.

Animations need to be 120% done in order for you to do anything else, with no animation queue system similar to Dark Souls or Elden Ring. Sometimes I click to start any animation like drinking a potion or using a whetstone, it just didn't do it and with no indication. Clunky and lazy.

I played this stupid game through because it gave me the occasional dopamine hit when I smacked the monsters dumb face with a big fucking sword. As of this review I'm still not done, this game is like meth and I can't stop playing it.

This game still holds up in 2024. The monster design is very well done, so is the environment design. There is a ton of armour and weapon variety although you have to grind a bit to get to the next set of armour and weapon upgrade. 
Some cons:
1. The systems aren't very well explained.
2. The menus are confusing.
3. The animations take long and you are stuck in it, you can't cancel.
However, you can get around those by playing intelligently. Recommended.

I've been in love with this series since 2010's Monster Hunter Tri. Monster Hunter World preserves the deep, chunky combat that Monster Hunter games are known for, but it's easily my least favorite entry. With its long, unskippable cutscenes, complicated maps, weak monster AI, and multiplayer jank all dragging down an otherwise solid time, World borders on being a bad play experience. It's beautiful but cluttered with triple-A fluff. If you're like me and want a more gameplay-focused experience, then you might want to consider the other entries.

I've never played a Monster Hunter game before, but when I saw this I knew I was about to fall in: MHW is a game where you fight and kill/capture big ol dinosaur monsters, cut em up, turn em into gear, and kill bigger dinosaurs. Choose from a wide assortment of strange weapons, melee and projectile, and use traps and equipment to make your job easier. Overall, a fun but very complex game for friends to get down on. Highly recommended with some caveats:

The game design is sometimes oblique and most of the games information is imparted in either a constant barrage of tutorial text, requiring you to stop gameplay and read a combination of "basic shit everyone knows about videogames" and "actual information you need to understand this game", or *not at all* (for example, affinity is not explained ingame). It doesn't seem to know who it's catering to so it instead covers most of the bases, resulting in more confusion for experienced players (the person who had the least trouble with anything in this game in my group was the one who understood the least about games in general). It at least stores this info in a guidebook for you, but seriously guys, try some audiovisual cues and congruous design and you wouldn't have to impart paragraphs of info to the player like a fucking text adventure.

The story is the weakest part of the game and basically only exists to give you some context on how to progress. The actual writing is boring, the characters are hyper 2-dimensional, the cutscenes are forgettable at best, and the whole goal and plot is literally "kill dinosaur, make gear, kill bigger dinosaur, make better gear". That's ok though, it works. Switching the voice language to "Monster Hunter Language" improves the immersion though, as the writing can be forgiven if you consider these are literally cavemen.

This is the biggest problem in this game by far: Creatures can do status effects like roaring to interrupt your attacks, but the game doesn't explicitly tell you this is happening, and unlike any other game in history it doesn't apply a status effect: you only know it's happening when you're mashing keys and your character is standing in place jerking himself off. This results in one of the most frustrating combat systems I've ever played. Be prepared to be mid-fight when your character will stop what they are doing to comically roll their head around like they're confused as you FURIOUSLY mash keys. This is easily the worst part of the gameplay, knowing how to avoid it doesn't help that it's clunky as fuck. I get that I've been BLINDED but in what fucking universe does that mean I can't use my fucking legs? Just white out my screen and let me flail around like the monsters do when they've been blinded, or like any real thing does in real life. I get it for the paralysis, when you get shocked you're pretty immobile, but fucking blinded or roared at? Are you fucking joking? Holy fuck nuggets.
>>Like what if someone threw a flashbang in Counter-Strike, but instead of blinding you it made your character wipe his eyes and stand stationary while you watch other players kill you? That's the system at play here and it's fucking retarded. Shit ass fuck I could go on and on about how badly this part of the combat loop is designed. Everything else is fine but this is just so bad it feels like a game mechanic from an N64 game was hamfisted into a modern game. It breaks immersion, disconnects you from your character, and all around these mechanics have been done better in worse games.

We constantly found ourselves wishing for features only to find them, later, in weird places. Like at the start of a mission you can access a supply box that looks a lot like the one you use to equip weapons, so for the longest time we thought you couldn't modify your loadout while out on expedition; but you can, you instead *turn around* in the campsite and walk into the tent. Cool, okay, but why get me used to accessing a fucking crate if you're gonna make it into a tent in the game?

The main area you spawn in looks like a hub, but no players are here. I thought I was disconnected but no, the main area is a singleplayer zone for some reason, and the gathering hub is a seperate place, a small area, that nobody ever uses. It is empty 100% of the time because it's just a waste of time to go there - you can't really do anything there other than see other players in the lobby...? The fuck is the point of this?

BUT I digress, these issues are never enough to make the game bad because the gameplay and gameplay loop is so tight, and once you figure out what they (the game designers) intended, the issues are forgotten. Except in the case of being blinded/roared at, someone dropped the fucking ball there. I love seeing my buster-sword wielding barbarian stumble around after getting yelled at like a toddler. What the fuck

Very fun, insane learning curve. You build a relationship with your weapon and playstyle, and once you get past being knocked down every 5 seconds you start to feel cool and aesthetic. Some of the best, long term progression of any game ever. Endgame has a lot of grinding and farming, but since the skill curve is so large you're still engaged with repeatedly throwing yourself at certain monsters, getting better at reading them each time and things not feeling like a slog. 

Third party resources like the wiki are pretty much required. You're gonna be googling how to target farm specific things you need, or farm decorations. 

Get Iceborne. The extended movesets and clutch claw are VITAL.

Poor online services and waiting for cutscenes sucks, but oh well.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked Nobushi and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a custom duel for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I've finally gotten around to playing Monster Hunter: World, and seeing the main story line thru to its completion after six years of seeing it pass me by. No regrets buying or playing this game, even if the Monster Hunter community has moved on to other more recent titles in the franchise. The graphics, the gameplay mechanics, even by today's standards hold up very well. Where it falls short for me is in the story line. It's a bit short (though I plan on buying Iceborne soon to "complete" the game). The boss battles are also very underwhelming; Zorah Magdaros, Zeno Jiiva, and even a couple of the other Elder Dragon fights fail to put pressure on the player to use dodging attacks and pivots to the best of their abilities because the primary targets move way too slow, so reacting to their attacks is a sinche. After beating the main story line, the rest of the game becomes a grind fest for shiny gear and clout (trying to look cooler than the other players). There's really no point in playing the game beyond the story line, or once you've acquired a few desired armor sets and loadouts that you enjoy playing. Still, well worth the time, energy, and the purchase if you like video games that center on cooperative gameplay, and an engaging and unique melee combat system during the fights.

I've been playing Monster Hunter Series since the release of MH4U (Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate) on Nintendo 3DS. Visually the game is really good from what I see on game-plays online (Running this one on lowest possible option as my System specs is low LMAO). Now that's out of the way here is my opinion on the game besides the Visuals.

[h2] Monster Designs [/h2]
From old to new monsters in the game, chef's kiss. It's really good to see the old monsters getting that update ([spoiler] Deviljho [/spoiler] ~ my beloved). As for the new monsters I liked the overall designs, specifically the [spoiler] Xeno'Jiiva [/spoiler], it reminds me of the battle with Shagaru Magala from MH4U. Btw this is my opinion only but [spoiler] Kushala Daora can succ da pp with its wind pressure BS [/spoiler].

[h2] Maps/Maps Design [/h2]
The environment changes (i.e day and night system and weather change on ancient forest), the design of each map, and also THANK GOODNESS, NO MORE LOADING SCREEN EVERY SECTION CHANGE ON THE MAP! So when chasing down your prey, it is more engaging and fun since no loading screens cut off your actions, cause on the older series the monsters can be saved by literally the borders of the map. 

[h2] Gameplay and Game Mechanics [/h2]
Let me start on the best mechanic of the game in my humble opinion. THE MONSTER CLASHES/ TURF WAR. IT IS LIKE WATCHING WRESTLING MATCHES, BUT WITH MONSTERS. [spoiler] Deviljho [/spoiler] once again my beloved~  suddenly shows up when I was hunting a [spoiler] Rathalos [/spoiler], they roared at each other like The Undertaker facing up with Ray Mysterio talking "cheese" before getting it on. My beloved grabbed that Flying Wyvern off the sky and slammed it down to the ground, and as I was watching like a Judge in the mushroom corner, My beloved suddenly faced on my direction and then JUST DRAGGED, THEN THREW [spoiler] Rathalos [/spoiler] IN MY WAY, HITTING ME. (sorry for the narration can't help it). It gives you a challenge especially when [spoiler] Bazelgeuse starts to carpet bomb your area [/spoiler].  Now throughout the map, there are stationary traps, which gives the player the advantage when the monster gets baited. [spoiler] Then when mounting monsters it now gives you an option to choose the part you can weaken and also finish it with a finisher move [/spoiler]. The clunky controls from the past series is gone, the movement is really smooth. No more stopping when consuming items (except for whetstones, which make sense) and the overall movement animation had really improved after Generations. Add to that the grappling mechanics as the cherry on top.

The weapons mechanic and game-play also slaps, the additional move sets and special abilities gives new players more chances of survival and for old players to basically exploit and break the monsters even more. The attack transitions are now really fast and smooth and makes the timing of your attacks even more accurate. My only bad take is that they removed oils for the Sword and Shield. 

[h2] Gameplay and Game Mechanics [/h2]
The sounds makes the hunts more immersive but also gives you an easier time with the specific monster sound cues, the ambience of each map is great, you can sometimes just relax, fish, or spitroast meat, and just listen on the ambience of the [spoiler] Ancient Forest [/spoiler]. As for the music, it suits the situations you are in really well.

[h1] Overall [/h1]
Monster Hunter: World not only lives up to the series, it is an evolution, as a monster hunter fan I can't wait what comes after world and Iceborne (which I will get on the next sale).

Monster Hunter World is an adventure-RPG game. The objective is to complete quests by hunting ever bigger monsters. You play as a member of the Fifth Fleet who got waylaid by the Zorah Magdross, a lumbering Elder Dragon trying to reach the Everstream so that it can die. Your job is to divert the Elder Dragon so that it won't reach the Everstream and cause a massive explosion.

Gameplay-wise, mouse and keyboard.

Gameloop. Kill the list of monsters. Then, go through the loop with +,++,+++ versions of the monsters. Feels repetitive. While you can hunt them in different zones, it's a small plus and not as exciting. It feels like a core Barroth model is used for all bipedals e.g. Anjanath, Gastodon, Kestodon. Then, a Barroth with rolling for Uragaan. Dragon model for Rathian, Rathalos, flying.

Size Feel. Personally, I feel the boss battles are small. Not because of the damage or difficulty but because of the number of players. In MMOs, up to 25 players (or bots) hunt a big boss monster. In MHW, it just feels small.

Conclusion, MHW is okay. Was the dung beetle a hint? It's playable but it's not fantastic. It feels strange when you compare it to other AAA games e.g. Camera-lock works in other games. MWH feels like Final Fantasy 15 minus a whole lot of features.

If MWH follows the movie, there should be a massive desert to sail across. There should be a giant tower. A spider-boss monster. 

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Fishing 
Feels good to see the fish that I'm fishing. It's significantly better than World of Warcraft fishing as you can see the fish. You can't just fish in any puddle of water.

2. Monster vs Monster combat
Quite cool to watch. I like the monsters feeding on smaller creatures as well.

3. Multiplayer SOS Flare
Yes, this is interesting. Though my experience felt like killing monsters with bots.

4. Monster Riding
Yes, I like that a lot. Jump/Glide into the air and press Attack on the back/tail. If you're lucky, you get to stab it.

5. Food
I like the food art. Though I felt that skipping to the platter was too fast.

6. Scoutflies
At the beginning, meh. But when you changed the colour of scoutflies into green and blue, that made me realise there's potential. The normal version is silly, all green and you can't differentiate between quest and item.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Combat
I do not like pressing multiple buttons only to see my character perform kata and not hit anything. Having to sheathe and unsheathe your weapon is a major pain in the ass.

I really hate having to draw your weapon. The delay is so annoying.

2. Parallel Weapons Upgrading
Why parallel upgrades? I was hoping to stack multiple buffs onto 1 weapon. Instead, I got Bone, Ore, Monster, Defender, etc Is there really any difference? I didn't feel it. Maybe you need a tutorial to show the benefits of each type?

3. Life Bar
Honestly, I don't understand the heartbeat meter at the bottom of the screen. The player has a lifebar and stamina bar. Why doesn't the monster have one?

4. Ugly Icons
How in the world do you differentiate between yellow mushroom and pale yellow mushroom? Could someone make nice icons? Use images of Lingzhi vs Enoki. That's fine. Just make it discernible.

5. Confusing Controls Ranged Weapons
Why does mouse scroll work differently when you use a ranged weapon? You can't scroll between items.

6. Claustrophobic
The bases are so small. Even though you think there's a whole base, there's actually only a limited zone to move in.

The hunting zones. So tiny. It takes minutes to complete a whole run. 

7. Hunting
Quite dull. Touch some poop/footprint and use the scoutflies to find the monster. 

8. Quicksand in the Wildspire Wastes
It did not work like quicksand. I was expecting it to suck you and the Monster down.Then, you would fight in the cave with the Diablos.

9. Heavy Bowgun + Long List of Ammo
I felt that there was a really long list of ammo to scroll through. 

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Combat
Less kata, less flashy, more hits.

2. Swimming
I would like to hunt water creatures i.e. Assassin's Creed Black Flag.

3. Hints
Shoot the stalactite? Where? Hint, please. Make it glow.

4. Body Parts Highlighter
Refer to Horizon Zero. Highlight certain strong and weak points, so players know what to aim for. Turn off the highlighter until the Researcher gives you knowledge about the strong/weak points and timings. E.g. Don't hit the scaled back. Hit the glowing belly.

5. Monster-ily Functions
Do the monsters poop? More immersive to see the monster relieving itself and then you take the moment to ambush it. Disgusting, yes. But not being able to poop is abnormal. If normal body functions don't make sense, then how about feeling sick?

6. Request For Monster
How about big Snake-like monsters? Giant cobra that spits venom. Giant python that wraps around you and strangles you to death.

7. Monster Taming
Natural progression. I want to ride a Barroth. Even better, I want to ride Negrigante.

Monster Taming at the max level? Only when you're a Master Hunter, can you move onto taming the Monsters.

8. Hunting 
I prefer the hunting style in Evolve. I felt Evolve is a good fit for Monster Hunter. Instead of +,++,+++ monsters, "evolved" versions of the Monster, like Pokemon's Abra, Kadabra, Alakazam. Different because their size and skin changes and they have access to more powerful skills.

I like the harpoon trap gun. It fires single traps onto the ground that will ensnare the monster when it runs by one. The monster has to attack the leash/snare to get free.

9. Evolution and Babies
What does a Baby Barroth look like? I mean, Barroths are not Elder Dragons so they should have a baby form, adolescent form, adult form. Wyverns have eggs. It's sensible to have the 3 stages of a Wyvern. 

If there's a Rathalos and a Rathian, there should be a baby Rath. Where is it?

10. Capture Harvest
If you can turn a Bitterbug into medicine, why can't you capture (not hunt) Vespoids/Hornetaurs and turn them into items? 

11. Timed Zones
So, I noticed there's water and mud. How about tides? High tide and low tide? At high tide, the zone is flooded and you're swimming a lot. At low tide, mud and no water.

13. Ammo
I felt that it could be simplified into bullets with upgrades. E.g. Bullet adds Paralysis II + Stun I + Burn V. Limited to the effects and its level. So, you could craft ultra powerful bullets by stacking the effects. However, the cost would go up exponentially and you would need a lot of resources to make really powerful bullets.

That way, you only choose 1 set of bullets and you don't scroll through the list. Slow ammo with its slow charge, like Wyvern ammo, could easily be upgraded to fire faster.

14. Food
As you complete quests and collect more ingredients, more dishes appear on your platter. Instead of platters, you combine Appetiser + Main + Dessert (AMD) into a meal. You can mix and match e.g. 
Clam Chowder + Anjath Steak + Honeyed Fruits. 
Bug Salad + Grilled Gunpowderfish + Honeyed Fruits


15. World-level Improvements
MH World feels small. It feels like it should be in an open world with various Monsters roaming all over the place. It feels like there should be Monster Territories where you have to be careful in. You can pass through but if you get caught by a Diablos, it will actively hunt you down by sniffing for your scent and tracking you (The Boss Monster should hunt you down). You have to find ways to stealth; hide, swim, crawl, find secret paths, set up bait to feed the Boss Monster, lure it to its favourite food to distract it, smear dung on yourself to make it ignore you, camouflage, choose the time of day when the Boss Monster is sleeping to move in (nocturnals are active at night, sleep in the day).

Combine Research Base with the Main Base
Put a fishing jetty in the Main Base to teach newbies the basics of fishing. The Main Base is a convenient spot for players to relax and fish. Maybe sometimes players want to play a fishing minigame instead?

Played this ages ago on playstation, finished it, my opinion is still just about the same if not worst after getting through the iceborne dlc.

Start off with one of my main annoyances that hasn't changed. A monster being on the verge of dying with no clear sign that's their current state. You can have their research maxed out and still, it doesn't show the skull on the minimap straight away, if you just staggered or mount them or whatever, they won't roar and go to limp away straight away and so on so on. The amount of times i've killed shit because i've had zero indication of it about to die because i've been slamming it and staggered it so it doesn't end up trying to leave is annoying. The 2 red slinger ammo drops is not a realiable option either when some monsters drop more then 2. 

Then the hitboxes are still absolute dogshit on half the monsters, you can slow-mo a clip of yourself getting hit and clear as day see nothing touch you, but you still get fully slapped. Yet on other the other half of monsters, you can have an attack go right next to you and nothing at all and no, im not mistaking the attacks for wind pressure or explosions or whatever.

Then you got this mastermode bs, it's honestly just a boring annoying mode where most bosses just spam the same stupid move over and over, there is no fun in this. Take darkveil val hazak for example, i had that prick do his downward breath ability 5 times in a row. How the fk am i meant to do the fight if he is just gonna keep spamming it. shara ishvalda is the same with his frontal beam bullshit when im not even infront of him half the time, but at least i can still attack him while he spams it.

Then there's the fucking palico, one of the most dogshit ai i have ever seen for a teammate. The amount of times this rat will decide to bring a heal right as you healed is just stupid, no headsup, just gonna waste a heal. Then he constantly just stands there and does nothing any time you get slept or stunned, instead of knocking you over like he use to, doesn't seem to do it anymore.

Then there's stupid shit like his deployable heal on the ground, half the time i go to line up an attack on a sleeping monster, he will deploy it right infront of me mid attack, again, wasting a heal, for no reason other then bad ai.

And then the worst thing, on the odd chance i do actually die, the cats revival thing is just beyond annoying and a waste of time, might as well just turn it off, because majority of the time you get revived by him, the moment you're standing, before you can roll or block or anything, you get slammed with an attack and die again, no invulnerability for a second to let you actually react. Happened earlier on shara ishvalda, had an unlucky death and i get revived into his frontal beam. Like why even waste my fucking time.

The cooking is still just a nuisance for doing custom platters.

Armor that has resist to for example, thunder but also has thunder attack skill on it, still exist which is just stupid because you're not gonna use thunder attack against something you want thunder resist against. It's a complete waste of an armor, also got the poor optimization of the B version gear, for example, shara ishvaldas a+ boots have part breaker +2 and defense boost +2. Instead of the B version lose 2 points of defense boost, it just loses 1 point of part breaker and defense boost. Shit like this is just a waste of a piece of gear, no-one is gonna use that. Legit woulda been awesome to have 2 partbreaker but nope, ruined by poor optimization on the gear, this isn't me just wanting gear to be super convenient and broken. This is just wanting the gear to actually look like a viable option to use.

Also, wish i had the option to customize the item pouch wheel to cluster heals and traps together. Don't care too much for the radial wheel.

Oh and another massive gripe i have with the game that still exist. Using mantles, the mantle expires but when you sheathe your weapon, it doesn't auto take it off, making you have to stop and use it again. I want my tools going on cooldown as soon as im done with them, not having to find manually plop that shit off when ive already gone and sheathed my weapon.

And also the manage investigations menu, why is there no multiselect for deleting investigations??? Only options are to delete all of them or, to remove them one at a time with a prompt each time. Super slow and annoying.

It's just simple shit that makes all the difference. It really is.

Honestly, the more i play these late game bosses, the more i see just how bad and lazy these devs are. I'm fighting the furious rajang and he just uses his jump spray breath attack 4 times in a row on me, legit no didn't move or anything, he just kept jumping and spraying over and over. This is just fucking boring.

How is it, 6 years this game has been out and this is the best they can do to increase difficulty. Just make the monsters spam the same attack, over and over. Give them follow up moves to their moves and what not. Not bad ai that use same shit over and over.

Oh and one more big fucking thing. Why the hell the stupidly small amount of time at the end of a mission after killing the monster. You got shit like kulve where 60 seconds is literally not enough time sometimes, cunt has so much loot. Capture missions are annoying too, maybe you got a tail to loot, maybe you need the ore in the room. And so on so on, it just isn't needed, i will leave the fking mission when i am done. Absolute clownery

Yknow whats also fucking fun? Breath attacks that go through the floor and walls. How the fuck is that a thing. These devs are a joke.

Also, another loot related thing, why the fk would you add guiding lands, with all the loot they drop from smashing them into walls and breaking their shit and still only have a 2 minute loot despawn timer. They drop so much shit and im busy kicking their ass and loot ends up despawning time to time.

Let's add a bit more onto this. The guiding lands, cool place, bit glitchy which can be annoying, but a decent idea overall. That said, completely ruined by whatever idiot decided we can't just level all the zones to lvl 7. What a ridiculous grind that is, because for example, let's say i grind 15 tempered stygian zingores from lvl 7 hoarfrost zone, if i eventually run out of his resource and hoarfrost is at lvl 1 because i went and grinded the other stuff, i would then have to grind a shit ton of monsters i don't need a single thing from, all because of this augmentation stuff which is extremely worth getting. This really is just killing any fun or motivation, its stupidly slow, i've already done all the tempered stuff in wildspire, forest, tundra a shit ton so i dont have to relvl them again, now im just spamming non tempered monsters i dont even need, it just all feels like a total waste of time.

There is legit no reason for other zones to de-level when leveling up other zones. It's a dogshit system, if we want every zone at lvl 7, then we should be able to have it with a normal grind speed, we still have to bloody grind our way up then grind the mobs at that zone level. Absolute muppets made this shit.

I'm not here to disparage this game, as I know a lot of people really enjoy it.  But I am here to provide input for potential purchasers who are like me.  I can see how others can really enjoy this game, but it is most definitely not for me.  This game is written with a view that is different from the games I normally play.  I could be wrong, but I attribute it to being designed and developed by people from a different culture.  And while different is OFTEN good in my experience, in this case I found the differences are keeping me from enjoying it.  I suspect I'm just too old a dog to appreciate new tricks. As far as specifics (and some of these matter and others, well, are just personal disappointments):   I have never, in my 30+ year gaming experience had so much information presented to me to, ostensibly, help me, while at he same time feeling more lost than I ever have in a game.   The games continuous popups to explain were really appreciated when I first saw them.  But later, I realized, my eyes had glazed over and I was no longer reading them.  Basically, if you have to present that many popups to explain things, then your stuff's a wee bit too complicated imho.  Next, we tried to do multiplayer and have given up.  It's not that we couldn't make it happen, it's just too complicated to do!  All we wanted was to play together, and it is so friggin' complicated that we've now shelved the game.  Oh, and the complicated game play is way out of proportion to the complicated nature of the play.  In other words, I have really complicated games in my library, but the story and consequences merit that complexity.   Here, it feels like the game concept is simple, whereas the game mechanics and interface and hugely complicated.  In short, I don't care enough about the game to deal with all this complexity.  Or said another way, we though we were going to pop into a game where we'd have some fun playing together, developing our characters and slaying some monsters.  But the complexity of the interface and understanding how the game works, just sapped us of any desire to play it.  If I wanted this much complexity in my life, I'd play a strategy game (Stellaris) or a 'reallife' shooter (Escape from Tarkov), or pick up a simulator (flight or racing).  I don't want or need this kind of complexity for slashing dinosaurs.  My daughter (and adult gamer) and I got two copies of this to play, and we were thinking we'd maybe invite my wife to play if we had fun.  There is no way I would invite a non- or quasi- gamer to play this game.  It's way too complex for such a person.  The reward versus the investment of time to understand this game is just way out of whack for us.  Again, I see many people love this game.  I am not here to rain on their parade.  All I am saying is that this game was a major mismatch with me (60 yrs of age) and my adult daughter (25 yrs of age).  Now, to be fair, she seems to enjoy the game itself, but was completely washing her hands of the multiplayer aspect.  Way too complicated to figure out when you could and could not play with another and under what circumstances and only after you started your mission, but only after you watched this cutscene, blah blah blah blah.  complete insanity as far as we were concerned.  And i know there many MANY out there who will read this and go "but it's simple, just do.."  I am a software developer who has been coding UIs and playing games since the late 1980s.  I was there for DOOMs launch.  I have played complicated games.  I networked back when we'd have net-meets and had to create LANs to get multiplayer.  I have spent hundreds, if not thousands of hours in Falcon 4.0, one of the most complicated sims ever released.  I know complicated.  But since the 2000s we have, thankfully, existed in world where developers have increasingly created UI-friendly games (I mean, when was the last time you have even seen a manual for game?)   This game REQUIRES a manual.  They didn't create one in favor of putting in all this help inline, but the fact that it is so needed is only proof that the UI is overly complicated.

So, as you contemplate acquiring this game, you may just never know.  Will it click with you?  Will the complicated UI be easily understandable?  No way to know really.  If you can, play a friend's copy, or see if you can find a demo.  I'd give you my copy but no-can-do I'm afraid.

Bought both base and DLC, one of my best money investments in a game in a long while.

TL;DR
What I liked:
- Dungeon based game (can do small session of 10-20 mins and quit for the day).
- Can play Solo the entire game (HP scales based on number of players).
- Got co-op, with randoms too, mostly nice people.
- Lots of quests and story to progress.
- Many different mechanics - both monsters and weapons.
- Grinding is unnecessary, mostly a few kills of each monster is enough to gain full set + weapon.
- Easy to farm big amount of decorations (status jewels for weapon/armor)
- Graphics not bad at all.
- The scenery is very pretty and has nice interactions like swim in water, walk in snow, swing on ropes.
- Can customize the character appearance very easily (with some difficult monsters to beat to look the coolest!)
- DLC made the game trice if not longer than the base game.
- Have some nice events for full session (16 people) that change every 2 weeks, lots of players doing that content, easy to find and join (2 special raid bosses).
- 1-2 Weekly seasonal events very often!

What I didn't like:
- Hard to start co-op at first, its not very intuitive until you figure it out and get used to it.
- A bit bothersome to play story line with a friend - both have to solo watch cut-scenes before joining the other's quest.
- A disconnect from game completely kicks you out of the mission without way back (quest char slot wasted).
- Some decoration (status jewels) are extremely rare - still don't understand why.

Play Summery: 
Looked for a game to play with a friend (duo) for casuals, adults don't have 5+ hours straight of free time to play. world+Ice borne was very recommended. 
We started with base only, we almost dropped it at the very first few days because the co-op took a while to understand and setup, was very frustrating until we got the hang of it.
We got kind of pissed that we couldn't do story together from the first sec. each one has to start the story, see the cut-scene, then one has to quit his quest and join the others quest.
Game was still fun overall, lots of mechanics and some challenging monsters.
Decided we had fun, and bought DLC ice borne.
DLC has about twice as much content as base if not more - very pleasantly surprising.
Much less cut-scenes and we also figured all the co-op by now.
Played a month alone when friend was on vacation - very late but discovered the amazing SOS co-op system they have. very fun thing to help/fight with others that want to do the same quest you do.
Started getting to end-game builds and finishing most of the content.
Farmed some decorations, not the rarest thought (with my playing time only had 3 of Expert+4 and Challenger+4, not a single Attack+4!!!! why so hard?!)
Had some tough monsters to fight at the end, that took more than 1 try to learn most of the mechanics (like alatreon and fatalis - fatalis took us the longest to beat, i think we tried for about 5+ adult's days for a lucky 1st win)
Beat all the hardest bosses, got the best gear and best weapon/armor improvements including layered armor (only for looks).
Finished all optional content possible to have 100% complete quests and colored-title (about 80% achievements done).
after my 639 hours invested (MR 400~) and friends 500+ hours (MR 300~), we happily quit a fun game.
S tier game that rewards preparation and developing skill

I like the slow, methodical combat that tends to favour spacing, timing and aiming of your attacks towards a monster's weak points. I'm sure there are a bazillion ways to break the game, and I hear the clutch claw mechanic from the Iceborne DLC presumably undermines what makes Monter Hunter's combat uniquely satisfying. But the game at its core is about patience and carefully observing a monster's movement and attack patterns while waiting for that perfect opportunity to deliver powerful blows with some of the most gratifying and creative weapons I've ever seen in a melee-based action game. The quality of the animations and sound design in MH World is excellent, and that extends to the environments more broadly.

The net code of this game is trashy, me and my friends are constantly disconnected from each other. Note that you can't reconnect after a disconnect, so you're left alone against monster 4x stronger. You also can't restart the quest for you friends to join, because you just used a "daily bonus" to get extra loot if you succeed and if you restart you'll lose it.

This was my first dip into the Monster Hunter games, and even after falling in love and playing older and newer titles, it's still by far the best one. It's the most polished entry, and provides a good challenge for anyone at any skill level. There's only a couple major issues I have with it, but it's so close to a masterpiece that it's certainly worth looking past. The quest cutscenes are antithetical to the multiplayer experience, the controls are unintuitive and the tutorials don't explain very well how things work and leaves you hanging if you do things right without realizing, so it takes some research, experimentation, and a lot of input remapping (or just using a controller for some folks) to get to a point where you can be comfortable. There's a bit of friction with the smithy cutscenes and forge/upgrade UI, and I would just love if they took the new approach in Rise and stuck it in there. Overall though, this feels more like monster hunting than any of the other games with the scoutflies mechanic, even if it feels a little stilted sometimes. It's an incredible experience, and I hope Capcom continues building upon it in the future.

There are Dinosaurs, Dragons and more.

They are PISSED.

You must eliminate them. Whether done by a swift slash, a great BONK or some pew pews, the choice is yours. There are 14 weapons to choose. You can just main a single weapon, use all 14 or anything in between.

As a new player, as per recommendations from older players, I suggest picking the leather/chainmail gear at the beginning and avoiding the DEFENDER and GUARDIAN weapons/armor. unless you want to play on easy/free mode. With these tools you will basically one shot every monster and not learn how to play the game properly. I am happy I listened to this advice for my first playthrough so I can enjoy the process of learning the base game. Also download the HD texture pack DLC if your rig can run it. You will thank me later for these suggestions.

PS: DODODAMA TITSI YA YA KOO KULU YAPI

[h1]8/10[/h1]
Finished my third full playthrough of the base game, and it's still holding up really well. This time around, I decided to explore the Great Sword after previously diving into the Switch Axe and Charge Blade/Gun Lance. Each weapon feels distinct, offering a lot of content for those looking to master them all.

I managed to rush through the base game in about 30 hours this time, eager to dive into Iceborne without rushing so much that I sacrificed my enjoyment.

However, there were a few gripes that dampened my experience. The unskippable cutscenes, the presence of the handler (being one of the most annoying characters ever created), and the moments when the gameplay holds your hand a bit too much, disrupting the flow, were particularly bothersome.

Despite these complaints, I still found plenty to enjoy, even after sinking 250 hours into the game three years ago. I'd wholeheartedly recommend it, even at full price, but it's worth waiting for a sale if you can snag it cheaper.

Good game with good dlc. I like the gameplay, despite that the hookclaws can get old over time. The grounded combat combined with tactical awareness I need to deploy to hunt the monsters is what makes this game worth it. I do recommend people to get the Iceborne expansion as well, cause there are more monsters to hunt and the endboss of the Iceborne story line + the endboss of the endgame content are both better than the endgame boss of World proper. Only actual downside of this expansion I experienced are the copy-paste monsters in the first half of the Iceborne expansion, but it gets better later on. This game also doesn't have the 2 weeb waifus maidens from Rise/Sunbreak, which is also a plus in my book. You can also play Co-op if you want, but against Fatalis and Alatreon, you are better off doing them solo.

Slight spoilers for the core game loop, so like first 2 hours. No story.

[h2] Cool stuff [/h2]
The game revolves around the idea of a monster being so significant that it takes 10-20 minutes to defeat, and makes that exciting by making monster attacks significant. You have to play around the monster behavior, time your attacks and your positioning properly. That is fun and sometimes successful read of the monster makes it satisfying. The world is also immersive, the monster behavior and how they react to the player actions.

[h2] But, [/h2] there are many problems that make the whole ordeal irritating and boring.

[h3]1) Monster combat is supposed to be the highlight of the game, but some times it's extremely irritating and feels unfair[/h3] Sometimes attacks are not telegraphed properly. It's just walking and it hits with a huge hitbox. If you're unlucky enough, enemy might chain attack you and since the hitboxes are so huge and you don't have much of a choice, you get back up and get hit. I had a powerful armor set with health up stuff when I got chain attacked and died. This doesn't really leave you much of a choice but to play extremely defensively, maybe learn the enemy for a long time before you feel confident. That process extends the already long combat. Not to mention the mounting mechanic where you try to get on top of the monster, but if it decides to attack after attack you just get baited into getting hit. With a melee weapon, you are kind of left out of choice, you just wait for the monster to land.

[h3]2) Most of time is spent running[/h3] Especially if the monster can fly. You run for 2 minutes, right as you approach the monster it flies away. This happened to me in succession where I spent about 10 minutes running and 10 minutes fighting in a single hunt. Running isn't fun.

[h3]3) Extremely grindy[/h3] I think a single upgrade takes about 1 hour of grinding, and you have about 6 equipment and about 4 layers of upgrades, at like the middle point of the game. 30 hours in-ish. That's I suspect 24 hours of grinding. I didn't go for the last layer, so yea.

[h3]Verdict or something[/h3] I've played games that revolve around enemies in similar ways, so I'm not stranger to the concept. But it became a big chore at some point, and sometimes it didn't feel like I played bad but died anyways so I quit.
My introduction into the Monster Hunter series and easily one of my favorite games of all time. Easily worth every penny and every second of time I've gotten out of this game!

This game is fun, and not only does it let you play with friends, but you can grind for materials, even if it gets a little hectic.

You have daily quest, weekly quest, limited event, force multi-play mission, extremely low equipment drop rate, anti-save-load mechanism everywhere to prevent you get desired items quickly. In the mean while this is not a cloud save, login account based game, they put the critical game save data locally to make cheating possible and there is no such thing like VAC ban to prevent you from do that.

Although some of these elements are series traditional retrospectively to ancient days like Monster Hunter portable 3rd, but the online part are very similar to mobile gacha game in recent years - - make the game doesn't experienced like a typically single play game if you ever considered something like The Witcher Enhanced Edition (Witcher 1), and more like Genshin Impact.

In the end, Capcom indeed doesn't force you to have save data on the cloud - - only have account permission like Genshin Impact to prevent you from cheating, you also get RNG chance for free instead of paying 100$ to play slot machine (also Genshin Impact), Capcom didn't receive anything from you for those rare in game items. However these game design still just make gamers to contribute online hours for unknown reason, instead of selling experience in good old days.

Disclaimer: What I have mentioned are happens after main quest line, Capcom leave countless difficulties to prevent you from truly cleared the game. So far so good, untill I ever need a "Golden Dragonsphire" but can't find anywhere in the game, I discovered I'll have to wait for 2 weeks to wait event start, so I can unlock master level Kulve Taroth. Comments are written under fury.

I thought I didn't like this game back when I played the bejesus out of it on PS4.  Turns out there are things I don't like about it - the extra sponginess of the monsters, the art direction is a little boring, the handler isn't guildmarm, the fact that it wasn't portable (at the time), everything about Kushala Daora here - but it does feel like I'm actually hunting the monsters unlike Rise.  I also appreciate the pacing.  

But this isn't a knock against Rise either; they're just two different cuts of beef.  This one is like a medium well steak with some gristle you've gotta cut around.  Rise is like a burger where they forgot to leave off the ketchup when I requested no ketchup.  I think I'm hungry.

Monster Hunter World is an absolute gem in the gaming world! From its breathtaking landscapes to the adrenaline-pumping battles against colossal beasts, every moment is a thrilling adventure. The attention to detail in monster design and environmental graphics is unparalleled, immersing players in a rich, vibrant world. With its deep gameplay mechanics and satisfying progression system, every hunt feels rewarding. Whether you're a seasoned hunter or a newcomer to the series, Monster Hunter World offers countless hours of exhilarating gameplay and unforgettable experiences. Amazing game!! Worth every single penny and i mean it. Beautiful graphics that has withheld the test of time along with satisfying action. Not as grindy as your typical grinding game so perfect for those that want to spend each weekend slowly progressing towards the end! Mechanics are clunky when you first start however once you get into it, it becomes a lot more fluid. Exploring the world is a breathtaking sight! Of course i recommend getting the Iceborne DLC along with the game since it expands the game and allows you to unlock more weapons and armors that you can't get in the regular monster hunter world game. The Iceborne DLC will give you the true ending of the game! Enjoy and have a great time with your grind either when you are playing alone or with your group of friends!

The Monster Hunter Series is just great. I started playing this game when it came out on XBOX and put a lot of hours into it. I highly recommend this game for anyone who is new or old too the series and always have fun playing it (Except if I am hunting any form of Tigrex it is the bane of my existence and I wish they'd forget he was ever a monster). The game series has many unique and interesting Monsters to fight with a super amazing orchestral sound track unique too almost each and every one. I know this game is getting some players with #returntoworld happening after the announcement of the next game Monster Hunter Wilds which I hope is a huge success. These games have such an awesome feel and sense of community too them. I once again HIGHLY recommend you play this game if you're interested (there is truly no better fun than cooking a well done steak mid fight with Nergigante) plus it goes on sale all the time.

The best monster hunter to date and my favorite game of all time. From the ecology of the world, the stunning graphics, and thrilling combat you are in for a real treat. If you have read this far in to the review you should just do yourself a favor and purchase the game now. You won't regret it.

MHW is a beautiful looking game. This game is controller support only. The keyboard support is weak, not intuitive and poorly optimized for mouse control. "dash" is bound to L3 and R3 and there may be an option buried in keybindings but at a glance, nope. the "run and dive" move is not explained in keybindings or controls. This game is good for someone who knows what they're getting into but not for a casual to just pick up and go. Requires tutorials from YT to find the ins and outs before you start.

Incredibly addicting and fun gameplay loop. Endgame can be a bit grindy when you try to farm specific decorations to fit your multiple gearsets, but it's all purely optional and mainly for people who want to optimize their sets. None of the grinding detracts from the fun gameplay however. The game is equally enjoyable for both solo players, and with friends or with other random hunters.

Have over 700+ hours on Playstation since the launch of the game, so ignore the hours spent on steam. If you're new to MH in general and love getting loot, upgrading, and hunting monsters, this game will be great for you. Awesome monster designs, Weapon designs (most, not all of them), and armor designs (honestly whoever designed most of the armor deserves a raise). Honestly this game was worth every dollar especially the DLC "Iceborne", this DLC really pushed the the base game a lot in terms of features, monsters, armor, etc. They also have "mini raids/sieges" of certain monsters which is really cool. You can also collect pets (also rare pets) out in the wild that you can display at your house. This game has a lot of value, and it's a bang for your buck.

One of the best games of all time. The pinnacle of gameplay as a priority, with an addictive loop of grinding and improving your gear to face greater challenges at its core. The immersion and detail in this game's creatures and environments is unmatched. Can't wait for Wilds.

Monster Hunter has become my favorite game. As someone who never did good in science and was indifference toward nature, the game's immersion in it's fantastical ecology made me grow an appreciation for real-world ecosystems.

While it is grindy, the level of detail sets this game apart and keeps the game play loop fun. In every hunt, you notice new details of the monsters' behavior and physiology. Like you may notice the monster's carapace protects its head and leaves the chest vulnerable to crits, or how it interacts with its surroundings‚Äî sharpening its claws on a wall or stealing eggs from smaller monsters in the habitat.

Another layer of fascination for me is the gear design. It's so interesting to see monster parts that you gathered intricately added back into your equipment. That tail that kept KOing you is now your weapon. The monster's fur used to withstand freezing temperatures is now a 50 inch lace wig. 10/10

My first time ever playing a Monster Hunter game, and I couldn't be more happy this was the entry I started with. To be blunt, the story and handler are pretty bad. The beginning is also a bit overwhelming... It can be difficult to know where to go, what to do, etc. But if you can get past that overwhelming phase, there's really something special. 

It's difficult to summarize everything that makes this game so great. The combat is obviously excellent, and the hunts all very enjoyable. Some of the monsters definitely kicked my face in, but with enough patience and the right preparation, you can overcome them... eventually! But what puts MHW above other games, in my opinion, is how alive and detailed the world is. They're all very beautiful. Really feels like you could get lost in the different areas for ages, just exploring and discovering everything they have to offer. I know I did, haha.

Even after playing so much, I still can't wait to go back and see what else the game has to offer. My review only scratches the surface of it, but I really recommend giving this a shot -- especially with Monster Hunter Wilds coming out in the near future. I'd never played Monster Hunter in my life. The first thing I'd seen about this series was in a video mentioning it in passing and showing a picture of Xeno'Jiiva or Velkhana.
Starting in October of 2023, I started playing this game, and am I ever glad that I did. This community is so strong and now that I'm apart of it. I don't ever want to leave.
I've already accumulated over 400 hours in this game. And I don't regret a moment of it, it made getting through college so much easier. Getting out of my tiring and boring ass classes I'd get home and hop on World w/ my buddy and whoop some monster ass. 
To anyone who is considering buying this game, do it. This is one hell of an experience, and if you play the whole thing, DLC and all, I bet you'll come back for another hunt someday, and when the servers shut down, let me tell you, it was an honour to hunt with you all. (Even you, "Guy who brought blast weapons to Alatreon!".)
To the rest of you, may the Sapphire Star guide you, and may you hunt on!

I've given myself a few chances to get into this, because it has a lot of ideas in it that I really like. It's pretty much based on big boss-fights. You get your choice of up to 14 weapons. You get to make a little cat friend. You can customize all sorts of stuff, like your room and other pets.

But I have to say it: I don't like the combat in this game, and it doesn't matter what weapon I'm using. I get the idea behind making the player commit to their actions so that there's more risk, but your attacks have basically no effect on top of that. I'll have a monster down to its most pathetic state, where it's wounded and just runs away from you between random desperate attacks to push you away, and I'll still have to use five-ish combos or big attacks before it finally goes down. The total lack of any effect behind your attacks makes it unsatisfying. Your attacks are weighty in every way except what they actually do, so Monster Hunter World just feels slow.

I also don't see the point behind preventing the player from having any tracking at all once an attack or combo starts.

[i] [h1] I HATED IT BUT. . . [/h1] [/i]

I think i can finally put to words what i feel about Monster Hunter World. After a long confusion, frustrations, and triumphs, i must say this game is one of the games of all time. And by that i mean, i have found this game to be something but can't figure it out on whether to like this game or not.

Allow me to explain.

I have some share of experience in regards on playing acion games, whether it's ARPG or just plain action games. I found the pattern of those games are like this; Action games are divided to 2 types of games, singleplayer and multiplayer. Singleplayer games usually have a linear progression, the more time you spend, the more games you played, the more stuff you'll get and thus the more "powerful" you'll become. I put quotation marks with "powerful" because it's in the sense you're getting better items to easy up your fights or encounters. It's not that you're really becoming powerful, it's your character becoming powerful. Multiplayer games usually are not bound with that trend of progression. You could play a game for 1000 hours and yet you are still stuck in 2nd Dan (Tekken reference). The progression of a player becoming powerful isn't inherently coming from how much things you get or even you don't get anything at all besides some "progression" points. You're becoming more "powerful" because you're getting better at the game by learning a bunch of stuff related to the game or a certain point in the game or you're just better in doing some executions related things in the gameplay. Knowledge, motoric skills, and intuition. Those are three things that i think are important in a multiplayer game type to become "powerful". Instead of just your character, you (the player) also becoming more powerful as well in a way. 

Now granted, there are outliers from these categorizations and also there are other factors that determined a game is singleplayer or multiplayer but i wanna focus on the "powerful" part on this instance because i think this is pivotal on my feelings for the game.

As far as my expectation of the game, i thought this game would fall into the singleplayer category. You become more powerful by the gears that you will acquire per progression in the game. For the first 50 hours of the game, i felt that way. I acquired gears that deals more and tanks more damage. With that, i expected the later i'll get in game, the more "powerful" i'll become and these monsters will become just mere mob monsters. Ez 5 min runs on these monsters, i thought naively. Until i unlocked the High Rank missions and oh boy. Let me tell you, it felt like i was slapped by Baki Hanma himself. 

I was...kinda hating the game. Because the difficulty curve had gone so steep, it was painful. I called attacks cheap, i called the movement's fucking utterly shit, i called the fact there's barely any i-frames in animations is fucking garbage, safe to say it wasn't a good time. Granted, i just wanted to open up the game at the moment. I finally got it when people say the endgame is when the real game begins so i just wanna get through the story and learning about the actual game later on. 

This is where i'll say about the game, that this game is HARD AS GODDAMN IT HAS ANY RIGHT TO BE. Some of the monsters just can't be done with in solo and even if you do, it either requires patience, commitment, time, or some videogame knowledge like AI exploits and whatnot. I did not expect this AT ALL. I thought because it relies on gears, i just wanted to get through with it so i can finally get the "powerful" gears and learn more in-depth about the monsters later (in solo ofc, just to be clear here). 

After approximately 300 hours and still counting in game, i can safely say this is not the actual case at all with the game. Gears can only bring you so far in the actual game itself but the most important thing is how well you know about the game and the monsters. The little tidbits about the monsters, the environment, the pickables, and the timing of when to do what. Those are the things that you'll actually need to have to get better in the game. Even with the worst gear possible, with those things in your pocket already enough to beat a monster. Also you'll need a good hardware such as decent GPU, decent CPU, decent monitor, a comfy pad or KBM with the mouse particularly have at least 5 buttons on it. 

And this is where i realised that i might have perceived this game wrong this whole time. The multiplayer isn't a part of the endgame. It's not just there as a good novelty for the players to enjoy with their friends or some randos to prolong the longevity of the game. The game IS mainly a multiplayer game. The story is just a guide or an introduction to you to get to know the monsters better before jumping online and they have to force you to do so because again, it's mainly a multiplayer game. No compensations for you in the story because the game doesn't wanna be an irresponsible parent for letting you play with other higher rank players without knowing what the game is first and being a dead weight as a result. 

You're not getting good by just getting good gears, you're getting good by learning the game thoroghly. Every encounter is a battle to the death, even with a Jagras later on. Every monster's attack is a cry for help, your every attacks always have death peeking on you, every monster's flinch is a breather moment. Every single thing you do is a matter of life and death. It will all come down to your knowledge and intuition and hell there's nothing more primal than that.

And i think now i understand why people hail this game so much. There's so little game that offer this kind of experience and even if they remotely do, it's been muddied with some toxicity of some dick measuring contest or hell even some toxicity in multiplayer in general. Monster Hunter World isn't innocent on that front either, which is why it's kinda sad and upsetting whenever someone got carted there'll be one "git gud nub lol" auto chat. They missed the point of the game. The game is all about camaraderie, about bonding with other people within the game. There's little benefit to be had for being a god solo runner in the game and so what if you are master in this game? Girls will wet knowing you beat Fatalis solo with 4 player health on? Or you'll get a head or something? Hell no. Ranks aren't important even, so why bother with the shittalk. People will just see you got small dick and needing praise for being good at a videogame, A PVE VIDEOGAME THAT IS WHICH EVEN MORE OF A LAUGHING STO-*ehem*

I personally can't say that i love the game as a whole but i also can't say i dislike the game at all. If i was in a healthier mindset, i would enjoy the hell out of this game with its all punishing difficulty glory. It's just unfortunate that because i'm not, i can't enjoy it to the fullest. 

However, if you're looking for a good long 40 minute time killer, or a game that you can bond with someone, or a game that awakens your primal instinct for some life or death encounters, this game is totally for you.

Monster Hunter Rise was my fist MH game, I spent about 100 hour in that game and loved every minute of it, but I do prefer MHW a lot more. There is a couple reasons for that.

1st: The fauna is way more diverse and really feels lived in and a real echo system. Rise maps feels like a bunch of open area connected by little corridor.

2nd: World maps feels so much bigger, because you are allowed to fast travel with you dog in Rise the map feels smaller.

3rd: The wire bug in Rise breaks the game a little, you can bug out in case of danger.

It might sound like I'm shitting on Rise, but I'm not, I'm just pointing out what I prefer in World and why. I loved my time with Rise and don't regret it, but World is now my new addiction.

Like no other Monster Hunter game before, World immerses you in an eco system that feels alive & real while still nailing the combat against giant creatures as you bonk or slash your way atop the food chain.
However, this game never takes itself too seriously or tries to be edgy - you will watch cats make amazing looking meals, dress up your cat comrade in silly little outfits, do funny dances and collect cute pets for your room and that's what makes Monster Hunter so special - it's atmosphere is inviting and friendly and if you are able to share these moments with friends and make memories together, it's the best co-operative experience out there.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 21 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, created my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Monster Hunter as a whole is an extremely fun series. World was my first introduction to the series back in 2019 on my PS, and ended up buying it on steam a bit later which is how I'm writing this review. It's an extremely gorgeous, fun, challenging, and immersive game that lets you do just as the title says; hunt monsters. Everything about this game is fantastic, and even when it gets hard, I'm always coming back. I usually despise multiplayer games, but this series is one that has made me love and appreciate them dearly.

Update: 2/4/2024
A few months ago, I managed to completely erase my save files while transferring them to another computer. I was distraught for a few days, but jumped back in once I felt good enough to try again. I have never felt so happy and reinterested in a game but even replaying MHW AGAIN felt like I was experiencing it all over again. My friends helped me out and it just just such an amazing experience to play it all over again with them. I love this game, and I will always and forever #ReturntoWorld.

At first I didn't "get" the Monster Hunter series, it was beyond my comprehension. I'm very glad I gave it a second glance and am kicking myself for not sticking with it sooner. I've since put in over 550 hours into World and have taken a 4th new character to endgame.

Fantastic gameplay, excellent music, and a "cavepunk" or "primalpunk" aesthetic that has grown on me. It's not the typical fantasy with elves and magic like I assumed it was. There rally is no magic. There is technology that just works, like the Dragonator - a steam-powered pneumatic ship-mounted battering ram\harpoon\drill designed to pierce the hide of an Elder Dragon ("Elder Dragon" being less of a reference to mythical creatures and more a phylogenetic classification - like "Leviathan" from Subnautica.)

The game has a detailed ecology simulation that would make Sir David Attenburough proud. Some of the most superlative enemy AI that I've encountered in a videogame. Each monster has their own personality, you can almost see it in their eyes when they look your way, and you realize that this is the moment that they've decided to ruin your day. It's great.

Capcom's "Return to World" campaign along with the announcement of Monster Hunter: Wilds has lead to a resurgence in player numbers. Playing solo or co-op with the new, returning, and veteran players has been a blast. I only wish my friends gave MH: World more than just a passing glance.

My Steam playtime is not true to my actual playtime of MHW. On PS4/PS5 I have 2,264 hours of this spectacular game! Honestly, the best entry in the series so far. So many quality of life changes, it easily makes for the best game for anyone new to try out, or even a veteran player.

2024 - To this day, the Monster Hunter franchise is still the best co-op game, and experience available. World and Icebone are the best versions of the franchise, hands down. Being released for Playstation and then PC allowed Capcom to develop the best version of the game in terms of graphics, animations, and QoL. While Rise was a solid Monster Hunter, going from World to Rise was a huge visual difference, and I hope they see the success of World and continue to release games for high performance consoles and not Nintendumb.

If you like the combat, the game is amazing and it has a lot of replayability, but if you don't enjoy killing the same monsters over and over again, you will probably not enjoy it for a long time. Also some of the gear/gems are unnecessarily rare and you can't trade them between players, so it's a real possibility that you could go hundreds of hours without ever finding the gem you want for a specific build. I'm going to choose "Recommended" because Steam only gives me 2 options, but in reality my stance on this game is more towards "Neutral". I can't say I would recommend it, but I can't say I wouldn't recommend it either. It's a specific game with a specific niche. In my opinion, you will either love it, or hate it.

For one I am a bit frustrated with your final fantasy hunt the behemoth which all it does is spam wind tunnels, meteors and has an unblockable death attack. Whoever came up with that should be fired and Im serious, I can respect monsters that have superior maneuverability but theres nothing smart about what this level puts people through and should be removed or atleast fixed. On Playstation people helped out one another but apparently on PC nobody helps and if they do they faint more than they should like they never played this game before, I assume they lack skill from playing with to many mods in their games which id rather not call for sos in serious hunts.

I also feel alone when I play the story? I do every single thing there is to do but my teammates do F all? nothing...I see a hunter with a big green rathian sword, the Chiefs son, the handler and they do 0. Why not have them come on quests with me or do something so I do feel like the story isnt inclusive to the cut scenes. I see everyone doing the one for all and all for one but when in game its all for one and good luck bymyself!? THEN when I do everything and everyone is celebrating at the end like we been through some flippin unknown adventure that I never saw, idk what they a celebrating when I did everything.

You do have to add story to the gameplay and not just the cutscenes and add something else other than just hunting, you cant just make that the whole game, it needs like another element to the game. Maybe add being on a ship and battling pirates or monsters from the deep, underwater levels would have been nice, maybe even base building and not on a large scale but maybe a small village you can customize. 

Other than that its a 9 out of 10 game for me, buy it and play it. I wouldnt recommend to players who use mods cause you are not good at helping, thank.

Awesome game, got it on discount. You get more than 100 hours of content at full price but since this is already like 4 years old, wait for a discount and grab the complete package with DLC. 

For new players, if you enjoy games where you fight monsters and grow stronger eventually then definitely play this game. They have introduced a defender armor so that returning players can finish main story at GOD level equipment and start playing the DLC. I personally will recommend you to not use this armor/weapons. They are stat inflated for the early level and it will take away the experience of the game, let's be honest that's why we buy these games and not for multiplayer. Multiplayer is a added bonus, not the MSP ( main selling point ). 

Game is welcoming for casual players and rewarding for players aiming to hit the maximum skill cap. No idea why you will skip this one, unless you do not like genre then it is completely fine. 

Finally first 2 hours of the game you won't experience the depth, so if you are planning to buy/try/refund then don't, game is big, this isn't you new gen 10 hours story content game.
Monster Hunter is an amazing series, and even though "World" is not my favourite, like at all, it's still really really great.
