one of the worst game i have ever bought. no hype and "playing" it is like a chore. in no particular order :

- no 16:10 support

- checking the options and getting through the character creation and to/through the tutorial with its super long cutscenes goes way beyond 2 hours. so the refund period will be over before you can even actually try the game. it's a scam so it's better to read online or know the other games before buying/running this one

- npcs can't shut up and talk all day long

- recycling, grindign meager content of a few mobs copy/pasted and recolored

- controls are very unintuitive and erratic, they are just awful overall. the autolock system has to be ignored and unbound, with a mouse it will swap between targets super fast from any movement input and disable itself but stick long enough to make the camera annoyingly spin around, and even if remaining locked, be completely useless as it can't really reliably help the character face the right directions, and yet it can't easily be canceled once activated. useless.

the weapons are frustrating to use. i don't know how "many" people can play this trash. i had played some previous mh game and it was not so bad. the control schemes for any weapon make little sense. and sometimes things work, sometimes they don't, and others simply never do anything, i don't know if it's because they fucked up the keys display from the tutorial which happens a lot with shitty developers (they don't know that non-qwerty keyboards exist either apparently, or are just too shitty to add proper support), or something else. the game will bind the same functions over multiple keys and have somewhat conflicting and confusing keys and functions, and this is generally true for the whole game with menus navigation making absolutely no sense with no ergonomy and requiring loads of different keys and time just to do one thing. have fun being stuck in a "yes/no" window with no escape because your character tried to grab a resource while already having full inventory while a boss just keeps running. also being supposed to use menus in real time for items. place a trap ? use a dozen different keys throught 4-5 different menus and sub-menus in real time, then pray for the trap to not be bugged, because it usually does and can't be placed, just for the boss to not be captured when walking on it and it being thrown 4 tranquilizers at it and then 4 more and then a few more hits just in case even though since the beginning it was limping and with a skull icon and the game said it would guarantee a catch (and with only 1 or 2 tranquilizers) and you have to start all over again with no success on this single stupid early quest in 5 hours (one of the worst i have ever played in a game) and somehow this time the trap can be used from one of the two "quick" scroll/radial menus back again

again, the weapons are not fun to use. it's clunky, the character is slow as fuck and can't be readjusted in a logical manner, the player has to wait long times to do so and even from the point of view of the character it makes no sense. wait a long time before throwing a second attack in a different direction to change the direction and push the attack button or the character will stick with the previous direction. no, holding the new direction and waiting to push the attack buttons won't work. to use items like grinding stone to re-apply boost to the weapon, the character sheathes its weapon away... then fucking draws it back and then uses the stone, and all that takes animation time over several different sequences. SMART. the hitboxes are all over the place as well. you can dodge an attack 3 seconds before a boss does it or reaches you and it still hits. you can be BEHIND OR TO THE SIDE of a boss when it charges forward with a wide gap between it and the player character, and it hits. they can also run through the ground and the walls and hit from the ground while the player character is out of range around cliffs above it or hit through layers of the map through non-destructible walls. and this is in SINGLEPLAYER. i don't know if it still connects online but either way it's just plain dumb. and the player weapons can't hit anything. too low of a reach, and ridiculously slow speeds that don't match how the mobs are designed. or they can simply combo and stunlock your character until it dies and you have no input in the game, or one shot it with instant-cast attacks that are completely unavoidable. the game just decides that the player has to lose and nothing can be done about it. then even if you manage to hit, if you don't hit on their weak spots (you can't always/can't hit them on their weak spot depending of weapon and mob), it's mostly weak all bland "resist" damages to make sure you can't have fun with this $600 dlc fest of a fake game

it's like black desert's combat except they managed to make it convoluted, unintuitive, clunky, frustrating to use and buggy, all while having a much slower pacing and with a lot less abilities.

- the game is completely unbalanced. armors and weapon upgrades are useless, and they can't even be done anyway. no matter how many bosses i kill, in 15 active hours played i got enough to craft a weapon and give it slight upgrades twice. the game throws more craft choices but they all suck and are worse than the 1-2 first new crafts we discover from the first bosses. reading up online it appears to be "normal" (lol) and that players should ignore all the armors and weapons except the endgame ones. picking armor parts for their passive upgrades almost always means having a very dumb looking mis-matched armor. nice game design

- no respect for player's time. outside of glitches, the game unfairly punishes the player for no valid reason. you want to go roam mode instead of being tied to quests ? the bosses simply run away after you spent 15-20 minutes hitting them and you get NOTHING. you want bosses at all ? lol nope, try and run around the map for several minutes at a time just to see if any of them at once is spawning so you can play the fucking game. killed a boss after a 30 minutes fight ? GG preybirds come and steal the loot away from you. TRY AGAIN. you don't pick your hard-earned loot within 60 seconds ? THE GAME DESPAWNS IT. TRY AGAIN. you spent AN HOUR chasing a boss that always flies away and you have to hold foward + shift for 2 minutes straight every time and you run out of time because it's a health sponge and the game only lets you have weak garbage weapon that does no damages but still manage to almost kill the boss and the game just times out like that ? YOU GET NOTHING. TRY AGAIN.

- peer to peer online game with steam drm but requires online drm checks from capcom to be used and periodic checks to be used offline

- all content is downloaded (and payed for). have to pay more to access all of it. it's exactly the same as on-disk dlc (with the bonus of taking 50GB of space more for stuff you are prevented from using) but people are too stupid to complain about it and will even defend it

- around $600 "worth" of paywall dlc. it's 0 and should be priced as such. they also try to force you to throw money at them to change your character's name and looks with "tickets" that are one-time use. "anti-piracy" is great

- predatory "expansion" (which is the same as a dlc despite what shills and stupid people would claim) that not only adds a paywall that splits the playerbase, but negatively affects the base game by changing it by buffing the monsters and creating huge player gear powercreep so that players who don't buy the expansion were rendered weaker. buying iceborne also gives access to an overpowered starting armor set that trivializes the content of the original game and is selectable right from the start (character creation even), without informing the player about its real impact on the game

- like nintendo, capcom abuses copyright "laws" to delete mod-related content (videos etc.)

Love everything about this game. I used to play a lot of World of Warcraft and FFXIV, as well as every souls game and Elden Ring. This game manages to combine the MMO feel of these games with the difficulty of a souls game at times. Unlike the souls games, you get a slap on the wrist for failure, and can just try again quickly. This makes every monster a practice in trial and error, to the point where it feels like you're dancing with them.

Every mission is unique in a way that makes the grind feel refreshing. Maybe this time you'll see a turf war between a monke and a t-rex. Maybe this time you'll get that firecell stone or novacrystal you've been missing. Maybe this time you'll fight a monster in a completely different biome than usual. Maybe this time you'll get that DAMN chaos emerald you've been grinding for the last few hours. Maybe this time you'll sever the tail. The gameplay loop is beautiful, and always keeps you coming back for more. There's always more materials you need, and there's always new experiences to be had.

The base story actually made me tear up near the end. Everything in the world feels hopeful, and captures the feeling of noblebright while not feeling cheesy. You're not on a quest to kill the big bad guy, just to act as a deterrent against monsters who, if left unchecked, would cause havoc and death. This isn't a story about good triumphing over evil, it's about  humanity protecting the world from invasive species and monsters that need to be checked. The stakes are high, but it never feels hopeless.

The music, good god the music. The rotten vale battle theme will probably get me through a physical fitness test I'll need to take soon. From teostra and the elder's recess to the big monke and raging brachydios, monsters each have thematically appropriate and menacing music to make everything feel like a boss fight.

The graphics are pretty good, especially for 2018. My only complaint there is that certain monsters' abilities can blend in with the environment and make dodging and evading more difficult. Looking at you, iceborne. Combat has an incredible level of variety, with 12 weapons to choose from that each have completely different playstyles. Each one has a niche in both solo and multiplayer hunts, from supporting your comrades with the bowguns or being an agile fighter with dual blades or the insect glave, to being a one man wrecking machine with a hammer or greatsword. The depth increases replayability even more.

My biggest complaint is the subspecies, with a few exceptions. It's just the same monster with entirely different materials to pad out the grind while not feeling like you're just fighting the same monster again. It could be worse, but I don't like all the variations of rathalos or rathian, nor the jyuratodus variants. The exceptions are, unfortunately, near the end of the DLC.

9/10, made me love gaming again. I'm a police officer in training so I don't have a ton of time to play outside of the weekend, but I can just pound out a few hours responding to SOS flares or grinding for another piece of gear. Get the DLC too, it changes the game and adds probably another 400 hours of playtime to it. Also try and find a workaround for the garbage DRM they're trying to force.

I played the game a little here and there and loved it, but never had the hardware to get it myself. Now I got it and I really expected to love it so much that I could easily get 100s of hours worth of adventure.

...I'm barely more than 10 hours in the game and I'm really bored.

First of all the game is not a roleplaying game, it's a hack 'n' slash with some rpg elements. Most stat increases come from gear, but it doesn't get too crazy. You won't be able to one hit the first boss enemy type no matter how good your stuff is.

The combat is really polished and it looks amazing + there's some cool combos and mechanics, but it's always the same loop. You find the monster, you hit it till it runs away, you follow after it, you hit the monster till it runs away and so on until it's finally dead. The combat feels more tedious than fun.

It's not really an open world to explore, it's rather a series of tunnels that lead to the same points. It's filled with a wild variety of enemies and plants, but it somehow still feels empty. There's not really anything to explore.

I just have a hard time finding something to keep me coming back here. It doesn't really do exploration, I can't level up my character, the gear won't get much stronger, the story is painfully boring and the combat tedious.

[The game runs somewhat good on Steam Deck, but it will drain your batterie in 1,5 hours. You really have to lower the settings to have an efficiant, rather than good experience. I don't think it deserves the verified status though.]

10/10 Experience playing this game. I have played on console since day one, and loved every second of it. Even after 1400+ hours and 6 years post-release, the gameplay and graphics hold up extremely well.

However, people who aren't familiar with this franchise may find the combat slow. Also, the endgame can be a VERY long grindfest for people seeking out that type of content. Even so, if you take your time exploring the systems, environments and what they have to offer, the game is very rewarding and you will have a lot of fun.

A very good game. The combat is solid, monsters are excellent, hunting is fun and all optional side activities are non-intrusive enough to let the core gameplay shine. I can easily see how Monster Hunter (W) can be the favorite game/genre of many people, and I would certainly reccomend it to anyone to try at least once! 

Personally however, I don't think I will be playing much longer. Though (most of) the monsters so far are fun to fight, they don't require unique strategies, the fights usually play out the exact same way every time. Sure, every monster has some kind of weak point or weakness, however exploiting that (usually elemental) weakness requires grinding many different weapons, which I simply don't find fun. The monsters themselves also get old relatively quickly, and with how long many fights last and how few random rewards they give, fighting them also feels grindy after two or three kills. I know that this is the basic premise of the game (hunt, grind and master bosses), and I guess it's not for me.
If you dreamed to be a hunter in a parallel world, if you like dragonkin beasts, this is your game!

As a new hunter to Monster Hunter Series, I would say that this is one of the best game I've ever played. Previously, I didn't feel interested in this game at all as I was used to MMORPG gameplay style with character progress via levelling up and farming for the best equipment, to be honest, I looked down on this series that how come game would be fun if there was no levelling up system. However, I suddenly changed my mind after playing this game since the first step, and there is no doubt why most players love this game so much. 

Pros
- If you are the one who loves detailed game design, this game is your answer.
- Not too much grinding.
- Pleasant graphic design.
- Cross game events.
- Double fun if play with your friends.
- Good overall gameplay performance.

Cons
- It could be a bit exhausting if you need to hunt the same monster over and over for a material.
- Online session disconnect. (Rarely)
- Chasing down the monster is too far sometimes.
- Camera movement is sometimes annoying.

The story is pretty bad, but it doesn't matter. The monsters, music, atmosphere, and constantly engaging gameplay make up for it many times over. Even when monsters are kicking your ass and you're raging, you're having fun, and you come back at them with new gear and knowledge. The game is infinitely replayable, and fun both solo and with friends. And with years of content and the massive iceborne expansion, there is always something to be working toward and it's always exciting. 
I can't believe I didn't get this game sooner.
An addiction but a welcome one
Good game!

I originally played World on PS4 when it came out. Hundreds of hours in the base game, hundreds more in Iceborne. My friends and I did everything. EVERYTHING. We killed every monster from Jagras to Fatalis, farmed both Sieges, did every event. And now I'm doing it all again on PC with another group of friends. It's a bit easier now, yeah, since I could use the catch up gear to get to MR fast, and now I have a better idea of what to focus on for builds. But it's still a ton of grinding, and grinding that I am doing for a second time. And yet, I still love it all the same. I think that's the best indication of the quality of this game. That I'm willing to do the long haul grind, and do it all over again.

Fluffy Blueberry Pancakes with Maple Drizzle

Ingredients:

1 cup plain flour
2 tablespoons caster sugar
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon bicarbonate of soda
1/4 teaspoon salt
3/4 cup buttermilk
1/4 cup milk
1 large egg
2 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 cup fresh blueberries (or frozen, thawed)
Butter or oil for cooking
For the Maple Drizzle:

1/2 cup pure maple syrup
2 tablespoons unsalted butter
Instructions:

Mix the Dry Ingredients:
In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, bicarbonate of soda, and salt.

Prepare the Wet Ingredients:
In a separate bowl, whisk together the buttermilk, milk, egg, melted butter, and vanilla extract.

Combine Wet and Dry Ingredients:
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and gently fold them together until just combined. Be careful not to overmix; a few lumps are okay.

Fold in Blueberries:
Gently fold in the blueberries, distributing them evenly throughout the batter.

Heat the Griddle or Pan:
Preheat a griddle or non-stick pan over medium heat. Add a small amount of butter or oil to coat the surface.

Cook the Pancakes:
Pour 1/4 cup portions of batter onto the griddle for each pancake. Cook until bubbles form on the surface, then flip and cook until the other side is golden brown.

Make the Maple Drizzle:
In a small saucepan, melt the butter for the maple drizzle over low heat. Add the maple syrup and stir until well combined. Remove from heat.

Serve and Drizzle:
Stack the pancakes on a plate, and drizzle the warm maple sauce over the top.

Optional Toppings:
Customize your pancakes with additional toppings like whipped cream, more fresh blueberries, or a sprinkle of icing sugar.

Enjoy:
Dive into a stack of these fluffy blueberry pancakes and savour the perfect blend of sweet, tangy blueberries and rich maple goodness. Breakfast bliss is served!

Want a game with cats? A friend of mine introduce me to this game. and initially, progress was sluggish as I stumbled through, unsure of what I was doing. However, with time and the guidance of fellow players in the Monster Hunter: World community ‚Äì a heartfelt thanks to all the veterans with 999Hr/Mr hours that I had fun encountering and friends that I met that to this day we still hunt and faint occasionally.

I eventually clocked in 333 hours and triumphed over Fatalis, albeit not solo in the 1st try :') (editing this comment at probably 602 hours I did solo fatalis after my 50+ fails using Greatsword).. I remember back in my HR days odogaron was my worst enemy that I really don't wanna fight.. And after those odogaron tail slap PTSD.. And finally [spoiler]Rajang is waving [/spoiler] yep this guy is a pain my first time encountering this formidable foe was quite the ordeal..

To end in the better note, my main weapon now is the Charge Blade, with this by my side, I braved every challenge. Monster Hunter: World, an epic adventure that's as rewarding as it is challenging.

Reasons why Monster Hunter World is better than Monster Hunter Rise.
1. Better Graphics.
Rise was made exclusively for the Nintendo Switch. By default it's graphics are gonna be sub-par.
World, and ESPECIALLY Iceborne, look and sound far better than Rise could.
Especially the particle effects.

2. Immersion.
Rise is too much like your traditional "Anime-with-filler-somehow-worse-than-bleach's-filler".
From the stupid noises when your cooking raw meat, to having an unbearably catchy bunny-dango song whenever you wanna eat at the dango shop.
Can't get immersed in it myself.
World does it for me tho. More properly-done realism, less in-your-face fantasy.

3. Harder monsters + Wirebug cheesing.
Anjanath is a nightmare in World. In Rise he's a little baby. But only cause you can use wirebugs.
Wirebug abilities and Switch Skills are cool. But they give too much of a bonus to the point where the game becomes easier the more decorations you get.
The switch skills and weapon abilities should've been part of World + Iceborne, but been dumbed down HEAVILY to not do so much damage.
I say as even with Wirebugs I couldn't beat a 6 star Zinogre without fainting twice with a Magnamalo Longsword.
Speaking of which.
4. Weapons.
Every weapon feels so much more impactful with each hit - without being absolutely broken.
Insect Glaive was my main in World, but I do variety now.
In RISE it's one of the most broken weapons in the whole game thanks to wirebugs, switch skills and double air-dashing.
The Hammer's Flip-Jumps are less rare and more common thanks to wirebugs, which I was bothered by at first but came to love after replaying world.
The Long Sword's Sephiroth Omni Slash wirebug skill was satisfying, I'll admit. But wirebug countering? Now you're just pushing it.
The Dual Blades are what got me through most of the beginning game cuz of wirebugs.
And the Sword and Shield are what got me through first-time Magnamalo.
Monster Hunter is supposed to be hard enough to make you scream "YEASS! SCREW YOU ZINOGRE!!" At the top of your lungs and do a bully maguire arm-rolling dance like I did in 6 star. 
With Wirebugs I was just "Yes! Screw you..!"

Only Wind Serpent Ibushi got me to do that ... without the happy dancing.

But come Zinogre in World - Master Rank and I'll be doing that.

See you on the hunt. May the Sapphire Star light your way.

-GeassGamer

Very rewarding game where you fight solo or up to 4 people fighting small to Extremely large Dinosaurs for their materials to craft armor and gear!  Dinosaurs come out of the wood work and fight each other even if your in the middle of the fight!  Later on the ground can collapse to add dramatic effect!  I like collecting all the gear for cosmetics and to geek out and fight monsters with different gear setups.  You can craft gear with raw dmg or switch it up to an elemental (blue lighting coming out of my weapons always puts a smile on my face) or status effecting gear like sleep or my personal favorite BLAST! (watch some of the crafting materials explode off the monster during combat)  Enjoy Monster Hunter!

Update / Note: Since the addition of DRM I have had much longer loading times, sit on a black screen when starting the game, and have had many strange crashes. 
Currently as I am writing this review, my game crashed but the sound is still playing. I can not get it to stop.

-----

I have near 300 hours in Rise.
I've put near 40 hours into World, and I plan on fully beating it.
This is my experience so far with World.

The monster's AI is very good and it has vast complex biomes that feel natural and full of life.
It is very beautiful, but... that's all it has going for it.

It feels dated, it feels clunky.
All of the monsters feel very weak and easy to kill. Even the Elder Dragons feel dated in comparisons to Rise's versions of them, which have better animations and more showy attacks.
You will spend 15 minutes on a map trying to find the monster & kill it in under 5 minutes, unless it runs away, so you can spend another 5 minutes tracking it again.
Making weapons, upgrading weapons, is an absolute nightmare to navigate.
Joining friends early game is a terrible experience, but it gets better once you hit high rank missions.
The Handler is constantly talking, I can not stand her.
You can not skip cutscenes.
The forced Expeditions are very annoying to deal with, but they seem to be early game only.
The camera jerking to look in a direction is awful. This happens when you find prints or walking into the targets zone. It's disorienting. If you are in the middle of fighting something and your target shows up, the camera zooms towards your target. It can get you hit, or even killed.

If you have experience with Monster Hunter games and know the clunky feel of the older games, you will like this game.
I personally prefer the Quality of Life improvements that Rise brought - even if that means sacrificing the beautiful alive environments that World has.

If you're someone who just wants to drop in, kill monsters, drop out - get Rise.
I would highly recommend Rise to someone who is new to the Monster Hunter series. It is incredibly beginner friendly with some very hard late game monsters.

Monster Hunter World is a really good game with some flaws I will list later.

[h3] Pros [/h3]

[list]
    [*][b]The World:[/b] The games maps are very densly designed and thriving with live. Almost everywhere you can find bigger friendly herbivores, small critters and bugs as well as small animals you can use to help you hunt such as poison toads and the likes. This leads to the atmosphere being really great.
    [*][b]The Combat:[/b] The combat feels very satisfying. Every hit feels meaty without the weapon being clunky. There are many combos and monsters to learn. Positioning and knowing the monster is as important as knowing your weapon just like in every monster hunter before. For reverence: I mostly played Gunlance and Hunting Horn in World. Gunlance especially felt really satisfying with just perfect soundeffects and enough hitlag after every hit. Hunting horn also had a really great system for its notes where you can chain multiple notes and play an encore after that strenghtens the before applied buffs.
    [*][b]Immersion:[/b] The game really immerses you in its game world. You really feel like a hunter tracking your prey with your scoutflies
    [*][b]Scoutflies:[/b] These are a method to track the monster that has been the best one yet. You find footprints and other tracks of the monster. These lead you to other tracks until eventually the monster's location gets revealed to you. After you hunted the monster enough times the amount of tracks you have to collect before this happens gets reduced more and more. Scoutflies are not perfect, but definitely a step in the right direction.
    [*][b]Investigations:[/b] Investigations are randomly generated quests you get by breaking monster parts and collecting tracks. They can be multi-monster-hunts and can have different time limits or amount of carts. The more difficult the quest the better the reward. 
This leads to a system that makes farming for monster parts more interesting than just spamming the same quests over and over. 
The only thing I don't like is the random player cap. Sometimes you get quests just 2 player can join. This is bad when you want to play coop with friends and I can't wrap my head around this decision.
    [*][b]Gorgeous armor:[/b] The armor designs in world are really good and are all quite different. Some of the best imo are [spoiler] Pukei Pukei, Kulu Yaku and Anjanath [/spoiler]
    [*][b]Good Monsters:[/b] World has pretty good monsters across the board. A majority of MHW's roster is new and well designed. The game even threw in multiple new elder dragons.
[/list]

[h3] Cons [/h3]

[list]
    [*][b]The infinite restock:[/b] In MHW you can always go to the camp during a hunt and restock all your health potions and other items. After playing some of the older games I am sad to see the ressource managment side of the games go away. You lose out on all the decisions that go into preparing for a hunt with limited inventory space like: 
Are 10 mega potions enough? Should I take stuff with me to craft more during the hunt? Do I want a trap and tranq bombs? Do I need max potions and an ancient potions? Do I also need ressources to craft those if they run out? Do I need cold/hot drinks?
This may sound tedious to some, but it really added something. This could have fitted world really well especially with the faster gathering of herbs and the like, but the presence of these infinite restocks takes this and the "war of attrition against the monster" away. This also leads to the engame having quite a few monsters with "nuke-moves", because chipping damage won't kill you, but those moves were actually more a problem in the DLC Iceborne and especially the DLC of MHW's sequel.
    [*][b]Cutscenes:[/b] The cutscenes are good the first time you see them. They become a problem on second playthroughs as you cannot skip them. The worst thing about them is how they make playing through the game with a friend tedious as you both have to watch them in singleplayer and just then you can join the other persons mission. In the DLC's engame are even some missions where you both go in the same mission and then both watch the same cutscene where both of your hunters are present, so they showed that the games cinematic approach can work! Why not do it like this from the start?! 
    [*][b]Weapon Designs:[/b] To be honest, most of worlds new weapon designs suck. They are just the base weapon with some monster parts slapped on.
    [*][b]Monster Variety:[/b] While I think the majority of MHW's roster is great by themselves, sadly most of them use the same skeletons. You will fight Lizards, T-Rex-ish monsters, flying monster and 4 legged dragons. Older games had simply more variety with spiders, snakes, leviathans and insects. This is not a huge problem for me, but still sad to see.
    [*][b]Gathering Hub:[/b] Now we are in the small nit-picks territory. The gathering hub is not really great. It lacks most of the shops a hunter needs like the gardener, smithy and Argosy. This leads to having to leave the hub frequently or just playing from the main hub without seeing your friends in the base, which is sad to see, especially because the gathering hub itself looks really beautiful.
[/list]

Overall World is really good despite its flaws and definitely worth your time. I really love this game even though I ranted quite a bit about its shortcomings, but this is just because I learned to love the franchise from the point I played World as my first Monster Hunter game in 2021 and want it to improve. 

The Iceborne DLC brings a lot - and I really mean a lot, it doubles the amount of content the game has - of new content to the game and is a must have in my opinion.

Dear Insect Glaive,

Choosing your elegance in the realm of weapons has been a dance of power and finesse. In the symphony of strikes, your continuous DPS prowess is a testament to the beauty of continual damage, a ballet with the titans. The artistry in your moves, like the descending thrust and jumping advancing slash, transforms each encounter into a dance. The way you allow me to follow monsters, dealing substantial damage thus, creates a sensation of dominance, making me feel truly formidable. Insect Glaive, you are not just a weapon. you are a masterpiece, a captivating partner in the dance of hunting.

This recommendation is for solo players* Really wanted to like the game. its very well made as far as graphics and concept and story and all that. But the reason for my down vote is that its scaling and monster fights become absurd. if you plan to play with friends its probably way better. but if you wanna play solo, dont expect to reach the end. 

its alot of fun at first, but as you progress even if you have all the top gear maxed out, you're using all the boost, and items and the correct ailments and elements for the monster it still doesn't matter. it gets to a point where its harder then a dark souls game. at least in those games you have a chance, or there's something to learn. here the monsters dont follow any pattern, and get so strong that you are basically stun locked until you die. no chance to dodge or block. you just get to sit there for a few mins and watch as your guy frustratingly just stumbles around , or gets stunned or gets pushed to the ground repeatedly. it even feels like the i-frames for a dodge become non-existent. and the monsters attack radius will extend well beyond the swing of its tail or bite. Im sure its alot of fun with friends, as you can pull the monster off each other and have time to heal and recover. but as a solo player you are basically locked out of end game content once it hits around 8 star assignments.

I understand that some attacks do that, but sometimes you just get hit by an inch of a foot from a monster and still get stunned -> Dead if it doesnt lose focus on you
Also if you dont have any friends you can totally forget to accomplish anything in late game and trying to hunt the last monsters inevitiably ends with whole party dead after 5 mins. It has good graphics and nice designed levels, but thats about the only thing. Also you will need to buy the expansion for the same price, cause the base game consist of 20% of the gameplay and that expansion will just make everything worse I have just stated. Introducing the Clutch Claw, if you like it or not doesnt really matter, some do some dont, but even if you do, like me, its mechanic is totally unfinished and makes no sense at all. You need to push monsters into a wall and sometimes they just run by, even when facing it turn around and just kill you, that means DEATH btw... Its more frustrating than anything else, even if you get used to the mechanics, which are not at all beginner oriented, you¬¥ll still keep dying to random chances or a different monster just comes up, doesnt get repelled by dung pods and then have fun getting your combos done. If you want a monster hunter experience, just play some of the copies theyre way more thought through and playerbased. If you really want to play Monster Hunter to prepare for Wilds, play Rise, eventhough its a lot easier and less deep you can still spend your good 300 hours for everything, without damaging your furniture or hands.

First off, if you're gonna get this game, get it on sale with the Iceborne DLC. It's cheaper that way and you get the whole package. 

There is a learning curve and plenty of grind, so if you like that sort of thing this game is a good fit. There are tons of monsters to hunt and countless hours to spend in this title. Hundreds of weapons, armor, collectibles, cat armors and cat weapons, house decorations, and more to explore. I'd give it a 9 in terms of content, gameplay, and graphics. The story is lackluster, but that's not the appeal of this series anyways. You're not missing much if you just skip through dialogue. The game is best when grinding and hunting with friends. I'd advise having some buddies to play with or find some in-game or through the community environments.

I've played this game for ~400 hours on playstation 4 before picking it up on PC.
As a non-MH fan, this game is... Unreal. The entire gameplay is literally the best part of most games, epic boss fights. In MH:W most of these, can last anywhere from 20-40 minutes. PER BOSS.
The gameplay loop is --> Kill a monster --> skin it --> get armor that looks like the monster and has some unique properties --> hunt bigger monsters --> repeat.
I cannot give this game enough praise, it's brilliantly simple yet utterly boundless.

(Logged as a shoe-in for both the base Monster Hunter: World game, and the Iceborne expansion.)
Lavish & deathly exciting at practically all times - varied and expressive social MMO tissue connecting its numerous multi-layered terrariums of gorgeous arenas and silly monsties.

I do have some background with the series, with much history on Freedom Unite, and far less with the fantranslation of Portable 3rd + 3Ultimate at various points through highschool, and hit the credits of Rise. Freedom Unite came packed with FMV cutscenes that demonstrate how the monsters lived in their downtime - characterising the monsters to assure the player that they weren't merely thoughtless models with movesets to memorise, but individual links in the food chain with roles that keep the world biodiverse & strong.
It was always my favourite part of the game, and what felt like the series' missing hook to really sell me on the core conceit was in how this aspect is somewhat downplayed or unexplored.

By God's grace this was the kind of ecological focus MH:W absolutely relishes in. An interlinking tapestry of ecosystems ticking away, living & interacting in countless ways to make the New World feel so gd raw. And it's not just pageantry either, it plays into behaviours and environment interactions from traps to turf wars. So so so good to head out for a simple hunt to watch it blossom into a scrappy mess of tooth & claw, so so so good to go on aimless expedition to a zone and notice a new handful of behaviours from their endemic life. I‚Äôd not be able to sleep at night if I didn‚Äôt compliment the chefs on all of this, every monster in every zone is given so much purpose it‚Äôs inspiring.

One thing this series has always been great at is its environment design - the world of Monster Hunter is a land of plenty, and everything is blown out of proportion to match. You're eating sirloin steaks the size of your head, oyster side dishes that can feed an army. The tooth you built your hammer out of can sink a ship. Zones and skyboxes that coil across different unique biomes rich in visual stimuli, adding heaps of context for the world and how things are as they are. Pan the camera up at any point and you can assuredly see a spire of choral, ice or crystal towering over you from what appears to be a mile away. Hoarfrost Reach is gorgeous I need to live there NOW.

Moment to moment combat is of course good as hell. I love that it‚Äôs slow and weighty enough to separate it from a more typical Capcom character action affair. Even with the amassing layers of QoL the series has glazed itself with, World still focuses on hefty player move commitment and punishment. Every weapon here feels great and each individually recontextualises your approach to any fight, but I found a home with the Dual Blades I‚Äôm afraid. I love these stupid ale blades man!!! Basically adored the progression right up until the Furious Rajang, where the game takes a very steep swerve into grind and Raid-like Design territory I find catatonic & diagnostic. The Fatalis fight is so much fun I wish I could solo it üò¢

Quite the impressive game for even today's standards. Supreme, timing-based combat once you get over the small learning curve (escpecially as a new player), its not too bad though. Great modeling and designing with the wide variety of weapons, armor, and monsters. Epic fights in beautiful environments. Armor and stat systems aren't overly complicated and can be easily learned as well (much appreciated for this type of game in my opinion). Overall a clean game that I would recommend to any new players looking to get into modern Monster Hunter games. The only negative comments I have is that the Clutch Claw is an Iceborne Exculsive (though I can see why), the Handler's personality is a bit annoying, should have made the Serious Handler the handler instead.

Every time I make a review I give a TL:DR so here it is.

You are fighting Monsters. Then you use the materials to craft stronger monsters. So far so good. This game is kind of an action RPG but you don't gain level. Your character does not increase in strenght or HP or otherwise. Your progression is A: your weapon & armor but also B: your skill. 
One thing new players often misunderstand is how armor works in this game. 
You have skills on your armor. Like for example higher damage. 
You can upgrade the armor and slot gems in that also provide skill improvement. 
But upgrading the armor does not give more skills, it only increases armor value. 
More on that at *(1)
If you played Dark Sould you know what I mean. 
If you liked Dark Souls you might like this game. If DS was too hard for you, you still might like this game. It is much more forgiving. If you hate challenge in games at all, don't want to improve and just get a happy joyride easymode then this game is absolutely not for you. 

You can play and enjoy this game perfectly fine in single player. However it is a Multiplayer game. There is an issue here though more on that at*(2)

Unfortunately this game uses Denuvo.

World is one of, of not my favorite game of all times. The expansion is even better IMO except for the clutch claw. More about the clutch claw in my Iceborn review.

The Long review.

World is the 5th game in the series. 
The previous entries where slower and more methotical. However in this game they went for a more actiony approach. 
Therefore monster move much faster. But you do too. 

The game is also more story driven and more catered the a western audience than previous games in the series. 

(1) In this game you need to figure out what kind of skill you want to use that works well with your playstyle. 
For example, if you use weapons that can block attacks, you might want to use skill that decrease damage when blocking. 
If you want to play glass cannon you want to use skills that improve your damage.
There are many different sets of skills.
You can play as a healer by using the skills wide range for example, what it does is that if you heal yourself by drinking a potion, all other hunters in your team get healed as well.

(2) If you want to play with a friend through the story missions, you can do that. 
But when you meet a new monster during the story missions you get a cutscene. 
The problem is that someone at Capcom thought it is a good idea to not let anyone join in on the hunt before the cutscene has played.
So if you and your friend both start together, you must each seperately start a solo hunt, then both of you have to find the place where the cutscene triggers, then one of you has to abandon his hunt in order to join the other players hunt. 
This is annoying af. I played like this with a new player, I had to wait in the Guild hub until he watched his cutscene every time. 

Let's talk about bugs. 
And here we have an elephant in the room so to speak. 
The game is mostly pretty bug free. Yes some do occur, here and there.
However. There is one bug that is a serious problem and has never been fixed as far as I know.
And that is the "you get kicked from your party when you faint/cart" bug. (Carting is Monster Hunter lingo for fainting)
Sometimes when you or a teammate carts (in online multiplayer), the game freezes for a short 1-2 seconds or so and you or that teammate will be removed from the team.
This is not a teammate kicking you for fainting. I think this is a problem with some denuvo anti cheat but not sure about that.
When that happens to you it puts you into offline mode for whatever reason.
You are still in the hunt, just now alone. You can rejoin online play after finishing the hunte or abandoning it. 
However. If you were in a 4 player hunt, or the hunt was only for 2 player to begin with, you will not be able to join back on that hunt. 

Lets talk about performance on PC.
You should have a decent pc. 
If you have to tune down the graphics with the very limited options for graphics available, monsters look like shit. 
The character models look fine, the enviroment looks fine. But Monster textures look terrible. 
Aside from that, I with my 7 year old budget PC was able to play in 60fps most of the time.

Jaw-dropping visuals and deep combat draw you into a seamless, vibrant world teeming with monstrous foes. Master 14 unique weapons in strategic, exhilarating battles, best enjoyed with friends.

Newcomers beware: Monster Hunter World demands dedication. Complex systems and a steep learning curve await, alongside potential grind fatigue. Some PC port issues persist, but Capcom actively improves.

Overall, a 9/10 gem for those who embrace the challenge. Just sharpen your skills and prepare for an epic hunt!

I am not a person who post negative reviews for fun, but this game just make me do it. It's my personal opinion and don't want to change others opinions - just to vent my frustration with this ''work of art''. 
I never played more clunky and awfuly designed game before( maybe the first Witcher is close), the controls and animations are clumsy as heck. The battle mechanics are so emty,  its seems that your actions and attacks are totaly separated from the monsters you are hiting, no weight in the battle at all. Transactions between the scripted cinematics and when you gain control over your character are so unnatural, even the forced restrictions  of your contols in some scripted transactions are worst than to not have any control over your character. It's feels so forced and unnatural. The UI is nice, but not frendly for new players at all and that may be only my problem, but the stutering in the menues for me was beyond anyoing.  One other thing that i didn't like was the character of your "handler" (this term is all another issue), i get that Capcom wanat to make it mor anime feel. but she is just ayoing and stupid. And before someone jump and say i don't like female characters, just look how is done right in FF games or DMC or plenty of other games. Back to the battle mechanics - can't say enoght how dull they fill, ffs the mostly free to play GW2 have better mechanics than this  highly prased game.
Conclusion - it's not for me. End of the rant. 
issued refund after only 2 hr of play.

1. Steam only lets you return a game if you haven't played past the 2 hour mark. You'll spend half of that getting out of the tutorial.
2. Fat. Your characters are so heavy set it is distracting. I guess it fits the theme of "I jump on big monsters with big things and go smash," but there's no athletic characters?
3. Did I mention it won't shut up? It won't shut up. You want to play a game, but you're stuck with story. Then more story. Did you move an inch? Story.

I bought Dragon's Dogma years ago. Then ever played it. Exactly the same reasons. It just wouldn't shut up. It wouldn't get out of your face. And it wouldn't just let you play it. The only saving grace for that game is Bitterblack Isle. You can go there at level 1. THERE at least it will shut up, let you play, and leave you the heck alone. ALSO, you can be you. This game is super pretty, the animations are good, the art direction is excellent, but it won't leave you the heck alone. It won't get the story out of your face. And it won't shut up. Also, you can't be yourself in another world. You've got to be brunhilda the masher. 

Capcom really needs to get a grip on the openings. If you want to open a game this way do something like "tutorial world" and make it really clear "this direction to the tutorial". Otherwise "this direction" (in the environment) to get to the game. To get to my character. I know this is a game about monsters, but really I want to try some armor on first. To see what weapons are out there. To just... you know... GAME and BE in this other world. 

Argh.. First impressions of this game are "no". I'm sure there's something about 8 or 10 hours past the "please let me return this game for a refund" point, but this... is the "Chimera Experience" of Dragon's Dogma without as much character design choice.

Monster Hunter World is a game that is focused on big fights with monsters. Every hunt is like a boss battle that lasts a maximum of 50 minutes, but is more likely to last about 20-30 minutes. These fights revolve around learning to read the attack patterns of the monsters and playing around them. There is a large number of different weapon that have different playstyles and you can get skills from your equipment that can further influence your playstyle. Whether you want to deal a lot of damage, want to be a tank, someone who is fast and can easily dodge everything, want to support your team, use status effects to deal with your enemy or take them out from a distance it's all possible. 

Since most of the gameplay is max 50 minutes boss battles it is a great game for people who are looking for a game that they can play for short periods of time. It is also the type of game that you can not play for months and then just continue where you left off.

Monster Hunter World is one of the greatest games to ever exist.  It really is hard to overstate my praises of this game.  There is nothing quite like it.  I will attempt to cover the various aspects of this game that make it the perfect game for me, but to quickly summarize: meticulous worldbuilding, fantasy-zoology, the back-and-forth nature of the fights themselves, weapon specialization and skill expression, and the overall feeling of the ‚Äúhunt‚Äù combine together to create an experience that is truly unmatched by any I‚Äôve ever had in all my years of playing games.

1) Wordbuilding
Monster Hunter as a series has always done worldbuilding in what I consider to be the only correct way to do it in a video game: you must experience the world to understand it.  This is exemplified in looking at monster behaviors and their interactions with the world.  Monsters behave as real animals in this game, oftentimes ignoring you if they do not perceive you as a threat to their territory and engaging in activities that reveal more about the nature of their biology and their fights.  Watching Nergigante preen his spikes by violently rubbing them on the ground or Velkhana strut about knowing she is the ruler of the Hoarfrost Reach does more to relay to the player what they can expect of their fights and personalities than any amount of explaining can do.  The monsters and their respective environments tell you a lot about how they fight and their places in the food chain well before you fight them.

2) Fantasy-Zoology
Branching off of the monster behavior topic, this series hits a particular niche I have yet to find a good alternative to, something I like to call ‚ÄúFantasy-Zoology‚Äù.  While many games in the action-RPG and Medieval (in terms of weaponry) genre lean fully into either realism or fantasy, this game creates a world that is decidedly fantastical but implores you to accept the rules of its world through self-imposed limitations.  There are the occasional god-like monsters to be sure ‚Äì Kirin summoning lightening from the sky or Kushala spitting tornados come to mind ‚Äì but in relation to the heights of fantasy other games might reach even these feel grounded.  The world is one in which the natural history of the planet is that of monsters, and many aspects of these beasts reflect those of animals in our own world.  You don‚Äôt need to wonder how Namielle spits water and electricity at the same time, you see it in the jellyfish-shape of her wings and the bioluminescence in her veins that reflects those of animals in our own world.  The monster live and behave by the very instincts animals in our own world do, carving out their own territories and niches and competing for resources even outside the watchful eye of the player characters.  It is a world that is lived in, and it scratches an itch that a child who grew up obsessed with dinosaurs and natural history spends a life-time trying to rekindle.

3) The Fights
I came primarily into this series from a background in Dark Souls and other FromSoftware games.  After coming off the initial high those games offer, I found it difficult to find a series that pushes the 3rd-person action RPG genre to the same heights.  Boss fights in those games are about observation and execution, not simply attaining the highest stats possible.  Spending time learning the enemy movesets in-and-out, mastering your own moveset, and responding in turn with a bit of personal flavor on the battle gives way to a unique combat experience that is tough but very satisfying to master.  Monster Hunter expands on that in ways even I never anticipated.  Every fight is a dance, one that is meticulously designed so that you must use the knowledge you‚Äôve gained from the previous two points, i.e. observing the monster‚Äôs behavior and place in the natural environment to determine how you must approach each battle.  You are rewarding for identifying Diablos‚Äô weakness to Screamer Pods when it is underground, for identifying Rathalos‚Äô tail sitting closely to the ground when it flies allowing for a quick cut into a dunk, and for noticing that Deviljho cannot resist the urge to fight other monsters that come into its territory.  You can make use of environmental hazards, traps, consumable buffs, and even the divisive clutch claw to turn every disadvantage into an advantage, and this is even more pronounced when you have a full team of hunters with various skillsets and specializations.  All of this allows for a level of personal expression that takes an already fantastic fight into a phenomenal experience.

4) Weapon Specialization and Skill Expression
Speaking of skill expression, Monster Hunter uses the Golden Rule of good game design: less is more.  It understands there is beauty in simplicity.  Fourteen weapons may not seem like much, but in using a similar design philosophy to fighting games, each one provides such a unique and deep experience that picking up a new weapon feels like picking up a new game.  Using mobile weapons like Dual Blades or Sword and Shield allows one to dip in-and-out of battle, utilizing i-frames to dive through monster attacks rather than away, providing an experience similar to that of Dark Souls.  Conversely, some weapons like Greatsword and Lance require you to stand your ground, identifying safe-zones in monster attacks and positioning yourself for an incredibly satisfying punish.  There are ranged weapons for the run-and-gunners out there, weapons that fly, and weapons that have the mechanical complexity to their combos that fighting game enthusiasts will enjoy.  In short, there is something for everyone in this game, and it‚Äôs difficult to play it ‚Äúwrong‚Äù when there are so many ‚Äúright‚Äù options.

5) The Hunt
The mark of a great game is something I like to call the ‚ÄúExperience‚Äù.  This is a combination of the mechanics, the story, the music, the tone, the art design and everything else that goes into a game to create the ‚Äúexperience‚Äù or ‚Äúfeel‚Äù of a game.  Going back to Dark Souls, I fell in love with that series because of the experience of being a lone soldier in a dying world.  The games relish themselves in the feelings of the morose and the macabre, and you can feel the sad state of the crumbling kingdoms and fallen knights around you as you struggle to not simply be another Hollow in the great web of failure the world is spun from.  The game feels oppressive in every aspect from its mechanics to its music.  And while this is not a review focused on gushing about Dark Souls, it is necessary to understand this concept to understand why Monster Hunter‚Äôs actual ‚Äúhunting experience‚Äù is so damn good.  Every point I‚Äôve talked about thus far as well as those more artistic ones that I have not (namely color scheme and music) all work together to create an experience of a ‚Äúhunt‚Äù that no other game series can match.  I understand many veterans believe the ‚Äúhunt‚Äù feeling of the game has been lost from previous titles, as pre-quest preparation is not as big a focus in this game, but I believe the overall experience is alive, well, and thriving in this game.  When you observe a monster‚Äôs features, relate it to real world animals, use that to infer something about its natural place in the world, watch it interact with its environment and other monsters to see how it fights, then put your own knowledge and skillset with your chosen weapon into battle against that monster, using all the tools and resources you‚Äôve gathered from your time in the wild, all of that feels like a true ‚Äúhunt‚Äù.  You are the hunter, this is your prey, and the more time you spend studying it and its environment the more success you will have.

In conclusion, I‚Äôve spent 1000 hours playing this game over the past two years and I‚Äôll spend 1000 more engaging with its colorful cast of crazy crocodilian carnivores just to experience the joy of the hunt.  I hope to see all you hunters out there and in the Wilds when next we meet.

Happy Hunting!

[h1]Monster Hunter: World is an action role-playing game In an unnamed low fantasy setting, humans and other sentient races have set their eyes on the New World, a separate continent from the populated Old World. The New World is an untamed wilderness where many powerful monsters roam free, and where researchers have been drawn to uncover new mysteries. The player takes the role of a Hunter, tasked to hunt down and either kill or trap monsters that roam in one of several environmental spaces.  [/h1]

[b]Enjoyable Hunting, Grinding, and the Community is Great. 

Gameplay - Great because it has many weapons and weapon movesets you can learn, several monsters to hunt, monster movesets to learn, tons of side contents, expeditions, multiplayer if u want to play with your friends but solo is preferable too if u want a challenge, and more. 

Difficulty - Challenging especially Iceborne (DLC) and the True Final Boss or Final Title Update will gonna beat the hell out of you until you lose your sanity but it's a relief and very satisfying if u defeated it.

Graphics - You'll forget what reality is.

Length - This game is long in Story but the length of what u can do in this game is 
"To infinity and beyond"

Sound Effects, Music, and Voice Acting - Eargasm except for "The Handler" because I want to punch my monitor every I hear her voice. (no pun intended)

Plot - Average but here's the example: A particular focus of the Expedition is to study Elder Dragons, powerful beasts that can affect entire ecosystems, and why they migrate to the New World every ten years in an event known as the Elder Crossing.

MHW is one of the best games I've ever played and is now My Favorite Game of All Time.

This is the first time I created a long-ass review because I love this game and of course MH Series as well.

MY RATING: 
Plot - 6/10           
Gameplay - 10/10                       
Enjoyment - 10/10
Overall - 10/10 for me [/b]

This game provides significant quality of life improvements and refinements over its predecessors, and lacks the arcadey, over-the-top nature of Rise/Sunbreak's faster combat system. In my opinion, World/Iceborne remain the gold standard best Monster Hunter game. 
Pros: The maps are visually stunning, the monster variety and design is great (especially with the Iceborne expansion), and the combat system is engaging even after 1000 hours (on console). With 14 weapons that all function completely differently, there is a playstyle for nearly everyone. Even the minigames, like tracking down rare endemic life that you can then keep as pets, are engaging.
Cons: There is a learning curve to the game, some interactions are poorly explained, and the game does require a bit of grinding; but persevere and this is a top tier gem worth the time players can put into it.

After 300 hours playing and complete every optional quest and got yellow name tag, here's my review:

-Monster Hunter: World is my first ever Monster Hunter series that i play, it's fun and annoying at the same time, the story is really nice but at the same time the world is just beautiful, its very different from other open world games that i play.

-I have played 100 hours of base game and 200 hours of iceborne dlc (after 100 hours of base game, i decide to buy iceborne dlc) and i'll tell you, ice borne dlc is super buff game play for this game. Don't get me wrong, even without dlc i still play this game for 100 hours until i decide to adding dlc iceborne into the game.

-The mechanic is really fun, battle with monster that just massive is got me goose bump with some bangers music that playing on the background makes the battle just out of this world. 


-To beat the monster, you forced to use your surrounding things like stone to lure the monster to precies area for you and your party easier to fight the monster, grab some thunderbug and craft it into flashpod to make monster blind for a second, climbing the root to get to the top, even we got some raider ride to make the exploration easy.

-With so many mechanic on this game, on my first hour playing this game i just wanna quit and just call it a day, because it so much work and i don't even have another goal after beating one monster, but with some good story and some tips from my friends, i decide to continuing the game for few hours.

-With no experience of this game, i feel like you just confused because the fighting style is so slow and the mechanic is really something else, but i tell you, this game is so much fun if you playing with 2 to 4 people. You can learn from them how the game work, how the mechanic game that you never see make the game easy, and for some people with just present one person can never make this game boring, even with your silly friend that died every time or even you died evey time (well in my case died every time is extremely frustrating, but at the same time, it's makes me wonder what is wrong with that, it is because my lack of experience? is it because i got too close to the monster? or is it because i don't bring proper weapon? etc. With that much though's in my mind, it's make me want to become the better hunter and beat the monster even harder that before.

-If you can't handle the monster preasure, there's mechanic called SOS Flares, it will make your quest appears on SOS quest, but to use SOS Flare you have to Online and got connection to internet. When you launch SOS Flare, wait for some time and some people will come to help you finish the quest.

-For people that isn't used to grind on their gaming, this game isn't for you, BUT with dlc include on every begining of the game, you got set named "Defender SET" that will make your base game much easier until you can grind some decent. (this is plus point for me cause mos of the game that grind really hard almost didn't care about newbie that just got into the game, yet they really trying hard to beat the game, most of scenario they stay until finish the game, and the rest just gave up and leave the game).

 After buying Iceborne dlc, my playing experience has changed. i can't put all of my iceborne dlc experience in this review cause it's too much, but i'll write some big changes of my Monster Hunter: World experience so far:

-Clutch claw is really powerful tool that make your hunting so much easy that you cant get feel it on base game
-You can wounded the monster to get much easier big damage, makes your hunting faster to clear because monster have been wounded
-Some weapon got new stance, like Long sword got Iai stance make it so much better game play cause you can infinitely attacking without putting your sword down.
-More story and more maps that make your gaming experiences never end (this where end game begin)

 The game is so good that my laptop can't even handle it (i use rog from 2016 and it's very lag i barely got some decent fps, yet that won't stop me playing this game), Kill monster to get material for make better armor and repeat, that what people said. But for me, grinding material alone is not enough, I have been blessed with good friend and good mentor, and i will use my knowledge of the game to help people to go trough the game, or in my case helping people that use sos flare to finish the quest faster is my end game habit if i got nothing else to do, but still want to play the game.

 With some raising player on the end of December, this game is best to be play with more that one player so you can learn from them and make your game play interesting and fun.

Been meaning to review this for years but haven't gotten to it til now. 
TL;DR - people against DRM are seething because their specs are garbo, game is fine

First off, addressing the DRM situation and the negative reviews relating to it; if you're having performance decreases that are actually impacting gameplay, your pc is probably outdated and shouldn't be playing "newer" games anyways (even though MHW launched in 2018 and isn't really that demanding). I can understand the issue with Camcom's stance on modding (QOL and Visual mods anyways, not game changing mods) but a lot of games and game companies are like that so... what difference does it really make? game is still playable and enjoyable as-is. 
Second. The actual game itself. Great game, great visuals, story is hit and miss but realistically the main point is monster genocide 
Spent a good amount of time in base world years ago, then eventually Iceborne. Not too difficult if you're not new to these type of games or especially any souls-like
Even then, learning the mechanics of the weapons and finding what works can be a challenge at first but eventually you adjust to the way things work. Then next thing you know, you're grinding endgame content hours on end.

Only REAL complaints I have are the abundance of sluggish animations that take forever to get through (and cant cancel either). As a greatsword main, of course being abysmally slow with attacks and combos in general are the bane of my existence but that's why timing is key. however theres just the slightest things that tend to irritate over time regarding slow animations. would take awhile explaining but if you know, you know. 
The other issue, as a completionist and achievement hunter, is the insane level of RNG it takes to actually get some of the achievements. It ends up being a chore especially for crown hunting. but if you're solely focusing on that, then obviously it takes the fun out of it instead of just letting it happen over time naturally (instead of solely farming for crown monsters for hours a day)
Nice.
Awesome game!

It's such an amazing game that offers a perfect blend of challenge and reward. The combat can be tricky at first, but as you get the hang of it, you'll feel like a true hunter taking down massive beasts. It's so satisfying to see yourself land hits and take on tougher challenges with ease. Overall, it's a really fun and thrilling experience that you won't regret trying out!

The combat system has a learning curve, gradually increasing in complexity and leading to exciting encounters with various monsters. Taking down these formidable creatures and using their parts to craft powerful gear is a truly epic experience. Wearing your hard-earned trophies as items is a unique touch that adds an extra layer of excitement to the game.

Although I thoroughly enjoyed my solo adventures, the multiplayer aspect adds a whole new dimension to the experience. Hunting alongside fellow players, and sharing in the spoils of victory enhances the overall enjoyment of the game is one aspect I have missed and wished was more accessible. 

Monster Hunter World is an exceptional game that offers an immersive and exciting adventure. The game's world, mechanics, and the thrill of hunting make it a masterpiece. Whether you are a seasoned hunter or new to the series, "Monster Hunter World" is a must-play game.

Multiplayer with friends: Avoid at all costs.

In all honesty, I enjoy the game and would love to recommend it. Alas, the game has dozens of very anti-consumer micro-transactions (Such as having to spend real money to change the way your character looks, and locking several character cosmetics and house decorations with no in-game way to earn or unlock them). If you like games in the "Hunting" genre, then this is probably one of the best. However I refuse to endorse a game with such flagrant anti-consumer practices, in this game's case in particular it's incredibly egregious to me as the bulk of your play experience is grinding out gear unlocks... *except the ones Capcom wants to charge you extra for.*
"Gives me the ick"/10

the first part of the game is good, but once you go to master rank the monsters are disgustingly hard and to be honest not everyone has the patience to stay and grind one shity monster over and over until you get it, this is not dark souls, it should not have such a stupid difficulty spike.

This port is incredibly half assed. The controls for mouse and keyboard are horrendous and the hardest to reprogram out of any game I've ever played. It took me 2 weeks and 100s of google searches to finally find clear enough information about how to rebind the sling so that it actually works, because the default setting for sling does not work on PC unless you have a basic 5 button mouse(which I do not), the ingame settings do not just say 'FIRE SLING', and even then theres so many other button problems with the default settings that the game becomes a nightmare to play. 

Also, the worst UI I have ever experience in any game ever. They just kept the garbage console UI and made no alterations to make it accessible for PC users. Systems upon systems piled up and no explanations how any of them work, and combined with such a horrible UI, makes for a STEEP learning curve. There is no excuse for such a piss poor porting of a game

Lastly I will talk about the combat. Combat is pretty mediocre. Animation locks with no mid-animation cancellation option, forcing you to commit to swinging wildly at the air often. Literally 2 button combat, which is super lame considering the game has combos, so a combo is literally just pressing 1 of the 2 buttons. Incredibly slow movement speed/turning speed. Game relies way too much on stuns for artificial difficulty instead of just programming better monster combat. The stuns are so rage enducing, that itll make you want to just quit the game. Even with stun reduction gear(which doesnt appear to work at all?), the stuns last way too long.

So why am I recommending this game despite having all these negative things to say?
1)its cheap. For the price, its a fun boss killing adventure. 
2)multiplayer VASTLY improves this game. Once you experience your first raid on a boss with others, you will understand why people love this game so much.
3)the game was designed to be played with a controller, and if you dont mind submitting and using one, it plays alot better

I think Monster Hunter: World is best played solo and since my experience was all about 4 player co-op I can't really recommend the game for a few reasons.

1: Multiplayer sucks. Imagine having to disband your party all the time, start a solo quest, get to a cutscene, quit, and then finally reform the party to play said level together. Whoever designed this game clearly wanted to showcase the annoying NPCS and NPC outfits as much as possible which imo is why they force you to play certain missions solo to unlock co-op.
Also the scaling of difficulty is bad for 3-4 players when for Solo / Duo you get invincible cat monsters to help you. 3-4 should have a few more revives imo.

2: Story is meh. This is one of the few games where I feel like I am the bad guy and I wish that I could play as the monster in order to annihilate the annoying npcs and npc cat monsters. The Quest Giver NPC I am convinced is an Evil Entity that was created purely to annoy me.

3: Game should be called "Resource Hunter" and not "Monster Hunter" because that is the game pretty much. Running around collecting resources before eventually bumping into the monster, having a spat, chasing after it while collecting more resources before finally killing or capturing the monster.

4: Game feels very grindy when it comes to all the materials and money that you need to upgrade items.

5. Combat feels rather repetitive and sometimes the hitboxes from monster attacks feel really off. Imo it would've been better if the game allowed you to switch between like 2 weapons so you can vary up the fighting - otherwise you'd have to run back to the box to switch weapons which would feel lousy.

In conclusion: due to the multiplayer experience rubbing me off in the wrong way I can't recommend this game because it isn't fun having to switch from solo to co-op for many missions. Since it was co-op that brought me to this game that is the biggest drawback for me. Solo? I can see the game being fine. Otherwise 2 player is probably the next best thing despite the same issue with solo locked mission cutscene skulduggery nonsense simply because you both get an invincible cat monster that can aggro the monsters without drawbacks.

Would recommend if I could feed the annoying colonising NPCS to the monsters.

How to make luwak white coffee
Ingredients : a sachet of luwak white coffee, boiled water
Steps/how to :
1. Take a sachet of luwak white coffee and tear it.
2. Put the coffee powder into a cup.
3. Brew coffee with boiled water into the cup.
4. Stir until the coffee powder dissolves in the boiled water.
3. Wait for a while until the luwak white coffee gets warm.
4. Luwak white coffee ready to drink.
