[h1] My first ever review. [/h1]

This is easily one of my favourite games of all time and an introduction to now one of my favourite franchises of all time. I picked up this game back when it first released and it had a lot of issues with the online multiplayer servers which got fixed within a couple weeks. It's sad but most of the negative reviews for this game are for the initial connectivity issues. But anyway onto the actual review.

Most people read reviews to find out if anything is wrong with a game so after playing for 1,500 hours and earning all the achievements, here is what I believe to be wrong with this game with discussion based around those points.

[h3] Price / Playtime / Replayability [/h3]
First and foremost the price is always a hurdle with any of these AAA games. But I will say that despite the big price tag of not only the base game but also the DLC Iceborne, this game delivers with the amount of content it provides. The iceborne DLC is easily one of the biggest game DLCs I have ever found and played effectively doubling if not trippling the content of the base game. It's also worth mentioning that in both the base game and the DLC, after the story has finished there is a huge amount of end-game content to keep you attached for hours fighting new monsters, raids, events, new gear, etc.

[h3] Beginner Friendly? [/h3]
No. This is quite possibly the biggest issue with this game and there are a lot of aspects as to why it fails in this area. Let me first talk about the UI. The UI in this game is quite possibly the worse UI in such a successful game. It's incredibly unintuitive and trying to learn how to do anything can take hundreds of hours. People joke that the UI is a harder battle than the monsters in this game and it really is true for new players. You may not even know that loadouts exist for dozens of hours and then when you learn that they exist you won't be able to figure out how to register and use them effectively until another dozen hours. I've seen people say that the UI is designed this way due to it being first released on console and the intended experience being a controller but I don't think that gives it any excuse for it to be as unintuitive as it is. Unfortunately it's the product of a 20 year old franchise that hasn't changed its outdated systems all that much. It works once you know how it works but yeah.

The weapons and combat can be a struggle for new players too, there are some weapons that are more beginner friendly than others, I personally used one of the most complicated weapons (Charge Blade). I also want to clarify that complicated does not necessarily mean hard in this case. The Greatsword is a great- (hehe get it) example of this because its combos are very simple and you really only have 1 or 2 options of what you want to do, however the weapon is still challenging due to its slow mobility and the weapon is all about positioning and timing. Regardless of what weapon you pick, I highly recommend looking up some youtube guides for your weapon or asking a friend who has experience to teach you, else you will be struggling against the monsters without realising that you have a parry for example.

Another point regarding beginner difficulty is general items and consumables. A lot of new players don't quite understand just how important some of these items can be and it's one of those things that you'll only really learn through external feedback. A great example is flashpods which can be used against flying creatures to blind them so they fall out of the sky for a large damage window opportunity. A big thing in this game is capturing monsters which literally lets you finish the hunt when the monster typically only has 30% HP left (in the beginning). I could easily talk about items for a long time but you get the point. This game has tutorials but they're all useless. You will only learn from external sources.

[h3] Achievement Hunting [/h3]
If you're like me, you love to hunt for achievements. This game's achievements are... tedious. Obviously there are your basic ones like going through the story and killing 100 elder dragons or whatever, but the really difficult ones can take hundreds of hours. Monsters in this game don't have a defined size and instead appear on a sort of spectrum. If you're fighting a large version of a monster and you beat it, you'll be rewarded with a crown made from silver or gold depending on it's size. There are big gold crowns and small gold crowns and there are 2 achievements (4 if you count the DLC) which are to acquire every large and small gold crown in the game. Gold crown monsters have between a 3%-6% chance to spawn normally and you can up those rates by doing some event quests but it really is abysmal. But those achievements aren't even the worst ones, and I think that really just sums it up. If you want to achievement hunt this game then by all means do it, I did, but it will take over 1000 hours to do so, so I hope you enjoy your time :P

[h3] Is it a Souls-Like? [/h3]
This is a good question and it really comes down to what your definition of a souls-like is. Personally I don't think so and I'll lay out a few key differences as to why. Leaving behind the obvious gameplay loop differences (things like going back to retrieve your souls and checkpoints), the combat itself has a fair few differences. 

First off the lock-on. The lock-on in this game is atrocious and you might be tempted to use it at first but even on controller you are better off just turning your camera to look at the monster. It doesn't have any fluidity like Fromsoftware's carefully craft lock-on camera does, and just keeps the monster dead centre of the screen (If you don't know, Fromsoftware's lock-on camera dynamically moves where the lock on is placed on the screen based on your position in the environment. It also zooms out for larger monsters, etc.)

Let's look at iFrames (invulnerability frames). This game does have iFrames but they are no where close to what Dark Souls' iFrames are. In this game you are encouraged to roll away from an attack, block it, or counter it. You do have iFrames at the very very beginning of your roll and have hundreds of hours you could start to utilise it in some situations but I would never rely on it as a beginner. There is actually a skill called Evade Window which increases this size of this iFrame window so if you want to practice getting better at rolling through things then that would be something to aim for.

As for weapons there are 14 different weapon types including 3 ranged options, as mentioned previously, each of them is difficult in their own right and they all have different combos, abilities and nuances. It very possible to switch between any weapon type on the go so if you want to learn multiple at a time then I encourage it.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
I am obviously making this review 6 years after the game was released so there's not much I can say that hasn't already been said. But I think the points I've highlighted above should be a little more niche than your typical performance and graphical posts. Most reviews will tell you to play the game, as does this one. But I won't shy away from telling people that it's hard to learn, especially on your own. Do research. This game is far more enjoyable if you know what you're doing.

Happy Hunting everybody! I look forward to seeing everyone in Wilds!

EDIT: Just to mention DRM briefly. If people don't know, DRM is an anti-cheat software however for CAPCOM's purposes it's mainly used for anti-piracy. This is not a new thing with their games however people are talking about it due to a recent controversy surround street fighter. CAPCOM typically has a more expensive anti-cheat software in their games when they first release and then downgrade to a less expensive one after a few years. It's not something you should be worried about and it's not quite retro-active as people say it is.

This game is digital crack. You might not like the taste at first, but may god have mercy on your soul if you get hooked on it.

I tried it out on XBox when it came out and bounced off of it pretty fast. With the reveal of Monster Hunter Wilds and the big sale last year I decided to try it out again and now I'm in for good. Finished the story (including Iceborne) today almost 140h in and I still feel like I have only scratched the surface.

The basic loop of the game is that you hunt monsters (duh) and collect their parts to make new armor and weapons to hunt stronger monsters. This loop gets addictive as hell and if you get into it, you will hunt the same monster over and over again to complete the set.

The combat itself is more methodical than your average third-person action game. Animations are slow and generally leave you locked into the attack until it is done. So if you initiate a move that takes 5 seconds to complete when it is not safe, the monster may move out of your attack and attack you instead. So pick your openings for big attacks and stick to fast moves while the monster is still mobile.

The great thing about this combination of having to hunt monsters repeatedly and a combat system that rewards knowing how to read the monster's behavior is that you naturally get better at fighting the monsters. Nothing beats the feeling of having mastered a certain fight and absolutely bulling a monster that kicked your ass the first time around.

Some things that may bother you in the beginning:
   - The menus are not great. A basic UI/UX overhaul would be appreciated. You'll get used to them.
   - The game is not great at teaching you how each weapon works and I feel like most weapons have moves and tech that feel very much required for some of the harder fights. Watch the little videos on every weapon in game to get an idea of what you might like and then watch a tutorial for that weapon on YouTube.
   - There are two story-related missions that break the general loop described above. These SUCK. You'll know which I mean when you have to do them. Just sit them out.

All these negative points are truly nitpicks compared to the vast amount of top-tier content. Truly a Masterpiece.

Old review: 
The best non-competitive game I've ever played. It's never a chore to play this game; even though I've collected and crafted every item in the game in 500 hours of play (minus a few AT Kulve Taroth weapons), I still find it fun to learn a new weapon and kill some monsters. The weapons are very unique and offer many different play styles. They are also very deep, and can get extremely technical if trying to learn meta for max DPS.

Incredible graphics, amazing score. I also like the story.

This game is easy to mod, which is fantastic. There are some great quality of life mods that make this game more enjoyable to play on PC over console.

Cons: The servers go down a lot during new events or AT Kulve Taroth. Extremely frustrating. I hope they work on disconnection issues for Iceborne.

The only other problem I have is a minor one, and that's Bazelgeuse's behavior. It is too predictable and thus just becomes a stupid annoyance. If he is on the map while doing an investigation and you initiate a fight with another large monster, he will show up to interrupt you 100% of the time (assuming he can get to that part of the map). I think the reson I bought this game was because it was missing all of the BS from modern games. I like overwatch, I like battlefield, but I love this game for being a whole complete game, that set out to make an old series of games better. Older fans of the series hate certain aspects of this game and I understand that. I didn't like ds3 when it came out originally. But this game made so many QOL improvements that I can't imagine going back to older games anymore. 

I don't think this game is easier or harder than previous games. But I do think its different. Very few monsters have combo moves that are guaranteed to kill you. But many late game monsters have oneshot kill moves. I think many old fans find this game easy because they are used to dodging attacks, because many attacks in old games would lead to a combo death.

Contentwise, this game is longer than most mainstream games, but its also shorter than older games. Not many modern games will have this much content, so I won't complain.

Honestly, play this game. Most of the networking issues are either resolved or being resolved. Play with friends too, although admittedly, they really should change the way the cutscenes work. Either way, have fun.

Can't wait for Wilds!!!!

First off, the learning curve is steep and the game doesn¬¥t explain everything. I was 50+hours into it before I realised my switchaxe has two guages, seriously just watch tutorials to avoid needless frustration. Often you¬¥ll need gear to fight certain monsters properly, grind it first, not being equiped properly is the source of a lot of frustration. I¬¥ll give you the example of me trying to farm nergigante ( highly agressive elder dragon ), I wasn¬¥t equiped with a weapon that had elderseal or exploited a weakness of his. To make matters worse my armorskills were all over the place, it was disgustingly frustrating to fight this thing on my own. Now I have farmed for the armor I needed and have a new weapon that exploits his weaknesses to some extent + has high elderseal. It¬¥s pretty easy after this, save yourself the headache and look it up first. it¬¥ll take you 10 hours to figure it out on your own.

Enviroments are gorgeous and easy enough to navigate, a variation of smaller animals roam the lands, it feels alive no remarks there. Even your headquarters look awesome and everything you need is right where you want it. The monsters are impressive, especially in turf wars, the first time seeing a rathalos ( flying monster ) just plain picking up an anjanath ( t-rex land monster ) and dropping it on the ground for massive damage was amazing.

Now the combat, it¬¥s my first game out of the Monster Hunter series and honestly I expected the combat to be more fluid. I have to admit, so far I only have experience with the switchaxe wich is a heavy weapon by all accounts. It¬¥s just realy difficult to play reactive, you can¬¥t weave combo¬¥s and dodge monsters at the same time. Sometimes the monsters can just charge, run you over and then start stunlocking you. You don¬¥t survive 10 seconds of not being able to do anything in this game, it¬¥s frustrating dying like this, it doesn¬¥t really feel fair.  

I¬¥m 50 hours into this and my gear is still crap, I¬¥m struggeling to get trough. Dark souls gives you a sense of achievement when beating a boss because you can simply try again without having lost anything. Here you have to farm up what you spent trying to kill something that guts you with 1 attack. You can¬¥t play reactive because everything stunlocks you and the weapons limit your mobility greatly. Half the time you¬¥re running around the monster with your weapon sheated hoping for a gap so you can heal. Then when you take a swig of your potion it turns around, looks at you from half way across the map and then jumps you. Taking a potion will also limit your mobility and it heals you gradualy. I¬¥d say it takes about 2,5 seconds to down and it draws monster aggro so if you need to dodge or get hit you¬¥ll lose half the potion + take the damage the monster dealt. This is the reality when fighting on your own, having multiple people to hunt with greatly improves the experience.

Would I recommend it? It¬¥s not for everyone I can tell you that much, casual playing isn¬¥t an option, you need to grind for gear to take on bigger monsters. If you¬¥re not willing to put in a huge amount of hours to finish a lackluster story then don¬¥t buy it. It is time consuming and a lot of RNG, you can manipulate what the monsters drop by breaking certain parts but when you need gems... Good luck, decorations are even worse.

EDIT : After 600 hours I still loath the day the clutch claw was introduced, its mechanics are so damn janky and the entire Iceborne DLC is balanced around it.

It goes : 
1. Mantle up and tenderize the monster part you¬¥re looking to attack 
2. yeet it into the wall wich downs the monster and use the opening for damage
3. Run around like a moron becuase now the monster is enraged and hyper agressive.

Repeat when no longer enraged. The claw made the game so much worse.

 Arch Tempered Velkhana, Alatreon and Fatalis are the 3 cherries on top of the shitcake. Besides dealing absurd amounts of damage, enough to one shot you, they have mechanics requiring you to break certain parts, a damage check to avoid a one shot, a plethora of blights and/or a 30 minute time limit forcing you to play and slot decorations agressively. Soloing these fights feel entirely unfair and they¬¥re not doable with randoms, they cart in the first phases. I¬¥ve beaten these monsters and never intend to do them again, it is not "challenging" it is frustration beyond belief. If the clutch claw makes it into Wilds I¬¥m out.

Monster Hunter: World is a breathtaking journey into a vibrant and dangerous ecosystem that sets a new standard for the action RPG genre. Developed by Capcom, this installment in the Monster Hunter series manages to blend stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and a captivating narrative into a seamless and unforgettable experience.

Visually, Monster Hunter: World is a masterpiece. The environments are lush, diverse, and teeming with life. From dense forests to arid deserts, each locale is meticulously crafted, creating a world that feels alive and dynamic. The attention to detail extends to the majestic and fearsome monsters that inhabit these lands. The creature design is awe-inspiring, showcasing a perfect balance between realism and fantasy.

The gameplay is the heart of Monster Hunter: World, and it excels in delivering a deeply satisfying and strategic hunting experience. Players assume the role of a Hunter, tasked with tracking and defeating colossal monsters. The combat system is fluid, intuitive, and rewards skillful play. The range of weapons and armor available allows for diverse playstyles, catering to both newcomers and seasoned veterans.

One of the game's highlights is the cooperative multiplayer feature. Joining forces with friends or other players online adds a new layer of excitement and teamwork to the hunts. The seamless transition between single-player and multiplayer modes is a testament to the game's well-crafted design.

Monster Hunter: World doesn't just rely on its gameplay; it also weaves a compelling narrative. The storyline unfolds as players explore the New World, revealing the mysteries surrounding the Elder Dragons and the Research Commission. The lore is rich, and the characters are well-developed, making the journey as engaging as the hunts themselves.

The game's soundtrack is another standout element, enhancing the atmosphere with epic compositions that perfectly complement the intense battles and serene moments. The sound design, from the roars of the monsters to the ambient sounds of the environments, further immerses players in the world of Monster Hunter.

The post-launch support for Monster Hunter: World has been commendable, with regular updates, events, and collaborations keeping the community engaged. Capcom's commitment to providing new content and addressing player feedback demonstrates their dedication to delivering a lasting and enjoyable experience.

In conclusion, Monster Hunter: World is a triumph in both design and execution. It successfully modernizes the Monster Hunter series while retaining the core elements that fans love. With its breathtaking visuals, exhilarating gameplay, and captivating world, Monster Hunter: World stands as a must-play title for fans of action RPGs and newcomers alike.

I love the Monster Hunter series. This game was my introduction to it all. At first, it's a hard pill to swallow especially if you're someone like me who takes longer than most people to learn mechanics of a simple game, let alone the mechanics of a big game like Monster Hunter World. The mechanics, the monsters are huge, there are so many armour choices, descriptions etc. and it can be overwhelming at first. You'll die a ton until you learn your groove in Astera. Find the weapon that best suits you, get some armour, collect those scout flies and start fighting everything in your way. You can't get good at this game by standing in base. You need to get down and dirty and learn from the ground up. It'll take time, but those who put in the time, effort and commitment to learning will enjoy it far more in my opinion and get the whole experience that MHW has to offer. If you're up for an adventure, here it is!

Wonderful game, the tracking system could use some work, the hit boxes also need some fixing but overall the combat system when you get used to it is great. i recommend not starting out with charge blade like i did unless you have tons of knowledge on the weapon and game anyway. the way you can interact with the environment and monsters makes you feel like you're part of the game, part of the ecosystem within the game, you can lure monsters and track them by gathering clues around the map. I also love the incredible world design with the way different monsters interact with each map, it makes you feel like this is a real world and you are merely tapping the surface of the secrets of this world. All the different weapons allows you to have a way to play regardless of how you play the game, do you want a complicated weapon with intricit combos that unleash big damage, charge blade might be for you, do you want long range, either of the bowguns or the bow will help with that, are you a weeb in desperate need of a long sword to cosplay with, long sword is for you. All in all the different ways you can play while interacting with the environment allows you to feel like you're inside a world doing whatever you want while sticking to one singular goal, being a monster hunter.

How to play Monster Hunter.
1. Find armor you want
2. Fight monster
3. Fight monster again
4. Fight monster 3 more times
5. Realize you're missing a material for the full set
6. Fight monster another 5 times
7. Finally get full set
8. Repeat with next monster

Game Good

[h1] One of my all time favorites [/h1]

I love this game. Not much else I can add to it but that.

[h2] The good [/h2]

- The combat. The simple to pick up, yet complex to master weapons really make this combat system shine. It's a very methodical game that puts heavy emphasis on positioning, timing and knowledge. While still feeling snappy and precise when you need it to be.

- God tier soundtrack. Listen to the theme of Raging Brachydios, Fatalis, Nergigante, Safi'jiiva or really most monsters in the game. It's some of the best orchestral soundtrack you could find in a game.

- Stunning visual design and animations. I legitimately spent hours on end watching background events and even walking through areas. This is a beautiful game. If you can run the game with the HD texture pack, please do so. It only makes an already great looking game look even better.

- Great endgame. The Guiding Lands are a great way to encourage further playtime and cooperation, while not feeling too overly grindy.

[h2] The bad [/h2]

- The jewel grind can get tedious sometimes. I legitimately grinded for hours on end and never quite got the jewel I needed. Even with the jewel farming quests. That said the later updates amended that a bit.

- Clutch claw is a system mechanic that nerfs weapons. My beloved insect glaive got absolutely butchered by this change. Not only is my damage already comparatively low to other weapons, now I have to tenderize twice with the clutch claw to reach my full damage. Amended a bit with shaver jewel, but it could have been implemented better.

- The netcode is shaky. Several times where I played perfectly fine in co-op with a friend our connection just died. Even though all other co-op games we played didn't have this issue.

- You can't play story quests co-op until you watched a specific in-quest cutscene. This was just really annoying, I desperately wish this wasn't a mechanic in the game.

[h2] My conclusion [/h2]

These gripes are very minor overall, I thoroughly enjoyed my time with this game and will recommend it to anyone who is interested in playing it. An amazing addition to Capcom's library. Now go out there and start hunting, Fatalis awaits you at the end of the road.

Bought the game when it released, didn't like it much back then. Decided to give it another go after many years since playing the previous games to see if I like it better now. I still think the game gets bogged down by some unnecessary features and mechanics that take away from the good parts of the core gameplay, like (unskippable) cutscenes with a story that doesn't really need to be there. Being online constantly is also fairly annoying, being able to pause during a hunt is a minor but pretty convenient feature, and I don't want to have randoms joining me during solo hunts anyways. Overall though, the core gameplay loop is still just as good as the previous games, and playing on PC feels much better than playing on a shitty little 3DS as well, so I managed to find appreciation for the game again.

Monster Hunter World was my first step into the franchise, so while I can‚Äôt speak with the wisdom of a veteran I‚Äôll give my two cents as a greenhorn. In short, MHW is not an easy game, but I think it is easily the best one I‚Äôve played. It rewards patience and practice, and conquering a difficult monster is one of the most satisfying feelings in the world--before you inevitably hunt said monster into extinction because you need more of its teeth and a piece of its frontal cranium to stick on your funky hammer that looks like a bastardized axe for your own amusement.

TLDR: Demanding but highly satisfying learning curve for both weapons and monsters, diverse large maps to explore and environments to use to your advantage, attention to small details like capturing endemic life and thoughtful NPC interactions. 

I started out really badly, missing hits and getting whacked around constantly by even the earliest monsters. As an old Warframe player, the lack of mobility in MHW was quite jarring, shown by the countless times I‚Äôve tried to dodge and failed miserably. 

After the initial battering, the next step is about perseverance, revisiting monsters to farm materials to get stronger armor and weapons. It‚Äôs an uphill battle, especially if you need to repeatedly do a monster that took 30 minutes and 2 faints the first time you tried. It‚Äôs about fighting the monster and yourself, as you really need to think one step ahead and pace yourself according to the enemy. 
The diverse range of weapons the MH franchise offers is no secret, giving players many different ways to fight the same monsters. In my opinion, every weapon is great and fun, and while it takes a lot of time to learn and master certain ones, it‚Äôs never a bad idea to have multiple main weapons to see you through different hunts. I love the insect glaive like nothing else, and I‚Äôll die on this hill. (not literally) But for monsters that are more ferocious, I tend to approach them more cautiously with the lance or charge blade with their incredible mix of defensive and offensive capabilities, for example.

This journey of constant learning and relearning forms the bulk of my MHW experience, and even as I‚Äôm gearing up for the final boss I‚Äôm still working out the moves of monsters I‚Äôve already conquered, and learning new weapons. I found this process of self-improvement to be the most satisfying part of the game, and something I haven‚Äôt been able to find in any other franchise to date. There‚Äôs no better feeling than greeting a monster like an old friend before you kick the shit out of each other, with a fast-paced fight that makes you feel almost invincible as you dodge, weave or just walk out of the way of attacks that used to rend the flesh off your bones.

MHW has seen me through some tough times as well, so the sense of achievement I attained from overcoming great beasts here has also kept me going in the real world.

As the name implies, MHW emphasizes the world it has created, giving players several maps to explore. Besides being pretty, these locations provide diverse areas to fight monsters in. As you chase monsters from one area to the next, you‚Äôll find no shortage of ledges, slopes, vine traps, loose boulders or even cannons to gain the upper hand in a battle. This is something that‚Äôs very much less present in older MH titles, something I realised after playing MHGU a month ago. 
While the same few maps can get old after hundreds of hours, I think that it was very thoughtful to have such features in the first place that spice up the fight more often than not. Moreso, I enjoyed the exploration itself, running around freely in expeditions to collect mushrooms, look for shortcuts or befriend the local cats--who can actually help out a lot in hunts. Befriending the Grimalkyne tribes in each map means they may set up vine traps to ensnare a monster, or even drop a whole firing squad to give you a chance to brutalize your quarry. 

I also enjoyed collecting the endemic life, though it is a much smaller part of the game. As an animal lover, I was stunned when I threw my net at a random bird on the beach and got to bring it home as a pet. Almost any creature you see in the wild is either a material or a potential pet to let loose in your room, and I have spent many hours hunting down fluffy birds to keep, or fishing for majestic fish in the frozen bowels of the arctic. This is not compulsory unless you‚Äôre going for 100% achievements, but I feel it‚Äôs a very nice touch to the game, making the world seem more alive. 

While nobody ever plays Monster Hunter for the story, I feel like MHW had a decent storyline, following abnormal behavior of a great dragon and pioneering exploration into the New World to uncover the secrets of the land. While not terribly emotional, I feel that it was linear enough to be clear, and gave story quests some meaning. I do feel that the NPCs were crafted with a lot of thought, seeing how different fleets were sent to the New World every 10 years, each with different specialties like engineering, resource management, research or hunting. This does shape NPCs‚Äô attitudes and lines, especially if they hail from different fleets. 
Moreso, MHW gives presence to the player, as NPC voice lines change according to the recent quests players have completed, or if the player is about to square up against a tough foe. I remember the day I completed all the optional quests in MHW, and I was presented with a bonus quest to hunt 4 challenging monsters in a row. After my success, every NPC in the hub presented me with a short congratulatory message, and it differed significantly between everyone, from the novice hunters strolling around to the resident botanist, and even the sailors who helped out at port managed to get a word in. I recall walking to the highest point in Astera and speaking to the Admiral, who had quite the speech prepared. I screenshotted the whole conversation, and I still look at it from time to time when I'm feeling sappy. It‚Äôs a small detail, but I have heartfelt appreciation for the team that decided to implement it, giving some weight to my actions, and making MHW even more immersive. 
All the NPCs are now clamoring for me to face off against the final boss, so in a way I feel like their hopes and dreams are on my back too.

It‚Äôs a long review, but I feel like I couldn‚Äôt have discounted my feelings for this game with less words. MHW remains my favorite game of all time, and has even encouraged me to delve further into the series with other titles like MHGU and MHR, and now I eagerly await the release of MHST2. If you have any doubts about buying this game, it‚Äôs never too late to start. It‚Äôs more fun with friends (though I insisted on doing mostly everything solo) so grab your buddies and don‚Äôt hesitate to call on pubs if you need help--some randoms are actually really good!
Happy Hunting!


Edit: I beat the final boss for the first time, and on a solo hunt! I finished the quest with 30s left on the clock, but it was really satisfying to get it done, and go through all the NPC dialogue at the end. There's a cool nod to characters from the previous generations as well, which is a nice touch!

Second edit: The endgame grind can get droll, but it's still a blast to play, and a means to pass the time while we all wait for MHRise's PC release, and Sunbreak! I've managed to solo the final boss 15 times now, and while not perfect these hunts have given me some seriously hair raising thrills. I look forward to the challenges I'll find in other games of the series!

Third edit: In 2024 I'm returning to MHW. Rise and Sunbreak were fun, but not nearly as fleshed out as their predecessor. They were a bit arcadey and fast paced, so it's nice to come back to a more organic-feeling hunt and pick up where I left off.

Monster Hunter sucks with its lackluster gameplay and uninspired mechanics. The touted open-world features only serve to mask the repetitive grind beneath bland visuals. Combat feels clunky and unresponsive. The convoluted crafting system and excessive resource gathering turn what should be a thrilling experience into a tedious chore. The attempt at storytelling falls flat, with forgettable characters and cringe-worthy dialogue. Multiplayer connectivity issues further hinder any potential enjoyment. Monster Hunter is a regrettable misstep, failing to capture the essence that made its predecessors truly engaging and enjoyable, and of course, the malicious DRM practices Capcom has implemented.
good to play with friends.

I had never played Monster Hunter before so this was my entry to the series. The monsters get very big. Every monster you kill unlocks a new armour to build. There are lots of cut-scenes and a decent enough story to tie things together. Good Japanese VA. Multiplayer is fun. Different weapons to choose from. 

There wasn't as much content as I was expecting before it threw me back into the early stages for a kind of NG+. Same areas, same enemies, but slightly stronger. If you use the Defender Armour and Weapons you could probably get through those initial stages in about 15 hours.

It's worth noting that even though there are relatively few areas, going back to them is rewarding. I had never fished or caught a bug until 30 hours in. The meta can be complicated, so having experienced players guide you is a plus.

The multiplayer is kinda odd. You can't join another player on a hunt until they've seen all the cutscenes in a level. My friends are all up to iceborne and don't want to play with me anyway. Luckily online matchmaking is decent and other players often help on quests. 

Elder dragon farming (early post-game content) = the grind for mats is real. No problem since I'm still enjoying hitting monsters.

75 hours in. The ability of some monsters to rush past you and hit you despite not making contact with you is not enjoyable.

Here are my personal negative feedback in this game:

-Clutch Claw (Iceborne Expansion mainly)
Clutch Claw mechanic is BS. Iceborne Expansion introduces this mechanic but it also affected the base game as well. Weakness Exploit nerfed to 50% max affinity which also makes it worse for those who don't owned the Expansion. It's ok to not use Clutch claw though, but it makes the hunt quite longer. it's not a really big deal. The problem is not the Clutch Claw itself really, but the constant need to tenderize, since with the Iceborne update many hitzones from base World got updated to reflect the change so tenderize was not to deal more damage but to be as efficient as before but only on the tenderized zones. Also the constant wallbanging to keep the monster enraged is very annoying.

-Decorations
Decorations (Jewels can be slotted to armors to gain armor skill effect.) are obtained by drop chance from hunts. Some of them are extremely has low chance to drop which is frustrating in my opinion. Though Some low tier deco can be obtain through melding process in village. (I don't like that so much grind especially I have a limited time to play because of IRL stuff. If you're an old world hunter like me. I find this deco system grindy.)

-Playable offline?
Possible offline, but you can't Pause the game unfortunately.

-Playable solo?
You can solo the game, finish the main story and the expansion story. BUT, some monsters are recommended with other hunters. Those monsters are still possible to solo but its extremely difficult. and there's a specific monster in the Iceborne expansion that require you to deal elemental damage and destroy a part or else suffer an unavoidable fatal attack after some time has passed.

These are my personal opinion to the game.

TL;DR After spending 2200 hours between console and PC I can honestly say that this game is definitely worth the money and is the best game I have ever played. 

If like me you like a challenge and great rewards then this is the game for you. However the game has a few flaws:

1. Questionable hit boxes. For example the monsters sometimes will hit you when you are standing behind or to the sides.
2. The User Interface is not new player friendly and takes time to figure out. Luckily the game has lots of tutorials.
3. The 2 final bosses are infuriating and terribly designed however the rewards are worth it.
4. The end game region that you unlock has since become pointless other than for grinding Transmog items. As a result 
    it has become a "ghost town" for some endgame content.

Don't let these issues sway you from trying this game. These are minor issues when comparing it to the rest of the game. Overall this game is in my eyes a masterpiece.

Monster Hunter franchise introduces two games per generation. 
As per 5th generation 

Monster Hunter World as the Mainline game 
and 
Monster Hunter Rise as the Portable game 

Things I like about Monster Hunter World that you might come to like too. 

+Bald Hairstyle and Dance Emotes 
+Slow and Methodical 
+Feedback and Impact 
+Realistic and Grounded 
+Cats and Handler 
+Armor Sets and Monsters 
+Biomes and Event Monsters 
+Alatreon and Safi Jiiva 
+Shara Ishvalda and Fatalis 
 
-Cheaters and Exploiters in a PVE game 
~Modders who flex their DPS

This game is simple. 
Following the quest but you lost? don't worry there is a tracking device (It's called scoutfiles).
Various monsters, combat equipment, and upgrade with various element power (fire, water, thunder, paralysis, poison, dragon etc.).
Yes, you can upgrade the equipment and forge an equipment.
And you will have a cat (it's called palico) to accompany your journey. 
The palico is quite usefull, because it can heal you and helping you placing a trap while you fighting a monster.
You will have a little farm, to farm item you need and a trailrider safari mission, this feature is quite important because it helping you to find some material or item you need.
There's a lot features in this game if you finish your main quest.
For now I still doing the side quest to upgrade my gears.

Solo, Co-op with your friend or stranger it doesn't matter, this game is worth every penny.

It's pretty entertaining. Some elements in this game that i like: upgrading the base through quests, fighting challenging monsters to get better gear to fight tougher monsters to get better gear...  I like the voice acting, i like the art style and the music and the zones are great.  Really the only criticism that i have is the combat.  The monsters move nice, and have a great move set, but anything the player does seems to be 1.5x slower than it  needs to be.  Got poisoned and need to take an antidote? gotta chug and wait what feels like 30 sec and hopefully slow walk around the enemies attack.  Potions as well.  Using weapons is your character identity.  If it feels like an absolute chore trying to attack the target then try a different weapon.  It's a 8/10 for me.

Monster Hunter World and its highly acclaimed Iceborne expansion have captivated players worldwide with their rich ecosystems, challenging monsters, and deep gameplay mechanics. As someone who has invested 200 hours into this expansive universe, I can confidently say that the experience is nothing short of extraordinary.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2539562247
First and foremost, Monster Hunter World's core gameplay mechanics are great. The thrill of the hunt is unparalleled, with each encounter requiring strategic planning, precise timing, and mastery of your chosen weapon. The game does an excellent job of making each weapon class feel unique, allowing players to find their preferred playstyle. In 200 hours, I've experimented with various weapons, each providing a distinct and gratifying combat experience.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2540681528
The world design is awe-inspiring. From the dense jungles of the Ancient Forest to the frigid landscapes of the Hoarfrost Reach in Iceborne, each locale is beautifully crafted, creating an immersive environment. The diverse range of monsters inhabiting these regions ensures that no two hunts feel the same, constantly keeping the experience fresh and exciting.

The progression system is well-balanced, rewarding players with new gear and abilities as they tackle more formidable foes. The satisfaction of taking down a colossal monster and crafting its armor and weapons is immensely gratifying. The crafting system itself is robust, promoting experimentation and customization to suit individual playstyles.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2539562345
Iceborne, the substantial expansion to Monster Hunter World, elevates the experience to new heights. The addition of the Master Rank, a host of challenging monsters, and the Hoarfrost Reach region extends the game's longevity significantly. The expansion seamlessly integrates with the base game, providing a cohesive and expansive adventure that builds upon the already solid foundation.

Despite the overwhelmingly positive experience, the learning curve can be steep for newcomers, and the sheer volume of content may initially seem overwhelming. However, the game's community is welcoming, and numerous resources are available to assist players in mastering the mechanics.

I've only scratched the surface of what Monster Hunter World and Iceborne have to offer. The continuous updates, events, and the promise of new monsters ensure that the game remains engaging and ever-evolving. Whether you're a seasoned hunter or a newcomer looking for a challenging and rewarding experience, Monster Hunter World and Iceborne stand as a testament to the excellence of the action RPG genre. It's a journey well worth undertaking, and I look forward to many more hours in the captivating world of monster hunting.
It's amazing, deep, challenging but rewarding, a truly perfect gaming experience.

Lots of weapons to try (currently trying Charge Blade), cool world and unique monsters to hunt. This game is very new player friendly, like myself, but has a high skill ceiling. Pick it up and you won't be able to put it down!

I am a veteran player of Monster Hunter, played since 4u and combined to all games I've played (3u, 4u, gen/GU, and world/IB) I have more than 5k hours of total playtime. This shows how much I love the series, and I care for it deeply.

I can understand why Capcom doesn't like cheating, as I've seen it first hand how bad it got in 4u with custom quest. BUT...

Modding is not cheating, it's NOT one and the same. Mods like custom quest (if it's balanced atleast), custom monsters, performance mods, and visual mods aren't cheating. As they only improve the player experience to those that use them (and it's a matter of choice if anyone wants to use them)

The only mods that can be considered cheating are those that change the crit values, material drop, jewel drop, and more. (I'd even say the Guardian armor that Base Iceborn give to the player, By Capcom is cheating) As it changes game values in order to speedup progression/better equipment.

Don't get us wrong, the majority of us players doesn't like cheater as well. But that doesn't mean everyone who uses mods should be affected.

For me, as someone with a barely passable laptop (minimum pc requirements). I could only run MHW:IB barely in 30 fps with even screen stutters. So a performance mod is essential, as it makes the game playable and run smoothly in 30fps. (NEVER in my mind that I would use a mod to speedup my progression in any way, as I don't like it just like everyone else)

Those mods doesn't affect other players in multiplayer, as they only affect what the game looks to me. So the graphic card can atleast handle the visual load.

Now if Enigma is going to be added in the game, forget players like me running the game barely. As the game will probably become a slideshow and if i EVER go to the ancient forest with Enigma installed... I'm pretty sure my laptop wouldn't handle it. And those that uses mods for fun new quest and challenges are now left in disappointment.

(I though you where better than this Capcom, so disappointed)

I'm giving this game a thumbs-up, although I don't know that I'll ever really play it.

The core mechanic is 3rd-person melee combos. Button-mashing works at first but not for long.  There are a large set of weapons, each of which behaves in very different ways and has different combo patterns. Switching to a different weapon can make the game feel significantly different. There are a wide variety of consumable items -- traps, flingable objects, healing, buffing -- which are essential rather than additional.  Consumables, armor, and weapons are all craftable, using parts you find or strip from monsters.

Each monster has different strengths, weaknesses, attacks, and movement patterns.  I'm told some of the battles can take the better part of an hour.  The game is a grind that rewards patience and careful observation.

A lot of this stuff is thrown at you in a short period, so if you haven't played other Monster Hunter games it's a bit overwhelming.  (Note: some have said this is the *easiest* MH game to get into.)  You can ignore most of it for the first couple of monsters.

Games are tied into online servers, but it's easy to play solo.

The bottom line is that this isn't something you just pick up and casually slip into.

Found this game years ago on PS4 through catching a random get good guide on Youtube. It seemed interesting little did i realize it would lead down a very pleasing rabbit hole. The opening experience of trying all the weapons and finding 1 of 14 to really dive into, i settled between two Charge Blade & Switch Axe, so much variety and depth of game play. It was so great to feel myself getting better learning both my weapon and the monsters and how they relate to each other. 500+ Hours I went back in the series to try MHGU and see where the series comes from, the old games still  manage to hold up and have character of their own. The sequel game Rise/Sunbreak was wildly different while i didn't care for it at first that has grown to become one of my favorites in the series. Depending on how satisfying you find hunting the same thing multiple times be it for skill or poor luck on drop you really need. 2000+ Hours in the series now glad to see the resurgence in the community around world and all the more excited to see what comes next in Wilds. Love this game. Tons of weapons and play styles to choose from, the combat is amazing, and the weapon and armor designs are some of the best out there. The Iceborne DLC feels like a completely new game, and there's always more to do. I'll convince you to buy this game right now: CATS. they cook your food, you can take them on hunts, you can dress them up like mega man for some reason, and they'll do a little happy dance when you complete a quest. Just a top tier game all around. Although, with that being said, there is usually a lot of grinding at the endgame. Sometimes you'll have to look up if the monster even drops the material you're looking for because it's been 20 hunts without the mantle you need for your new favorite hat. But that (hopefully) won't stop you from enjoying the game to the fullest, because it's truly an amazing game.

So I clearly have a love-hate relationship with this series. Despite the amount of hours I have put into this game and Rise, whenever I play sessions of the game I normally didn't enjoy playing it and just get pushing through due to suck cost fallacy. 
The concept of the series sounds amazing, hunt giant monsters, either by yourself or with friends, with weapons you have created from your previous victories. For me the experience of fighting these monsters had diminishing returns quite quickly.
I am well aware that there are some people that really enjoy this game and I understand how people can get great enjoyment out of this game. I didn't enjoy having to spend around 30 minutes hunting a monster to then not get the materials I needed, which means I would have to spend 30 minutes hunting the same monster. I didn't enjoy getting hit by a monster, getting stunned, getting hit again, becoming paralyzed, getting hit again, and then dying. Or maybe I should not have tried to play the entire game as a support hunting horn ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø. 

So if you are interested in the game and love grinding, min-maxing, and doing excessive amount of research then this might be the game for you. If you don't really enjoy one of those aspects this game will become a chore to play.

EDIT: 1/15/2024

I have done more research on the topic of Capcom and their DRM additions. That, I have found in all I could pull up, to be not true.

Capcom did not and has not retroactively added DRM to their old titles, and it was simply a snap assumption from people that seemed very believable, this including myself.

My recommendation of this game will now reflect how I feel about the game instead of Capcom as a publisher.

EDIT: 1/14/2024

I have recently seen reports that Capcom did NOT add DRM to their older titles as a reaction to recent modding situations. It would appear that the DRM had been there for over a year.

That being said, I am no authority on the topic. I will edit my review to positive once I am certain I know what Capcom will do going forward.
----------------------Recommendation

Monster Hunter World is an incredible experience. From start to finish, the gameplay loop is polished to a mirror sheen from over a decade of iterations.

The game is a blast with friends, or alone. It's a huge boss rush with light RPG elements.

Smash monsters, wear their skin, make a sword from their hip-bone. Do it to the next dragon that even looks in your direction.

This is Monster Hunter, and it's one of my favorite franchises of all time.

Play World as your first MH game.  Get through the main missions by the skin of your teeth with a terrible build (or 0 build) and with the help of strangers.  

Play Rise as your second MH game, get way too used to wirebugs and snappier combat, get all but 6 achievements, face your fears; actually learn what your armor skills do.

Come back to World with more knowledge of skills, gems, decorations, weapon synergy, and maybe with some cool hunting friends.  

[h1]Bully monsters.  FEEL POWERFUL.[/h1]

That's it, that's the review.

P.S.: [strike]Worst thing is unskippable cutscenes, frfr.[/strike]  
P.P.S.: I both get and don't get the clutch claw hate -- like it does seem like some of the early fights throughout World are trivialized.  But also, it adds another element to combat.  If you don't like the clutch claw, you are free to never use it.  IN FACT, the first time I played the game, even all the way through ICEBORNE, I didn't use it.  A kind player showed me how to "wall-bang" a rajang in the Guiding Lands and I fell in love with it.  Clutch Claw [i]best[/i] bully tool.

There is a reason why Monster Hunter World is Capcoms best selling game and why now in 2023 and 2024 it's now making a comeback.


With beautiful immersive environments and an ecosystem of bizarre but believable creatures, Monster Hunter has never before looked so stunning.


The combat feels so fluid and enjoyable to play. With a variety of different weapons to master, each featuring their own set of tactics and combo's to master, there's something to suit everyone no matter your play style.


Fights can be intense and keep your on your toes, starting very forgiving at first but as you play deeper and deeper, the difficulty ramps up and punishes you hard should you dare slip up and make a mistake.


With the addition of the Iceborne DLC this game becomes twice as big boasting a roster of over 70 monsters.

Monster Hunter World is an amazing Game and by far the best looking rendition of the Monster Hunter Franchise while also being the best for newcomers or players who where detered by older games.

While it makes great use of high end graphics, it also elevates the rather slow and sluggish gameplay from former Monster Hunter games by smoothing overall gameplay and introducing many new mechanics and movement options.

Where the game truly shines though is the Iceborne DLC. It adds many classic monster from previous entries and also increases the difficulty, while giving access to an imense amount of even more equipment.

I bought MHW on sale a while back and I can honestly say that it is still the best purchase I've ever made on Steam. I'm new to the franchise and this game really is a great place to get started. The game is extremely detailed and after 300+ hours I'm still learning more about the monsters tells and how to prepare for some of the trips into the new world. The game is great if you are looking for game that forces you to learn how to play it with little hand holding, asymmetric fights (not just boss fights), an enjoyable/repeatable gameplay loop and a truly great community of players. With the Iceborne expansion right around the corner, with new monsters, new weapon abilities, new areas and a new story I can't recommend this game enough.

Update 800 hours later......

I recently began noticing consistent frame drops in various areas of the game, primarily the hoarfrost reach and rotten vale... I have not had any issues like this until the last week and I also noticed that the weapon on my characters back twitches uncontrollably from time to time. I started looking into what could be causing this and saw that capcom has added (or maybe plans to add? Dunno, there arent alot of specifics) a particularly intrusive DRM software to the game. Reports seem to indicate that this software (or malware depending on who you ask) can and will cut frame rates significantly. I struggle to understand why capcom would do something like this to a game that came out the better part of 6 years ago... I had been really excited to get back into the game again after the announcement of wilds, but this unwelcome addition to the game as well as the absolutely awful switch port that was Rise, I don't know that I can support capcom anymore... I honestly never thought I'd think that.

[strike] And, sadly, I am here, revising my review for the third and final time. I attempted to give Capcom a fair opportunity to address the many glaring problems with Iceborne, but this Safi'jiiva update is the final straw. Capcom is still sneaking around with its buffoonish attempts to terrorize modders and punish game pirates - and all they have accomplished is breaking a game which SHOULD be able to launch and load at this point. I wish Iceborne had never happened. I would give my right eye and Silver Rathalos GS up to just go back to the good, old days of fighting ATKT and Lunastra. Avoid this cancerous DLC and its idiotic developers who can't drop a single update without breaking things. I am done trying to see the good here, this game is a joke and a disaster! Crapcom, really... WTF?

Edit:
I am finally changing my review of this game to a cautious thumbs-up because Crapcom appears to have at last stopped touching it and breaking everything with constant updates. Absurd CPU usage was never fixed by Crapcom. Issues with constant dc in multiplayer hunts were never fixed. Hilariously bad weapon balancing (looking at you, sticky noobs) was never dealt with. But the game is - tolerable in that it can finally be run with half decent fps (through the use of mods that correct Capcom's faulty coding). Buy it on sale if anything, and get with the Iceborne expansion. Base game isn't worth much by itself. What a sad and depressing end to what could have been a GOAT, but instead ended up being a ruby in a dung pile. It shines brightly and gives incredibly awesome moments - when it isn't bogged down by its horrible performance issues, terrible pacing, and constant dc's in the middle of hunts. [/strike]

Pros: The game (specifically the combat) feels great once the first few hours of the overwhelming new player experience passes. I've only used long sword so far, but the other weapons seem interesting and I look forward to trying them. 

Cons: The new player experience is overwhelming, although it is understandable and reasonable. My main gripe with this game is with the party system being convoluted and unintuitive. I originally played the game on XBOX when it came out. I was literally absorbed by the game, but never managed to be patient enough for the DLC. Now I got the game back on PC, and even before I reached DLC content, the game has changed so much, so many cool new features and it's still as immersive as ever, with even better graphics and a still amazing storyline. I'm very impatient to get into the ICEBORNE DLC! Amazing game! I love MH:RISE, but there's nothing like the graphics and story of MH:WORLD. A very intuitive game, and an even better game if you like to create various builds/play types depending on the situations.

I liked base world a lot, with the methodical combat and all. Only things I didn't like were RNG decorations (so it could take HUNDREDS OF HOURS to have a good supply of necessary gems) and the monsters were kind of samey until you got to the elder dragons. 
Iceborne, however, is terrible, and so are its changes to the base game in turn. Clutch claw is an awful tool that completely breaks the flow of normal gameplay, and you are forced to use it due to the increased hardness all monsters have so unless you "soften" them with the clutch claw your weapons are going to bounce all the time or do fuck all damage, refusing to do this can add up to twice the amount of time to a hunt depending on the monster and their hitzones. On top of this the devs added a specific stagger that has a change to roll for all stagger where the monster moves away and stands there like a dumbass waiting for you to use the clutch claw because they couldn't design monsters to organically provide openings for their garbage mechanic, and LR+HR monsters got this crappy stagger too which retroactively fucks with those early hunts. They also didn't bring up lance at all going into Iceborne making it quite a garbage weapon compared to all the other options on offer, which was a particularly frustrating experience for me as a lance player. The new monster variety is nice and FINALLY adding layered armor for most sets is nice (though it's behind the guiding lands lol so have fun going through the story looking like a dunce). The new monster variety is very welcome, but not at the cost of all this crap. They also added the Guardian set to the game, a set of end-of-High-rank tier armor and super strong weaponry that lets you completely clown on the main story and the high rank content in order to rush to MR stuff, but lets you skip that learning curve in turn resulting in a bunch of baddies in MR who got carried by the MH equivalent of the Drake Sword and cheat armor, have fun with your multiplayer hunts getting dragged down by those people. 
Basically, I don't like MHW because of the changes Iceborne brought. It's still an okay game, but it's not the game I originally loved and paid for, and thus don't recommend it. If you're going to play it anyway, my advice is break out Cheat Engine and just spawn yourself a few of every decoration in the game so you don't have to put up with the shitty RNG gem grind, maybe do it after you get through HR so you can at least understand why I hate that system. I'll take Rise's RNG charms any day over RNG decos. 

On top of this, Capcom are being a bunch of idiots and trying to stop modding because they want to sell you their crappy cosmetic DLC and stuff like char. changing passes THAT SHOULD BE IN-GAME FEATURES BY DEFAULT. And they're doing it by adding a crappy Russian DRM made by a malware company to all their older titles, though only a few are affected right now it's only a matter of time until such reaches this game and future releases. Dragon's Dogma 2 is the final product I'll ever buy from capcom after this stunt. And I don't recommend any of their products in general if they continue down this path.

Graphics and Design:
Monster Hunter World is visually stunning, with lush environments, detailed monsters, and vibrant landscapes. The design of both creatures and environments contributes to a rich and immersive gaming experience. The game takes full advantage of current-gen hardware to deliver breathtaking visuals.

Gameplay:
The core of Monster Hunter World revolves around the exhilarating gameplay loop of hunting massive monsters, collecting resources, and crafting gear. The combat is deep and rewarding, requiring skill, strategy, and knowledge of your prey. The addition of seamless zones and a more dynamic ecosystem enhances the overall hunting experience.

World and Exploration:
The game features interconnected zones, creating a living, breathing world filled with diverse ecosystems. The ability to track monsters, gather resources, and explore seamlessly adds a layer of immersion. Each location feels unique, with its own set of challenges and wildlife.

Multiplayer:
Monster Hunter World excels in cooperative multiplayer. Players can team up to take down formidable monsters, leading to dynamic and strategic battles. The multiplayer experience is seamless, and the game encourages teamwork through its cooperative mechanics.

Story and Progression:
While the story isn't the main focus, Monster Hunter World introduces a more narrative-driven experience compared to previous titles in the series. The plot serves as a backdrop to the overarching goal of hunting monsters and uncovering the mysteries of the New World. The progression system is well-balanced, with a variety of quests and challenges to keep players engaged.

Weapon Variety:
One of the strengths of Monster Hunter World is its diverse array of weapons, each with a unique playstyle. Finding the weapon that suits your preferences adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, ensuring that players can tailor their experience to their preferred combat style.

Post-launch Support:
Capcom has consistently supported the game with post-launch content, including new monsters, events, and collaborations. This ongoing support has kept the player base engaged and excited about the game.

Conclusion:
Monster Hunter World successfully revitalized the Monster Hunter series, bringing it to a broader audience while maintaining the depth and complexity that fans love. With its captivating visuals, engaging gameplay, and robust multiplayer, Monster Hunter World stands as a standout title in the action RPG genre.

This game is great.  5 years after launch and its' still an excellent experience.  The multiplayer servers are populated.  There are plenty of people to play with.

My only criticism?  The  new player experience is pretty tough.  This game just drops you in the middle of a thicket of complicated systems and barely exerts any effort into teaching them to you.  I mean I've played hundreds of hours of MH Rise and now about 40 hours of World and there are still things I don't really understand.  Of course that's part of the fun of hte game; I just wish it did a better job of making it accessible to people.

Capcom is trying to address this issue by giving new player "Defender" gear.  This is a double edged sword because on the one hand while it does make the game a lot easier, it also removes any incentive to engage with a lot of the game's systems.  What's the point of crafting anything new when your starter gear is more than good enough to finish the story?  New players are getting a truncated experience.  Instead of the hunt-gather-craft loop they can just hunt and hunt and hunt without having to engage with any of those systems at all.  You never lose a hunt because your gear sucks, study the monster, study it's elemental resistances, it's weak spots, strategize, figure a new build out, systematically gather the materials, craft what you need and come back and kick that monster's butt.  This is such a core partof the Monster Hunter experience and it's not here now because of the defender gear.

The game's graphics are impressive, creating vibrant and diverse ecosystems for players to explore while hunting monsters. Each location feels alive and serves as a breathtaking backdrop for your epic battles.

MHW boasts a fantastic lineup of monsters, each with unique behaviors and attack patterns. Taking down these creatures requires strategy and skill, making every hunt intense and satisfying.

A standout feature of MHW is its seamless online multiplayer. Hunting with friends is a blast, adding a sense of camaraderie as you take on formidable monsters together. The game's multiplayer functionality is well-executed and enhances the overall experience.

Customization is a key aspect, with a robust crafting system allowing players to create various weapons and armor. Experimenting with different loadouts adds depth and strategy to the gameplay.

The progression system strikes a good balance, offering challenges without feeling overly grindy. Completing quests earns materials for crafting better gear, leading to a satisfying sense of accomplishment.

While MHW is a triumph, it does have a learning curve, especially for newcomers. The story, though serviceable, takes a backseat to the thrill of the hunts.

In summary, Monster Hunter World is a must-play title for its stunning visuals, diverse monsters, seamless multiplayer, and deep customization options. Whether you're a seasoned hunter or new to the series, MHW promises countless hours of thrilling monster-slaying fun.

Game is fun. You can hear the good stuff in other reviews, I give it 9/10. But I have a few issues...

Monsters aren't really a threat, when they attack you, they only really do it once before stopping. The amount of times where I would've had died if the monster continued the attack but decided to stop is staggering. Hitboxes are also pretty bad, but thats a given considering its monster hunter. 

I don't understand some parts, why would a monster cause me to stumble and not attack me afterwards when I am defenceless. Or why would the monster grab me and throw me on the ground so I am stuck prone, and just watch me without capitalising on the opportunity to kill me. People talk about how this game simulates an ecosystem and all that jazz. But this game really struggles with making the monsters actually seem like they have a brain.

I've had moments where the monster gets me in a certain kill combo, but right before the killing move, it decides to just run away. Really immersion killing. They fixed this in Rise, where monsters are actually a threat, probably cause they made the player more OP, so they had to balance it with the monsters, but that's another game.

Another issue I have with World is that the hiding in bush mechanic doesn't really work all that well, if you want to hide from a large monster you have to sit there for a few minutes, in comparison, you can lose threat if you were to just run away for 30 seconds. There is no real incentive to hide in comparison to just running away.

Another issue is with the resources, you practically have infinite resources with access to the camp chest. If you are properly prepared, then you will never run out of potions, this is something I wish they would fix in the new upcoming game Monster Hunter Wilds. I've heard the older generation games are a lot more stringent on the resources you get.

Hope Wilds is able to make the monsters more threatening, rather than the World state, where you can really only die to a one hit kill attack.

Love everything else, though I've heard that Capcom is implementing a DRM on all their games, which will just make everything shittier. Can't really do anything about that though.

One of the best role playing games ever made. Stylistically gorgeous, with a believable living ecosystem, stylish artistic design and a five star full orchestral soundtrack.

If you know nothing about Monster Hunter as a franchise, don't worry, there is no need to have existing game knowledge to come into and play MH:W and enjoy it. The game starts you off fairly slowly and eases you into things, but make no mistake: this game can be fiendishly difficult and has a truly staggering amount of both gameplay depth, mechanical depth and complexity. As far as I'm concerned, there are two facets to the general gameplay loop: fighting the monsters, and upgrading your gear. Both are tuned to perfection. Creating your build is like a puzzle, choosing the best pieces of armor and fitting gems into all the slots to create the balance of skills that you prefer is extremely satisfying. Obtaining all of those things is arguably more satisfying. Monster movesets are all unique and fun at some level, and each weapon is complicated and satisfying in their own way. Combining them in a confrontation makes for extremely varied and fun combat. This is good, because when you think about how many times you need to fight a specific monster for a specific material needed for a specific piece of equipment for a specific level of a specific skill, multiply that by however many materials you need for that piece of equipment, then multiply that by six, then multiply THAT by however many playstyles you like for your weapon, then multiply THAT by fourteen, and "Infinite content" starts sounding pretty reasonable. 10/10.

Capcom has recently begun a campaign of adding a certain DRM to their older games, whether singleplayer or multiplayer, in order to curb mod use. There's no doubt in my mind that this will either be overturned or cracked, but this particular software is served by a company with no name or address, with the only clue being that their domain was bought in Moscow. I'm going to leave this review here until someone personally provides proof that this decision by Capcom is publicly apologized for and walked back, because even if they did want to be hard on mods, they ought to know their vendors. I'm uninstalling this game before the malware reaches my computer.

I've been playing Monster Hunter since 2014. Probably not gonna stop anytime soon. Happy to see that people are getting back into World. It is an amazing game with so much content to get into. Each weapon feels intuitive and truly like a tool that requires the time and dedication needed to master it.

What I love about Monster Hunter is that it is truly a game that is about taking on danger head-on. And while World definitely feels like you're on training wheels in the beginning (which can be frustrating at times) once it takes them off, it truly is a game that relies on the skill of the player. It's you that has become a better player. Maybe at first, you got tossed around and couldn't complete a quest without carting once or twice, but eventually, you'll find yourself able to react better and finish quests faster. It teaches you that it's okay to fail because you can always dust yourself off and try again. The time that you put into the game is rewarded, and that's what I love.

There are definitely gripes I have with the game. [spoiler]Tempered monsters were a great addition to give hunters a challenge and incentivize players to do it due to the awards tied to it. However, I feel that it wasn't as balanced as many can attest to on YouTube. Arch-Tempered Monsters being the largest offenders.[/spoiler]

What can also be frustrating is when players are faced with quests with huge spikes in difficulty, causing players to hit a wall as they desperately try to figure out how to fight the damn thing. This is generally common throughout most Monster Hunter games, having an almost unanimously hated monster. While it can be ignored at times, some weapons require that players fight these frustrating monsters to complete certain builds. It can be dreadful to feel helpless as you face them down only to get carted and fail the quest. Of course, with time, you can create a strategy on how to fight them; however, it never becomes a fun experience.

Another point where I think it falls short is in terms of decorations. These are items that are meant to boost certain stats to help complete a build, but when trying to get the specific jewel you wanted (Attack and Critical Chance jewels) becomes a gamble you have to pray for, it can get old very quickly. You could spend tens of hours doing the best quest for that chance and still never get the gem you want (I do want to say that maybe that has changed somewhat as event quests can help in getting rare material. However, I'm starting on a new save and haven't had the need to farm for jewels yet).

Other than that, there are very minor things that I can complain about, but I don't feel that they are important overall. This just might be a love letter to the game series, but I do feel that Monster Hunter World, including the Iceborne DLC, is a unique and immersive experience that will stick with you for the rest of your life. There will never be a game truly like Monster Hunter no matter how hard others may try.

Hopefully this review was helpful. This is the first time I've ever typed a review this long.

[h1] Monster Hunter World: Where Hunt Meets Hilarity! [/h1]

Ladies and gentlemen, gather 'round as I regale you with a tale of a game that's so monstrously fantastic, it's bound to make your heart race faster than an Anjanath (T-rex looking chicken..it has wings) in hot pursuit of a herbivore buffet! I'm talking about none other than "Monster Hunter World," the game that proves that hunting gigantic creatures can be as fun as it is ferocious.

Picture this: You, a fearless hunter armed with weapons that could make even Rambo jealous, embark on a quest to slay the most colossal, fearsome, and downright hangry monsters in the land. But fear not, for "Monster Hunter World" isn't just about swinging swords and launching projectiles at overgrown lizards ‚Äì it's about creating memories that'll have you chuckling long after you've vanquished your prey.

The game's humor isn't just about puns (though there are plenty of those, like "Why did the Rathalos bring a ladder to the hunt? Because it wanted to go to new heights!"). It's about the joy of teaming up with friends to chase down beasts that make King Kong look like a toddler throwing a tantrum. Ever seen a group of hunters chase a giggling, fire-breathing Tobi-Kadachi through the jungle like a bunch of Benny Hill characters? It's like a comedy of errors, except with more teeth and scales.

And let's not forget the feline sidekicks, the Palicoes. These little furballs will have you in stitches with their antics. Imagine them donning costumes that are straight out of a cat fashion show, wielding weapons, and assisting you in the most hilarious ways possible. They're the real stars of the show, and they're purr-fectly adorable.

But it's not all laughs and guffaws. "Monster Hunter World" offers a deep and rewarding gameplay experience. The satisfaction of bringing down a massive beast after an epic battle is unparalleled. It's like taking a rollercoaster ride through a fireworks display while riding a unicycle ‚Äì you'll feel like a legend.

So, in conclusion, "Monster Hunter World" isn't just a game; it's a comedy club, an action movie, and an adventure of epic proportions all rolled into one. If you're looking for a game that combines laughter and exhilaration like a mad scientist concocting a potion, then grab your hunting gear and dive into this monster-sized masterpiece. It's an absolute scream ‚Äì literally!
