I have 1500+ hours on PS4 (non-pro). This review will mostly cover PC-port issues, including Iceborne.

IMPORTANT: Master Edition on sale is the cheapest option.

2024:
Crapcom started added a virus into all their games that kills FPS and prevents visual mods, b/c they're "cheating".

Oct 2023:
Useless update broke official 4k textures. Fixed after a week.
Many report new crashes, freezes, stutters.

Oct 2021:
They removed Denuvo.
Still crashes sometimes, dunno why.
Dunno if other issues fixed or not.

Apr 2020:
Loading much slower, even on SSD.
MORE ANTI-MOD. Some can't use Reshade anymore.
Random Err12 crash.
DX12 randomly locks PC since 4 patches ago, requiring reboot.
Took 2 weeks to fix MHW triggering anti-virus.
Still very laggy, even on powerful PCs.
Still unstable online that makes raid events impossible to clear.

Jan 2020:
Iceborne breaks everything. Crashes, freezes, save corruption, anti-mod, very laggy anti-cheat.

Oct 2019:
In May, I upgraded from GTX 970 to 1660ti and got ~50+ FPS on the title screen, but I still got the same old ~45-50 FPS in-game, regardless of graphical settings.

Non-Denuvo DMC5 proved that Denuvo limits video card by bottlenecking CPU. Up to 20% performance hit. I later upgraded to a new CPU, same video card. Now MHW runs smooth as silk.

PC Iceborne came out way too late. On PS4 they've finally started dripfeeding 2 year old fashion armors, despite being fully implemented from the beginning. They know it's always been the most requested feature.

Quick summary:
Not a terrible port, but has extremely terrible CPU optimization. You need a powerful video card to use the high-res texture pack, otherwise many textures are very low-res. But it's still superior to console because of higher fps, much faster loading, and mods.

I can't recommend a game with major issues that shouldn't exist. I'd be annoyed if people recommended me a game and it didn't work properly. So I'm not going to do that. I paid for this game, I want them to fix it. Years later, still many unfixed issues.

Major issues (STILL relevant as of December 2019):
- Stuttering on any kind of input. Capcom has only very recently acknowledged this and are finally looking into it. AFAIK not fixed.
- Special K author Kaldaien says the game has worst ever CPU & Denuvo usage. Iceborne also has Denuvo. Early reviews suggest it still runs like crap because of this.
- Blocky skin in cutscenes. This problem exists on PS4 Iceborne, too. STILL.
- Still lacks disable bloom option.

Fixed issues:
- Keyboard settings error and "can't save game" error occurs if you store your backup files in the same folder as the other save games. If you move them out, both problems stop.
- You can now see friend sessions even if private, and join friend sessions easily.
- There is now an official high resolution texture pack. Almost a year late.
- Newer Nvidia drivers fixed the huge MHW frame drops.
- Effect huge frame-drops fixed.
- Online disconnection issues seemingly fixed.
- Mouse and keyboard supported.
- After months, they finally added disable DOF and Motion Blur. DOF is still forced on during cutscenes.

Unconfirmed past issues:
- Not sure if clientside can still cause all session players to disconnect via mods.
- Months ago there were reports of crashes on startup caused by Steam Overlay, GeForce Exp, Ansel, Reshade. No idea if fixed.
- Some reports of getting randomly locked out for a day after an update, due to Denuvo.
- There were reports of the Taroth event having crash/freeze issues. Probably fixed.
- Very, very rare bugs (sheath bug, infinite machinegun sound, cannot interact with anything and have to restart).
- All versions of this game reportedly have a small chance of corrupting savedata or refusing to save. So you should try to backup regularly.

PC port positives:
- Loads MUCH faster than the PS4 version, even without an SSD. PS4 takes a minute or two. This loads in a few seconds, presumably if you have enough RAM.
- Looks nice, when it runs properly.
- Minor improvements to the GUI over the PS4 version, which were added to PS4 Iceborne.
- Modding. Now you too can easily wear the tons of NPC-only outfits Capcom keeps making. On top of fixing tons and tons of other issues.
- Several graphic options have a "variable" setting that auto-adjusts graphic options in realtime. Some are noticeable, some not so.
- Gamepad support and key config via Steam Big Picture. I've heard there are limitations.
- Option to configure confirmation and cancel buttons (fixes the Asia vs West button swap problem).

Conclusion:
It's pretty obvious Capcom didn't test the PC version enough. Yet they saw fit to give early access to streamers and reviewers, who (as far as i'm aware) did not seem to notice any of these significant issues. Next time, get real testers to test your game.

It took them a long time to admit to and fix many of the problems. CPU optimization (ie. Denuvo) is still so bad that it can seriously impact the frame rate. 

Outside of the ongoing major issues, I think you'd still need to have a clear understanding of what the Monster Hunter games are like. I get the impression many people jump into this game expecting it to be something totally different, and end up disappointed.

As a game, it feels like just barely enough content. By endgame you'll realize it's stretched thin, with heavy reliance on RNG in endgame. It's designed in such a way that you end up fighting the same few monsters over and over until you get burned out.

There are some things that are done well, and several things where it feels like they dropped the ball, or are seriously trying to troll customers by doing the opposite of what everybody wants (no joke...for example, despite players complaining about this for almost a year, they keep adding exclusive outfits and hairstyles for NPCs, despite NPCS and players sharing the same models).

That being said, if you do enjoy the core combat, then you may end up playing this for a long time. I won't go into detail about the gameplay in this review, but I will say that if you just want something to spend 30+ hours on (rough minimum time to complete story) and you don't mind RELATIVELY "clunky" (ie. compared to what people normally expect) high-risk controls where you cannot rely on lock-on, then you may want to give this game a try.

If you want to try it first, and maybe refund it, then be careful not to spend too much time on character creation. Just use a preset, get past the unskippable lengthy intro, and jump into training room to try out the weapons. This is a game that relies very heavily on whether you like how the weapons and combat feels. If you don't, you won't enjoy this game.

Also note that this game is easier in solo. Multiplayer has a high chance of people screwing up, resulting in quest failure. Monsters can chain multiple attacks to kill you off a single hit. This happens often when you're learning the game. You're supposed to try not to get hit. Three deaths means restarting the quest. If that sounds frustrating to you, you may want to avoid this game.

Part of the fun is overcoming these challenges. Once you learn the monster patterns and how to use the weapons effectively, it can be a satisfying experience.

UPDATE: Iceborne actually fixes many of these issues. Monsters are less cheap and give you more breathing space in Iceborne. So again, you should probably wait for Iceborne before buying the PC version.

By the way, I'm not a veteran of the franchise. This is the first Monster Hunter game that I've fully invested into. From what I've seen others say, compared to previous games, this one is a few steps forward (eg. much better audio/visual, easier to obtain crafting materials, weapon improvements), and a few steps back (eg. less monster variation, story/setting too "casual", annoying NPCs, poor fashion support, lack of things to do in endgame, reliance on limited-time events). Also, you can't do events offline, unless you mod the game.

Great game had a ton of fun with it on ps4 and liked seeing it on sale and getting so much traction.  I never played Iceborn.  The game is great in so many ways, but playing it again I see a lot of re-skinned monsters, the tedious nature of fighting the same monster with different number values makes for a rather boring game at times, especially the end-game.

I used to think it had such a good endgame with a grind that was satisfying and after playing again, this is not the case.  The base MHW game is seriously lacking for content after 40-60 hours, arch tempered monsters are pretty poorly designed and gated behind gear.  The average person isn't going to clear these monsters with their weapon in build in most cases, and it doesn't matter since the fights are the same unreasonable Health/damage values and zero changes to fight animations.  I think the major problem is the health values just make it so tedious, with the exception of xeno'jiva being one that I still remember as fun and different.   I see why I stopped playing before Iceborn ever was released.  Great game, has some re-skin flaws, but not too bad, except when you get to some tempered/arch-tempered versions the game is terrible.  I assume just move on to Iceborn at that point, and that the expansion has much more fun and a healthier endgame.
DRM is trash and so is CAPCOM, shame on you, such a disappointment for a company that had such a high resurgence in recent years

The base game was excellent, up to the point where 9 out of 10 encounters were designed by a moron that hates fun and has no idea what they are doing. It quickly becomes tedious and infuriating, even if you clear an encounter. They stop being fun and start being like trying to wrestle an oiled up crack head in a bouncy castle.

The iceborne dlc should've seen everyone who worked on it blacklisted from the industry for how it made everything bad much much much worse, and improved nothing.

I'd like to recommend it, but there's a huge pile of very bad design decisions that exist at such a fundamental level you'd have to remake the entire game to fix them. Most of them aren't really obviously terrible decisions until you reach the very poorly designed encounters that litter the late base game and entire iceborne dlc.

Some examples:
-Dodges have essentially no iframes, it's like 5 frames. Most attacks are triple that in duration and have after effects that linger.
-Your character moves clunkily and with no sense of urgency ever, every consumable is used at a glacial pace. 
-More animations than not are locked-in, you cant interrupt or get out of them.
-Most monsters in the late-late base game and entire expansion are fast, spammy encounters with huge health bars.
-Clutch claw and tenderizing, everything about it, especially in iceborne. The design of most encounters makes the openings you need to do it very rare, but you need to do it for the encounters to not take six centuries. It's just bad all around and designed around multiplayer and monsters acting in ways that they didn't design them to act in.
-Decorations are all around just a bad way to do what they were trying to do with them. There are so many mandatory things you need for any given build, some of which basically aren't accessible until the game has gotten to such a point you're nearly done with it.
-Cool/Hot drinks. A mechanic that is mandatory to make an area not suck the life out of you, that adds nothing to the game and exists only as a tax to be in that area. Nothing in the game would change if this wasn't done, other than less wasted time and less annoyance.
-A huge amount of the game wasn't designed to be played solo but you're not going to find players to do either. Event quests, sieges, etc.
-Hitboxes. The monster hitboxes are janky at best, and often you will be hit by things that shouldn't have hit you, combined with the non-existant dodge its at times extremely bad unless you're using certain weapons with guards so you don't have to dodge.
-Food system. Everything about it could be done in any other way and it would be better than it is.
-The mantles and specialized tools kind of feel like they exist to work your way around the bad encounter design, rather than giving you interesting ways to interact with them. They make you immune to effects or what not, which is just a really round about way to give you windows to avoid the bad design rather than anything else.

I could continue, but it's just a pile of janky design that was fun in the base game when the monsters kind of roughly followed the same rules you had to, but as the game goes on, you have these rules and arbitrary limits and the monsters don't anymore.

Some people enjoy it and would disagree, but the issue is enjoying bad design doesn't make that bad design good, it just means you like shit.

They're also adopting an anti-modding stance, and possible DRM additions to prevent that modding. So they're going to make it impossible to mod the game to make it playable. This is the killing blow to an already difficult to reccomend game.

The way I had it described to me was that "You don't like Monster Hunter until you do."

I think that there is a lot that can put someone off of a MH game and that's mostly due to the lack of tutorials or "progression" in a sense.

The progression in this game is getting better gear to fight stronger monsters, and while that is "the game", it's more-so about build management and mastering your weapon of choice. You can play a weapon for 200 hours and all of the sudden realize a cleaner way to hit something mid fight and that is what feels amazing. Once you READ and learn all of the skills and addons for your armor and weapons, it becomes about becoming a COUNTER to your enemy instead of a jack-of-all-trades fighter. 

The story is predictable but enjoyable, and the only real downside to multiple playthroughs is the lack of cutscene skipping. 
The community is funny, and helpful but the wiki will be your best friend. It should practically come installed into this game.

I originally played Monster Hunter on the PSP and did not like it. The game threw too many things at you without good explanations. The first few hunts back in the day were truly "thrown into the fire and figure it out".

The crafting system is awesome. I love that everything is based around you just having to git gut, and not just google "who drops Excalibur".

Monster Hunter World: Iceborne stands as a majestic expansion to the already triumphant Monster Hunter World, offering an arctic expanse teeming with formidable beasts, captivating landscapes, and an avalanche of new challenges for veteran hunters. As a seasoned player with hundreds of hours invested in the base game, Iceborne feels like a magnum opus, seamlessly integrating new content while refining the core experience.

The frozen frontier, Hoarfrost Reach, is a visual masterpiece, showcasing the franchise's evolution in graphical fidelity. The seamless transition from the lush Ancient Forest to the frigid expanses of Hoarfrost Reach is a testament to the game's technical prowess. Each locale is a frozen tableau, breathing life into the monsters that inhabit them. The dynamic weather systems further immerse players in the harsh realities of the icy ecosystem, introducing an element of unpredictability to every hunt.

The expansion's real triumph lies in its creature design. The new subspecies and elder dragons are the epitome of ferocity, pushing even the most seasoned hunters to the brink. Velkhana, the flagship monster, is a crystalline marvel, demonstrating a perfect blend of elegance and lethality. The meticulous attention to detail in their animations and behaviors adds depth to the already diverse bestiary, making each encounter a visceral spectacle.

The Clutch Claw, a new addition to the hunter's arsenal, introduces a layer of strategy and risk-reward mechanics. While it may seem daunting at first, mastering the Clutch Claw elevates the combat experience to new heights, allowing for creative combos and openings to exploit a monster's weaknesses. This nuanced approach to combat underscores the game's commitment to rewarding skill and adaptability.

The Master Rank difficulty curve is a relentless ascent, ensuring that even the most seasoned hunters will find themselves humbled by the challenges that await. This spike in difficulty is not only a testament to the expansion's commitment to providing a true endgame experience but also a nod to the franchise's legacy of pushing players to constantly evolve their hunting tactics.

However, the introduction of the Guiding Lands, while conceptually intriguing, does pose some pacing issues. The constant grind for materials to level up regions can feel like a tedious chore, potentially deterring those who seek a more straightforward progression. Balancing this aspect of the endgame experience could have made the grind more enjoyable without sacrificing its intended purpose.

In conclusion, Monster Hunter World: Iceborne is an opulent celebration of the franchise's rich history, pushing the boundaries of what a Monster Hunter experience can be. The meticulously crafted environments, challenging monsters, and refined mechanics make it a must-have for fans and a compelling invitation for newcomers to join the hunt. While the endgame grind may test one's patience, the sheer satisfaction of conquering the frozen titans of Hoarfrost Reach makes every struggle worthwhile. Embrace the cold, sharpen your blades, and embark on a glacial odyssey that will leave you breathless in both awe and accomplishment.Monster Hunter World: Iceborne stands as a majestic expansion to the already triumphant Monster Hunter World, offering an arctic expanse teeming with formidable beasts, captivating landscapes, and an avalanche of new challenges for veteran hunters. A fun game if not in a rush to speed through the campaign. The cut-scenes in the story CAN NOT BE SKIPPED. Not as forgiving as "Monster Hunter Rise", but more fluid than older entries. Not CO-OP friendly when working on the story or "ASSIGNED" quests. Friends and other players can only join after certain cut-scenes in these quests, mostly monster intros. You can only see other players when in the "GATHERING HUB" unless on a quest. Also, when the servers do eventually shutdown, the "EVENT" quests will become unavailable since they're only playable with an online server unless modded. These quests make up a huge bulk of content with unique awards for most of them as well. Recommend if wanting to try out the series for first time or are more of a solo player AND the game is on sale. DO NOT BUY IF SERVERS ARE SHUTDOWN.

If you haven't played this. It means you're bad.

You're basically Kratos in a way... You look like you're a pretty strong guy/girl, but not kill an elder dragon 10x your size strong... You are a freak of nature, wielding weapons 3 times your weight, made from the carcasses of slain monsters that should be able to kill you just by breathing on you. Yet, some how, these gut wrenching battles last anywhere from 2 minutes to 30+ minutes of teeth clenching, muscle flexing, toe curling, controller breaking fun, screaming at God to let you drink a potion before you get absolutely slam dunked into the core of the world.... (see what I did there)... by a monster that has no other goal but to obliterate every living cell in your body, not leaving even a single atom to your name. 

This is hands down the GREATEST game to ever be developed by the greatest developers to ever walk Earth, CAPCOM. And the only ones that don't agree are the ones who never took the time to actually learn how to play... The ones that require INSTANT progression and a cash shop to let them buy their way to 100% completion.

You can eat, sleep, dance, kill, capture, have an apartment, fish, craft, become a fashion designer, ride monsters, you get a cat that fights with you, sleeps with you, eats with you, dances with you, has matching outfits with you, you can have pets that sit on top of your head while you fight, you can cut off monsters tails, slam them into walls, slam them into other monsters, you can glide across the sky like a squirrel, character customization, and I didn't even mention over 5 thousand mods that allow you to do even more unfathomably fun things making you feel like you're playing an entirely new game, jesus christ are you actually still reading??! BUY THE GAME RIGHT FREAKING NOW, on sale not on sale, ITS WORTH EVERY PENNY. ACTUALLY, ILL BUY IT FOR YOU. EVEN IF THIS GAME WAS FREE I WOULD STILL FIND A WAY TO SEND CAPCOM MONEY FOR THIS ABSOLUTE MASTERPIECE.

Okay first of all, fuck Raging Brachydios. "B-but It's meant to be played multiplayer!" NO, fuck you, whichever awful person came up with this fight I hope your takeouts are cold and your stub your toe till it bleeds. Second of all, I love this game! It's exciting to see how much thought goes into the design and nature of the creatures. I especially love Nergiburger with his World Ender title. The graphics are amazing, the customization- Oh My God the customization!!! You have so many armors to unlock, so many weapons to choose, so much of that 'layered armor goodness' and it all comes for a cost: your time, but don't worry it's totally worth it (unless it's Raging Brachy). You don't always have to play in a team either you can play the game solo too. It's a fun experience for everyone (unless it's Raging Brachy). The main game and Iceborne is exciting, always engaging you from monster to monster. Eventhough end game grind can be strenuous and boring, event quests are always there to give you a little boost. If you want something different and Elden Ring-like yet not as hard (unless it's Raging Brachy) then this game is for you!

8.3/10

in comparison to their sequel, this game have good and bad change to it. 
Since I'm a combat based player, how smooth the combat is are very important to me. and this game's combat in comparison to Rise is really clunky and having a lot questionable shit. 
Start off with the hit box, the hit box of this game is absolutely dogshit, explosions have hitbox way larger than it visual displayed,  dragon's rush have questionable hitbox especially on it's ass and leg position. and there's other weird hitbox. 
Second is the item usage and other weapon arts registration issue. first is item usage, the item consumed is register at the moment you use it, which cause two issue. 1, if the monster attack you in the same moment, the effect will not go off but the item will be used. which is just dumb, looking at other game like dark souls, the item will either not be used or the effect will be go off. 2, the animation of use an item can be cancel, but  result the same issue, effect not go off and item been consumed. this also apply to some weapon art tho that's rarely the case. second issue are the utility, it feels the devs intentionally make some basic mechanics worst so player need to choose between give your damage to compensation for the lack of mechanics, or endure this clunky mechanics and have good damage. 
Third is character's reaction.
Character react to all sort things, roar, tremor, wind, mud etc. it is good to see this amount of detail, but it is too much to a degree that effect the combat smoothness, sometime the character get knock down and just lay on the ground for like 20 sec with hand up for no reason, like what you gonna take a nap in mid of all the chaos? no need for it alright, it's too much, react to roar, tremor and mud seems make sense, but like every movement the monster does the character gonna react to it is really excessive. 
putting all those together, most classes of melee weapon would feel a clunky, slow and lumpy gameplay. 
The combat is the main issue this game have, let's talk about which part this game did well. 
Environment and Monster tracking.
In comparison to Rise, the amount of detail and graphic this game brings are shocking, and you need find tracks to find the monster is also make this game more fitting to it's name. it really feels like in a world hunting for monsters, (if you ignore the crappy combat). Scout flies are great tool point direction and item around the player. 
Story 
Story is top tier story, a great expedition team story, better than the rise one. 
Mechanics
The slingshot mechanics is very different than rise, i'm not sure if i like it, so i put no opinion on that. 
UI 
UI i do pefer rise version, more cleaner and easy to see. world's UI difficult to get start with but get used to over time. 

Overall if you are causal player and really don't care about combat, go ahead it gonna be a great game. but if you are combat orientated player like me, especially coming from dark souls, i would definitely recommend rise over world. the combat just way smoother and better hitbox, get used to rise than come to world would surely make it more comfortable. the big chop off on the score is the combat, other UI etc are small things. I do wish Wilds have combat similar to rise, at least just some improvement on hit box things mentioned above and but other things like world.

Previous Review:
This game is absolutely fantastic and is a blast with friends.
Two things I HIGHLY recommend for all new players.

1. DO NOT USE THE DEFENDER SET. 

This was put in so new players could rush to start Icebourne DLC. But by using this set it will take away from the whole genuine experience (the way the base game was meant to be played). You will miss out on a HUGE part of Monster Hunter's rewarding progression. The crafting, the upgrading, and customizing of equipment and armors. Also, you take away from the challenge of hunting monsters by giving yourself this (Base) endgame set right at the get go.

2. ASAP Try all the different weapon sets (before you even start your first mission).

 Each weapon has a unique playstyle and almost feels like playing a different game. There's many experiences of people who try this game and don't like it, then come back and try a different weapon and absolutely love the game (me included).
(You can do this by accessing the training area. Go to your room, talk to the Housekeeper palico, and access training. You can change between all 14 different weapon sets in the training area.)

I can see my self playing another couple hundred hours easy.
     I was really hesitant with playing this game for the first time. Seeing general game play and mostly clips of fighting the monsters left the game undesired for me at first. The Combat looked really janky and slow. Even now I can still see how newcomers won't be thrilled or convinced at watching game play unless, you show them Turf War sequences or special weapon animations. I was first only interested and gave it a chance because of the cross overs like the Wticher, Devil May Cry, and Final Fantasy. I ended up becoming a big monster hunter fan because of it
    But trust me the combat is really engaging and fun. Also Hunts do take on average 25-40 mins which for a lot of people who haven't played the game say it seems like too much. I will admit there are some monsters where they are little too easy and unengaging. You'll just be sitting there waiting for it to be finished while some are really frustrating and not fun. But there are so many fun monsters to fight once you learn the move set it becomes a dance, each different time you fight it you will be better then the last hunt. you will be able to land your risky moves more consistently. There is also the aspect of using the environment to your advantage. You will be keeping track of your positioning, the monsters positioning while you weave in and out looking for optimal windows while at the same time keeping an eye on environmental advantages you do can go for which help you deal big damage. Turning those 35 minute hunts feel like 5-10 minutes
    Now the clutch claw, alot of people complain about it which I do agree. It feels really janky to aim and shoot it. The clutch claw is a core game play feature which you need to learn. I don't really mind it as its another thing you need to juggle as you hunt a monster keeping you engaged.  
     There are different weapons and each weapon has a solid learning curve. Not only do you got to learn the kit of your weapon but learning the monsters move set allows you to plan and space your attacks meticulously. I spent a good chunk of the game playing Long sword which I found interesting and never boring tru my first 300 hours of the game, then i changed weapons trying different ones. Each weapon makes you approach the same monster differently and figuring how to navigate the fight is where most of the fun in the game is. This alone makes me see myself playing it for another couple hundred hours. As i just enjoy fighting the fun monsters with different weapons. 
    As a guy thats into PVP games like fighting games, Mobas and MMOs I'm not really into strictly only PVE games but this game changed my view on PVE. I never would have imagined my self playing a PVE game for long. but some of the monsters are hard and so well designed. Which I really enjoy helping players when they send out help request signals.  
   There is a lot of hate on how Multiplayer is handled. which is warranted. You cannot start a hunt from the story if both players haven't watched the cut scenes which results in players just waiting idle in different lobbies/instances waiting to exit and rejoin their friend. but outside the story mode hunts you can pretty much join any quest if you have it unlocked.  
   The UI for upgrades and crafting your gear also sucks, they seem to add extra steps while also making it a little confusing for no reason which I feel could have easily been on the same page or menu. 
    Overall, its a game where it shines in its game play, gear progression and obviously, the monster designs.

This may be a hot take: this is hands down the best game CapCom has ever made.

The level of detail that was put into this game is astonishing, and every fight feels different every time. While hunting monsters you can have something called a turf war: when two monsters meet they will sometimes fight each other, and there are special fights for [b]EVERY[/b] monster combination. The amount of time that must've been spent on animating the fights alone is astonishing. You can have one monster picking up another and throwing them around with tremendous force, or you could have two flying monsters brawling in the skies. (There are some really cool ones but I wont say because you should see them for yourself) There are some combinations you will probably never see, and there is still a unique fight for it. 

You're given around 20 weapons to choose from, and each one is unique in some way. There are many hidden mechanics involving weapons that are never told to you and it truly makes you feel like you've mastered the weapon when you figure them out.

If you are considering buying this: please get Iceborne. It is like an entire sequel within the game. It more than doubles the content and provides a ton of endgame replayability. Iceborne is what really sends this game into the S Tier for me.

This was my first Monster Hunter game after watching my friends play the earlier ones in the series.

I bought this over Xmas break with some friends and we never got into a game so hard. Two solid months, each day after work, poof --- gone in a flash. Each zone is gorgeous in their own right, each monster fight have been very fun and some monsters continue to deliver fun fights even after understanding the monsters patterns! Even after a few hundred hours on this game, I've still yet to beat some of the end-game monsters, photos, treasure hunting...so much more to do still!!! 

Beware arch-tempered Velkhana...

Side musings: I have tried Rise when it came out --- I have not gotten the expansion. I preferred World since the fighting in World seems to demand a bit more respect in terms if you read a monster's attack wrong or you charge up your attack at the wrong time, you will get punished. I will say the wire bugs in Rise are nice but kinda make it seem almost too easy compared to fights in World.

This has the worst multiplayer I've ever seen implemented in any game, period. For some unknown reason the game developers couldn't figure out how to let people watch cinematics together, so in order to play any "multiplayer" quest with a cinematic, which is the whole story mind you, you have to each separately load the quest, play through it until you reach the cinematic, then one player has to abandon their quest and join the other player in the middle of a monster fight. Does it spawn you right next to that player? No. You have to run all the way from the starting camp to wherever the other player is on the map, meaning by the time you get there, there is a good chance the monster is already dead. Sounds fun, right?
It's basically if you bought a ticket to a movie with friends but when you went to go into the cinema the usher stopped you and said "Hey no, your friend can go in but you have to watch it in cinema 5. When the movie is halfway done then you can come in here and watch the end... maybe."

There are multiple mechanics in this game that purposefully waste the players time (hours worth). I'm not talking tedious things that are a matter of preference. For example, monsters will constantly run away from you at a speed 5x faster than you. Once you finally catch up, they may just take off again to the other side of the map. It could take 20min to kill a monsters with only 4 min of actual fighting. The absolute worst element of this is that eventually all monsters will just leave the map usually when you're really close to killing them, meaning you get nothing - no reward, just a massive waste of your time. Worse, by engaging the monster in combat for that long you pissed away a massive amount of resources. This game could have been an 8/10, but it's destroyed by developer choices on the upper echelon of stupidity.

This game is a masterpiece. Yes, it has its flaws (like Iceborne making you weaken monster armor parts before they take significant damage, also the endgame grind of Iceborne is pretty soul-crushing), but when taken as a whole, it's a masterpiece and resides firmly in my list of one of the best games of all time.

And that's before you even start messing with mods and making the game even more great. 

Pro tip for any new players: don't listen to anyone about how you want to play. Want to cheese the game with a broken build? Do it! Want to install some mods to make the fights easier? Go for it -- as long as you remember that in any public lobbies you won't have those benefits and can drag a team down if you keep carting due to lack of training wheels. But the actual act of having training wheels is not wrong. Enjoy this beautiful game how you want to enjoy it.

Gameplay wise, I don't think this is necessarily a bad game. 

However, I have never touched a game with a more convoluted and joypadized control scheme in my life. Every button has like 5 different functionalities, there are dozens of commands requiring a double button input, there are about 6 different god forsaken radial menus which also somehow interact with each other, and to top it all off it has the classic Japanese UI that makes absolutely no logical sense whatsoever. I refuse to believe that anyone with an ounce of sanity would ever be able to even come up with this psychopathic scheme. 

Moreover, the game is infested with a ridiculous amount of hand holding. The first time you get sent to do the "exploration" mode, there is an NPC that has you on quick dial (yes, they somehow have phones) and he will endlessly spam you with "OVER HERE! HEY! OVER HERE! OVER HERE! HEY! OVER HERE! OVER HERE!" regardless of the fact that you are a biom and a half away from him. He will do it while you're gathering, he will do it while you're fighting, he will do it while you're reading the options, he will not stop until you do as he pleases. To make matters indefinitely worse, his spamming was completely irrelevant to the task I was doing. I was supposed to find a spot for a camp, and once I got to him, the game had completely forgotten about the camp quest and just started a monster hunting one. 

Six hours into the game (about 4 of which was figuring out the controls) and it does not feel like I am ever going to be let off the hook to just go and play. 

Oh, and almost forgot, the core concept of the game is hunting big scary monsters in order to get crafting materials and improve your gear. This whole ordeal is completely disregarded by the fact that they outright GIVE you weapons and armors in the beginning of a game that are about 5 tiers stronger than the most upgraded starting gear you are able to craft in the entire first region. I believe they call it a "catch up" mechanic to make you skip the early game.  Idiotic.

EDIT: IT GETS WORSE!
Several hours into the game after I had decided to give it a fair chance after all the nightmare I sat through, I have seen a person grapple onto an enemy. After 2 more hours of trying to figure out how it's done, I spend an hour more looking through guides on the internet only to figure out that the mechanic is locked behind a DLC. Among all the mess, this game is also PAY TO WIN!

For a [b]newcommer[/b] Monster Hunter World/Iceborne is [b]not[/b] the right one to start with. It almost feels like they tried to follow what [i]World of Warcraft[/i] tried, to get Monster Hunter more into a MMO style of play.  
There is[b]a ton[/b] stuff to do in Monster Hunter World/Iceborne, so at this point if you catch it on a sale... there are few games that can provide that amount of content.

The literally only bad side of Monster Hunter World/Iceborne is it's for the most part unexplained complexity. 

Like once you reach the end of World, in order to to being able to do every Optional 9* quests you have to gather tracks of Tempered Monsters. Those are easiest gathered in the Event Quests "A Simple Task" (T1 and T2 tracks) and "Tracking the Delivery" (T3 tracks) which the game doesn't tell you in any form. Then you need to go to the "Resource Center" and "Manage Investigations" and there you will see all the Tempered(purple) Quests you unlocked.

It is just sad that Capcom failed to provide more guidance on such things, unless I totally overlooked it and suck, which is possible.

[hr][/hr]
[b]Update[/b]

Played more, still not that great. Visuals are fine-to-good, still - better than MH:Rise. Plays better than it looks, but not by much. HUD is fine, but menus are 100% console. Menu translations are terrible and unhelpful. UX is abhorrent. VO is a bit obnoxious. Engaging, but monotonous. It is fine if you are looking for a grind. Boss fights are simple and easy to learn - you will have most on farm after 1-2 kills. The catch-up equipment turns the game into a speed-run and removes the grind, which is 80% of the game.

Hub area is extremely poorly designed for player efficiency. Gathering Hub area gets locked out (for no apparent reason) if you start a quest and aren't already in it. Auto-crafting is not quite as automatic as it could be. Gathering should be mindless but is annoying due to how they handle slinger ammo. Pretty much every interaction has higher priority than looting a boss, meaning you have to move loose items away before looting.

Their mission system, the 20/60s mission end timers, and their lobby-based multiplayer are useless and outdated, even for 2018. The mounted combat is boring and dumb: 11111111111. Resources respawn too fast (why do they respawn at all?!). Inventory is too limited for no reason: going back to camp, which is basically free, gives you access to your full stash. Too many Investigations (side quests) get generated too quickly. Additional cultivation plots unlock too late. RNG elemental damage isn't appropriate for a game that is supposed to reward a calculated play-style.

Sharpness mechanic isn't as bad as you initially think it is, but it is still useless and needs to die in a fire. There are 7 different "you can't do anything" status effects, which shows just how creatively bankrupt this series has become. So many useless, time-wasting mechanics in these games. They fill your playtime will dull drone work to inflate their numbers. Either that, or they are sadists and their player-base is full of masochists. So many better ways to spend your free time than playing MH.

Monster Hunter World is an absolute blast! The expansion takes the already fantastic Monster Hunter World and cranks it up to 11 with a chilly, visually stunning world that feels like a living, breathing ecosystem.

The new monsters are no joke ‚Äì they're tough, cunning, and a real test of your hunting skills. Each encounter is a unique experience, and the satisfaction of taking down these beasts is just unmatched. The progression system is addictive, and upgrading your gear to face even bigger challenges is incredibly rewarding.

What's impressive is how seamlessly Iceborne integrates into the base game. It doesn't feel like an add-on; it feels like a natural extension of the adventure. The story is engaging, filled with surprises, and keeps you hooked from the get-go. It's a great balance between expanding the lore and staying true to the Monster Hunter vibe.

The Master Rank difficulty brings a new layer of strategy into play. It's not just about hitting hard; it's about planning, adapting, and working together with your team. Multiplayer is as fun as ever, and tackling these challenges with friends adds a whole new level of excitement.

Seliana, the new hub, is a cozy little haven. It's a perfect contrast to the frosty surroundings, and the attention to detail in its design is fantastic. It's a great place to unwind between hunts.

The commitment from the developers is evident in the regular updates and events. It keeps the game feeling fresh, and the community is one of the friendliest I've encountered. There's a real sense of camaraderie and helpfulness, whether you're a seasoned hunter or a newbie.

In a nutshell, Monster Hunter World: Iceborne is a masterpiece. It builds on what made the base game great and introduces new elements that enhance the entire experience. Whether you're a die-hard fan or just dipping your toes into monster hunting, Iceborne is a must-play that guarantees hours of thrilling gameplay and a community that feels like a hunting family. Happy hunting, everyone!

Long IRL time spent on each Hunt/Mission.
Gear system a little unwieldy for newcomers.

I've been playing Monster Hunter from roughly it's midpoint, I started with Tri since I didn't have a Playstation back when 1 and 2 dropped, nor did I have a PSP for Freedom Unite. I've played Tri, Tri Ultimate, MonHun Portable 3rd, 4, 4 Ultimate, Generations, and into World and Rise (I didn't ever get to play Frontier, but damn would I have loved to), and I have to say that this game - World - is their masterpiece.

As it stands right now this is their best game to date and I don't mean this lightly. It's beginner and veteran friendly, supports a wide variety of playstyles due to the 14 different and unique weapons to choose from, and has a good progression system through the main storyline.

Some of the best features they've added to make this a more fast-paced and enjoyable game include (there's probably more I'm forgetting, but I'll add them as I replay through this game):
- No more loading screens in between individual numbered areas on the map.
- An auto crafting system that takes things you pick up and turns them into more useful items (Herbs -> Potions, etc.)
- Faster movement and no stamina usage when outside of a hostile monster's eyesight.
- Active resource grabbing allowing you to keep moving unless you're digging up bones or mining.
- A more proactive room decorating system with multiple rooms to decorate.
- To add to the decorations you can capture common and rare (sometimes extremely rare) fauna and keep them as pets in your room.
- The weapons attacks, combos, and new techniques provide further fluidity when fighting and chasing down monsters.
- The slinger pods that allow you to stun monsters and keep them from leaving areas is one of the best features.
- The sheer brilliance of some of the later Elder Dragon fights, of which I won't disclose for new players. But there's one in particular that is one of the sickest scenes I've ever seen.
- The addition of activatable items such as the Boosters and Mantles make this game extremely adaptive.
- A brand new style of hunt called the Siege - it was meant for 4 teams of 4 players to work together to take down giant monsters (you can now solo/4-man these).
- Being able to change the look of your armor without changing the armor itself is new to this game as well.

I do have a few complaints that are subject only to this game; The cutscenes really needed a skip feature and to allow your friends to still join you at the beginning of a hunt, but I think this is solely for the original story line (I forget if that's the case for Iceborne). Some of the weapons could have been designed better instead of monster parts slapped onto the base weapon, but I understand it could have been due to them learning a whole new system and putting some heavy time into the Quality of Life changes.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Game is charming and probably the best MH since 3U but has some baffling game design choices... As such this this is overrated title but at the same time, there's not much choice either.
Iceborne is a failure because of the idiotic spastic monsters (if you have played the older titles you'll understand) and because of the forced clutch claw mechanic which kills any variation from the hunts.
Steam is not my main platform for this game.

I highly recommend this. It is beautiful, well optimised and extremely rewarding to play. I'm going to list some issues I had with the game below, but for the amount of hours I got out of it, it was absolutely worth the price.

The thing that somewhat soured my experience was the end game content. There is so much missed opportunity here. Capcom could've opted to create a huge amount of interesting and fun end-game armour sets used for different situations and monster fights. Instead, all you get is Fatalis gear which is best-in-slot for almost all situations. The end game progression is extremely linear. Want to play longsword? Kill X, craft Y. Want to play hammer? Kill X, craft Y. Once you've done this there is nothing left to do at all. There are some variations, but really not enough to keep you interested long term unless you're fine with the repetitive nature. Not to mention weapons don't really feel significantly stronger than each other. I literally equipped the second best weapon in the game and I couldn't tell the difference in power over the one I was using before it. Same can be said for armour. It does not feel like it does anything at all.

Another thing that irked me end game is how it forces you into the Guiding Lands. Guiding Lands, for those unacquainted is basically a single map with all biomes in it. The game forces you to grind in this area leveling up different biomes within it to unlock monsters to fight so you can unlock their outfits. (Yes, it's mostly a cosmetic grind.) You can only have a few unlocked at once (which is another issue on its own) however ALL you have to do at the end of the game is unlock outfits, do event quests and grind Guiding Lands. Forever.

The game has some truly magnificent qualities like the soundtrack. The music is probably the best part of Monster Hunter. Most monsters have a unique theme that fits their personality and design, generally to a T. (Look up Rajang's theme, it's great.) The monster design is interesting, though not all of the fights are fun. Some feel like they have been designed to frustrate the player. See the monster 'Vaal Hazaak'. If you are a melee class, good luck fighting it. It halves your health if you go near it then slowly damages you over time. It's quite frustrating. Not to say it's impossible to kill, but it IS annoying.

Overall, MHW (and the Iceborne DLC) are good games, I just feel that the late game content is stale. Almost like they slapped it on at the end after making the rest of the game. As you can see, I got many, many hours out of it, so overall it was a great deal for the price I paid, I just feel that so much potential was wasted in regards to end game content. Add on to all of these issues the numerous small issues the game has, like whenever you need to speak to a vendor you need to listen to them rant about something random before they will open their shop, or the fact that the multiplayer is extremely tedious when it comes to grouping up with people, or even the fact that there are long loading screens even with an SSD, I really cannot recommend this game to anyone without them first understanding what they are getting into. You may not have an issue with the things I've listed, and in that situation this game is probably perfect for you. However if you, like me, feel that these issues could potentially spoil an otherwise good experience, you may want to give it a miss. It's entirely up to you.

Base game monster hunter world is wonderful and an extremely fun experience, I actually had a lot of fun learning new weapons and new play styles. 

Iceborne is just a stat check DLC. Even when you have gear appropriate for that hunt you will still be a 2-3 shot against any 360 move that all Iceborne monsters have and spam consistently. Also every IB monster has 3-5x the normal HP from any monster from base game with no additional stat increase to any of the new weapons added into it. So you are actually gated by an artificial health wall while also being a 2 shot when doing any IB monster hunt. Hunts in base game used to take me just 5-10mins on a non meta build now take 20-30 mins in IB. New DLC has made me better but hate the series more. 

Just get the Base game and play until you get to HR 50-100 then decide if you want a bullet sponge challenge before you get Iceborne.

Lots of time on PS4 before picking it up on PC. Easily the best, most newcomer friendly, immersive monster hunter yet. Methodical action combat with a focus on animation management and monster weakness knowledge. Lots and lots of gear customization with unique weapons all of which having completely different playstyles and unique style identity. Fantastic game to play with friends, hunt together! With many difficulty ranks it greatly pushes replayability/content amount as only the most dedicated will push into the highest ranks and challenges. All things considered for a game that came out in 2018, it's still one of the most complete, visually compelling, and fairly easy to learn, difficult to master game since.

Great grindy content. Sometimes awesome community. Even better than Rise.

Base Game: Much of the 'GOTY' talk is a little ridiculous though. Story is cringeworthy at best and all the morons carting at the first wave of Behemoth (normal) can't convince me that the gameplay is so good that there needed to be no story and only 5 true zones.

Icebourne: Recommended, awesome, and honestly rejuvenates the game in many forms; adding quality of life updates (things that feel like they should have been here all along) and the launcher/claw finally has use other than being where you launch flashpods. It totally bombards you with things to do and tutorials to explore; but ultimately becomes "how many reskins can be performed before you notice" and you may be sick to DEATH of the game by the time you reach the endgame. 

The strangest phenomenon is that Capcom's tried and true RPG mechanic "omg the boss is going to perform a nova/AOE attack so run" is a standard M.O. late game and for maybe six months of playing this game, not many people have "wisened up" to this point; The last 4 patches spanned over the last 8 months or so are all different bosses on this focus/mechanic and it's real shit with pugs. In fact, with the exception of some shooting games, I don't think I've had WORSE pugs than in this game. Some fantastic new friends, but some real stinkers too.

Not recommended because it's really hard to sell this amount of time wasting to the standard player, but if you enjoy the series or Anime Souls, join the party.

Monster Hunter Iceborne

Iceborne is an absolute game-changer, making Monster Hunter World feel like a whole new game. The arctic-themed region of Hoarfrost Reach is stunning, and the new monsters and improved game-play mechanics really up the difficulty. The endgame is super challenging, keeping you on your toes even after you've put in hundreds of hours. The expansion is so massive that it almost feels like a sequel, and it's a better version of an already amazing game.

G'day! As someone who hasn't been playing this series since 2008, has not easily amassed over Ten Thousand Hours in the series starting with Monster Hunter Freedom Unite on the PSP.
i can easily say this is genuinely one of the best Action RPG's ever created.
This game is NOT easy, it'll take a ton work to learn the mechanics of each weapon, and all the individual Monster Fights (But you could just look up a guide).
You have 14 weapons to pick from, from a basic Sword and Shield to a fully automatic Chaingun.
But after you learn the fights, learn your weapons (unless you just use dual swords), start getting your builds and gear set up, nothing is as satisfying as putting down the guy who's been kicking your butt all night, and turning him into a pair of pants.
I'm extremely excited for Wilds, to continue the story as long as the handler is killed within the first 5 seconds.
If you haven't played this, OR Monster Hunter:Rise yet, i highly recommend them both.
But while Monster Hunter world is currently not on sale as I type, i 100% recommend this game.

Updated Review about 400 hours later:
Still the peak of the series. Cut a lot of more experimental stuff to focus on the basics to do those very well.
Every single weapon feels impactful to use, fights are challenging and require adapting in both playstyle and armor/upgrades, environments are dense and feel rewarding to explore and learn the layout of. 

My only complaint would be that the way multiplayer story progression is handled is a little weird (having to watch a  cutscene before being joinable or able to join lots of missions means all but one player have to start and abandon the mission to join another player) and sometimes the online connection can be a bit unstable.
But I can still return to this game over and over again and have as much fun as i did when i first played it.

Original Review: Played the Game already on Xbox One and Xbox One X before for about 60 hours.
In short: Great game, finally brings Monster Hunter to the modern times, since while it was stuck on Nintendo consoles it didnt really advance from the state it was on when it was on PSP in the 2000s.
Perfect balance between useful changes, next gen improvements and old charme.
Some monsters have some questionable hitboxes, leading to occasional frustration, but not ebough to harm the experience overall.

PC port seems great. I know some people had issues, but for me it runs like a charm.
Detailed settings for graphics and gameplay, can even rebind secondary keybinds on Keyboard. I have a Controller, but actually prefer Keyboard in this case because the shortcuts you can use on PC are really useful, Mouse fully works even in menus.
Very well worth the wait since the console launch, this is the best way to experience Monster Hunter World now.
I love monster hunter. this is my favorite game

Coming from MH3:U on the Wii U, they took monster hunter formula and improved it in every way. Everything is implemented as a masterclass to gameplay, visual, sound,  design. Every aspect of this game is perfect as a Monster Hunter series game.

Look at the global achievement statistics and you'll see that this game's completion rate is very high. The main story is about 45 hours, but if you want to grind and melt faces, try all the weapons, or are new, it should take longer.

My only personal gripe is the story is constantly asking you to continue it, I feel like in MH3U, back when I was terrible at MH, much more of it was spent on grinding quests without the story bothering you, but that was back before Dark Souls was really a thing. That one thing doesn't come close to a mark on the armour of this perfect game.

This is the first MonHun game I have put any real amount of time into.  The first game in the series I played was Tri.

The Good:
There is a crap ton of content.  Way more than you normally see in games these days and Iceborn adds even more.  There's around 40 to 50 huntable monsters in the base game and a lot of smaller farming creatures.  This gives you a lot of variability in hunts and the ability to switch to different targets when you a tired of hunting a certain type of monster.

There are a ton of items to be found, crafted, and unlocked that have specific uses for specific hunts that make the hunts more manageable and require you to prepare for the hunts properly.  Generally this is true for hunts at your rank or at the upper end of the next one down  (High Rank Pickle will need proper planning even if you are Master Rank for example).

There are also 10 to 12 weapon types which are all very distinct and offer different gameplay styles.  Certain hunts are made easier using certain weapon types which encourages players to try out all of them.  Each weapon had to be constructed from materials collected from the game world and harvested from huntable monsters.  Some of these materials can be hard to obtain, so there is a large amount of grinding introduced; however, the grind is manageable because of the number of possible monsters to hunt.

Overall grind in this game is handled extremely well for a game as grindy as this one.  Lots of thought went into the systems to make this possible and shows an above average understanding of proper game design.  Introduce multiplayer into the mix and the grinding goes from still somewhat tedious to usually fun which is an amazing achievement.

There are a number of features, such as the Trailriders and the Argosy, that make getting monster materials a bit easier and help to reduce the grind slightly.  In addition to this, capturing monsters, using the Hunting Guiide to break breakable parts of monsters, and some other systems allow you to get more parts including a better chance to obtain rarer ones.

One of the best Steam co-op integrations in gaming.  Accept a join request from a message and then hit the menu option.  Very simple, more AAA studios with Steam co-op support need to do this.


The Meh:
The writing in the game isn't that good and neither is the story.  Thankfully the story is pretty irrelevant in this game.

While the grind is one of the better designed aspects of the game there are still some places it could be improved.  This applies mainly around gems and the material tree.  Iceborn weapons require World base weapons and materials to be made.  These weapons should have been placed into their own trees without needing materials from the base game to be made from scratch.

Upgrading from base weapons is fine, but those base weapons should have been the start of the trees.  In addition, augments from the base game seem to be removed when upgraded to Iceborn weapons (I haven;'t actually done this yet because I think that is what happens, so take this with a grain of salt).

The cultivation system makes item material grinding a bit easier, but you can only, as far as I currently know, cultivate two item material types at present so you will still need to farm materials in some cases.

Certain item limits don't make much sense (like certain kinds of traps being limited to 1).

Hit boxes and collision meshes sometimes don't make sense.  For example, cutting off the tail of a monster sometimes still results in that monster being able to hit you with their tail further away that it seems they should be able to.


The Bad:
Monster size scaling can make otherwise normal fights impossible (large Black Diablos for example).  Size has too big of an impact on some stats.  On the other side, smaller monsters are too easy to kill.  Size scaling refers to the size of a monster compared to an average version of that monster, the size varies from hunt to hunt.  This is a good system overall, there were some oversights that make it annoying.

Astra's design is bad.  Things are not laid out in a natural manner, the hub is really bad and looks low effort compared to Seliana's.

Can't set the rank of expeditions (as far as I know).  Expeditions allow you to free hunt/gather materials; materials and monsters will respawn (good feature).  The problem is that they are always scaled to your Hunter Rank and you can't change it so if you wanted to just troll around in low-rank Ancient Woods and beat the shit out of angry Barnies (Anjanaths) for low rank parts, you can't.  You would have to do quests for that which are time and enemy limited.
 

Overall Monster Hunter World is an amazing game with well thought-out systems and game design.  While the stuff that doesn't matter, like the story, is pretty weak, the important systems and features are well designed and offer quality of life features around grinding that put almost all other games to shame.

MHW gets a 9/10 from me and is a must play for any gamer that enjoys simulation adventure games.

G'day! As someone who's been playing this series since 2008, has easily amassed over Ten Thousand Hours in the series starting with Monster Hunter Freedom Unite on the PSP.
i can easily say this is genuinely one of the best Action RPG's ever created.
This game is NOT easy, it'll take a ton work to learn the mechanics of each weapon, and all the individual Monster Fights.
You have 14 weapons to pick from, from a basic Sword and Shield to a fully automatic Chaingun. 
But after you learn the fights, learn your weapons, start getting your builds and gear set up, nothing is as satisfying as putting down the guy who's been kicking your butt all night, and turning him into a pair of pants.
I'm extremely excited for Wilds, to continue the story.
If you haven't played this, OR Monster Hunter:Rise yet, i highly recommend them both.
But while Monster Hunter world is currently on sale, i 100% recommend this game.

Monster Hunter World. There is a lot to say about this game, I could honestly go on for a while.
This was actually my first Monster Hunter experience, I don‚Äôt remember how it started but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôll ever really end, and I‚Äôm here to enjoy that fact. 

I played this game with the glaive, swinging it around like a little monkey man to begin and breaking every monster‚Äôs back doing air combos by the end. Couldn‚Äôt be a more fun and potentially chaotic way to play, I never have a bad time and my party members don‚Äôt mind some
easy mounts from that. 
I dipped into Hammer as well. Simple, effective, incredibly painful (it definitely looks to be). The visual of sliding down a slope and then suddenly launching into a charged hammer roll only to bonk a monster, or even get a mount, is something wonderful and hard to beat.

I fought and I captured and I most definitely blew up many monsters on the way, to Iceborne and the guiding lands. I can say confidently that the Guiding Lands are an incredible piece of late/endgame content. Refreshing, honestly very rewarding, and the pinnacle of how I imagine World, an endless run around with everything at your disposal, constantly collecting materials and hunting Kulu Ya Ku and the occasional Elder that pops in.

I think this game is worth the time. I played it mostly with friends but had many solo moments that were just as rewarding.

Just like any other monster hunter, if this is your first in the series, just be prepared for a steep learning curve. However, once you dedicate the time to learn, it is incredibly rewarding. I would encourage you to watch YouTube videos on the different weapons and how to play them to make the most of your experience.
